Date: Thu 31 Aug 2017. Source: Global Polio Eradication Initiative (edited) (http://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/this-week/)   Poliovirus weekly update 30-Aug-2017, World Health Organization  New wild poliovirus cases reported this week: 0 Total number of wild poliovirus cases in 2017: 9 Total number of wild poliovirus cases in 2016: 37  New cVDPV cases reported this week: 7 Total number of cVDPV cases in 2017: 47 Total number of cVDPV cases in 2016: 5  Headlines  - Pakistan and Afghanistan polio eradication teams convened last week in Islamabad to follow up on the southern corridor (Quetta Block - Greater Kandahar) joint planning for the upcoming low transmission season. The meeting was attended by the national teams as well as the staff from the southern region of Afghanistan and Balochistan province of Pakistan.  - Summary of newly-reported viruses this week: Pakistan: 2 new wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) environmental positive samples; Syria: 6 new circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) cases; and, DR Congo: 1 new cVDPV2 case. Additionally, pre-notification was received this week of a new WPV1 case from Karachi, Pakistan, the 1st in Karachi since January 2016. The case will be officially reflected in next week's global data reporting.  Afghanistan  - No new wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) cases were reported in the past week. The total number of WPV1 cases for 2017 remains 6. The most recent case in the country had onset of paralysis on 10 Jul 2017, from Zabul province, neighbouring Kandahar province and Pakistan. - Preparations continue for a targeted vaccination round in the southern region of the country, scheduled on 11 Sep 2017  Pakistan  - No new wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) case was reported in the past week; the total number of WPV1 cases for 2017 remains 3. The most recent case in the country had onset of paralysis on 11 Jun 2017, from Killa Abdullah, Balochistan. - Two new wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) environmental positive samples were reported in the past week, from Karachi, Sindh (collected on 7 and 12 Aug 2017). - Additionally, pre-notification was received this week of a new WPV1 case from Karachi, Pakistan. The case will be officially reflected in next week's global data reporting. Karachi had previously been a key reservoir for WPV1 in Pakistan. Analysis is ongoing to determine the origin of this latest case and a response is being planned. The case had onset of paralysis on 11 Aug 2017. The last previous case from Karachi is from January 2016. - The National Task Force for Polio Eradication convened last week, chaired by the Prime Minister of Pakistan and attended by the senior leadership from the national and provincial levels. The Task force reviewed the revised National Emergency Action Plan 2017/18 and discussed mechanisms of accelerating the implementation of strategies to stop WPV1 transmission in the key hot spots. - Under the National Emergency Action Plan for polio eradication, the country is planning to implement 2 nation-wide and 2 sub-national vaccination rounds from September to December 2017.  Nigeria - - No new cases of wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) were reported in the past week. The total number of WPV1 cases for 2016 remains 4 and no cases have been reported in 2017. The most recent case had onset of paralysis on 21 Aug 2016 in Monguno Local Government Area (LGA), Borno. - Nigeria continues to implement emergency response to the detected WPV1 strain and cVDPV2 strains affecting the country (last detected in 2016). - Detection of the polio cases in Nigeria underscores the risk posed by low-level undetected transmission and the urgent need to strengthen subnational surveillance.  Lake Chad Basin  - The detection of wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) (Borno, Nigeria in 2016) and cVDPV2 (Borno and Sokoto provinces in Nigeria in 2016) continue to pose a risk to the neighbouring countries of the Lake Chad basin and hence an outbreak response plan is being implemented as part of the response to the Nigeria outbreak. - Emergency outbreak response efforts continue across the Lake Chad basin, together with activities to fill subnational surveillance gaps across the region.  Central Africa  - One new case of cVDPV2 was reported in the past week in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DR Congo), from Haut Lomami province, with onset of paralysis on 20 Jun 2017. The total number of cVDPV2 cases this year 2017 is now 8, in 2 separate outbreaks: in Haut Lomami province (6 cases, with onset of paralysis of the most recent case on 20 Jun 2017); and in Maniema province (2 cases with onset of paralysis on 26 Mar 2017 and 18 Apr 2017, with an additional isolate detected in a healthy individual with sample collection on 2 May 2017). - Confirmation of additional cases is not unexpected at this time. Outbreak response is taking place, including use of monovalent oral polio vaccine type 2 (mOPV2) in line with internationally-agreed outbreak response protocols, targeting more than 750 000 children under the age of 5 across the 2 provinces. \n- The 1st mOPV2 round was implemented on 27-29 Jun 2017 in the 2 affected provinces; and the 2nd mOPV2 round ran from 13-15 Jul 2017 in Haut Lomami and 20-22 Jul 2017 in Maniema. - Surveillance and immunization activities are being strengthened in neighbouring countries.  Middle East  - In Syria, 6 new cases of cVDPV2 were officially reported in the past week from Deir-Ez-Zour governorate, bringing the total number of cases in this outbreak to 39. Onset of paralysis of these cases is between 3 Mar 2017 and 10 Jul 2017. The bulk of all cases are from Deir-Ez-Zour, the epicentre of this outbreak. - Confirmation of additional cases is not unexpected at this time and would not change the operational situation, as outbreak response plans are being finalized and implemented, in line with internationally-agreed outbreak response protocols. Two vaccination campaigns are planned for both Deir-Ez-Zour and Raqqa governorates. - The 1st mOPV2 round in Deir-Ez-Zour was successfully carried out between 22-26 Jul 2017. Independent post-campaign monitoring reflected coverage of 88.4 percent (based on caregiver recall). - The 2nd immunization round for Deir-Ez-Zor governorate started on 22 Aug 2017 and is ongoing. Monovalent OPV2 is being provided for children between 0-59 months of age, and inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) for children 2-23 months. In addition to polio vaccines, Aqua Tabs are being provided to families for water purification - 2.5 tons of water purification tablets for 400 000 people have been disseminated at health centers. - Plans are being finalized to mitigate the risks of further spread from the outbreak zone to neighbouring areas and countries, including immunization of at-risk populations in northwest Syria, Turkey and Lebanon.  Officially reported wild poliovirus cases as of 29 Aug 2017  Total global cases in 2017: 9 (compared with 22 for the same period in 2016) - Total in endemic countries in 2017: 9 (compared with 22 for the same period in 2016) - Total in non-endemic countries in 2017: 0 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016)  - Afghanistan: 6 cases in 2017 (compared with 7 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 10 Jul 2017 - Pakistan: 3 cases in 2017 (compared with 13 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 11 Jun 1017 - Nigeria: 0 case in 2017 (compared with 2 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 21 Aug 2016  Total global cases in 2016: 37 - Total in endemic countries: 37 - Total in non-endemic countries: 0  Officially reported cVDPV cases as of 29 Aug 2017 - Total global cases in 2017: 47 (compared with 3 for the same period in 2016) - Syrian Arab Republic: 39 cases in 2017 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 10 Jul 2017 - Democratic Republic of the Congo: 8 cases in 2017 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 20 Jun 2017 - Pakistan: 0 case in 2017 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 17 Dec 2016 - Nigeria: 0 case in 2017 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 28 Oct 2016 - Lao People's Democratic Republic: 0 case in 2017 (compared with 3 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 11 Jan 2016  Total global cases in 2016: 5 - Total in endemic countries: 2 - Total in non-endemic countries: 3   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Syria - WHO Situation Report. Date: Wed 30 Aug 2017. Source: WHO UNICEF Situation Report 11 (edited) (http://www.emro.who.int/images/stories/syria/WHO_UNICEF_Situation_Report_11_cVDPV2_outbreak_Syria_29.8.17_3.pdf?ua=1)   Key Highlights  - Six (6) new cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week: 4 cases are from Mayadeen district and 2 are from Boukamal district, Deir Ez-Zor governorate. - The total number of cVDPV2 cases is 39. All confirmed cases to date have had onset of paralysis before 14 Jul 2017. - Final lab results are pending for an additional 5 poliovirus type-2 (PV2) isolates (3 from Mayadeen and 1 from Boukamal districts, Deir Ez-Zor governorate, and 1 from Thawra district, Raqqa governorate). - The 2nd immunization round for Deir Ez-Zor started on 22 Aug 2017 and is ongoing due to high levels of population movement in and out of the governorate during the round. - WHO has organized the redistribution of vaccines and mapping of population movements to increase reach. An additional 90 000 mOPV2 doses are being transported from Damascus to Deir Ez-Zor, to cater for population influxes from As-Sukhnah, Homs governorate, and Al-Qa'im in Iraq. Corrective measures are expected to extend the round by 2 days. - Preparations for the 2nd immunization round for Raqqa are underway. - The total number of AFP cases detected in Deir Ez-Zor governorate since the beginning of 2017 is 122 (91 from Mayadeen, 10 from Deir Ez-Zor, and 21 from Boukamal districts). Raqqa governorate has reported 16 AFP cases (5 from Raqqa, 10 from Tell Abyad, and 1 from Thawra districts). Homs governorate has reported 28 AFP cases (12 from Homs city, 13 from Rastan, 1 from Tadmour and 2 from Talkalakh districts).  more details on the vaccination activities and future plans are available at the source URL as well as the epidemic curve and graphic representation of the vaccination status of non-polio acute flaccid paralysis cases by governorate and district. - Mod.MPP   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  In the above global summary, there is still identified transmission ongoing in Pakistan as seen by the positive environmental sample in Karachi as well as the early report on a case of WPV1 associated disease in Karachi. It will be interesting to learn of the genetic profile of the environmental isolates in Karachi (from this past week as well as from a few weeks ago) and compare them with the newly identified WPV1 associated case in Karachi to see if they are genetically related.  There has been more activity associated with cVDPV2 in both Syria and the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DR Congo), with 6 newly confirmed cases in Syria and 1 newly confirmed case in the DR Congo. According to the Situation Report in section <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> above, there are still 5 additional PV2 (poliovirus type 2) isolates in Syria undergoing final testing  4 from Deir al Zour and 1 from Raqqa. Hence there will probably be more cases confirmed in the coming days or weeks. I have not been able to identify similar report information from the DR Congo outbreak so it is not clear if the transmission has been interrupted leaving a total of 8 cases, or if there are still probable cases pending confirmation.  A map showing the global distribution of all WPV1 associated cases and cVDPV associated cases can be found at: (http://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/).  HealthMap/ProMED maps can be found at: Syria: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/86) Pakistan: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140) DR Congo: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/194) - Mod.MPP  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"185":{"title":"Crimean-Congo hem. fever - Afghanistan: (HR) ","date":["28","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Crimean-Congo hem. fever - Afghanistan: (HR) [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Mon 28 Aug 2017 20:17 AFT. Source: Pajhwok Afghan News (edited) (https://www.pajhwok.com/en/2017/08/28/congo-virus-kills-13-infects-42-herat)   Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) has killed 13 people in western Herat province this year 2017, with another 42 being treated for the deadly virus, according to officials.  CCHF is a viral disease. Symptoms may include fever, muscle pains, headache, vomiting, diarrhea, and bleeding into the skin. The CCHF virus is typically spread by tick bites or contact with livestock carrying the disease.  Health officials in Herat advised people to be careful these days due to increased interaction with livestock in the wake of Eidul Adha Sacrifice Feast; 31 Aug-4 Sep 2017, when Muslims across the globe slaughter millions of animals.  Public health director in Herat Abdul Hakim Tamana said many people lost their lives to the Congo virus in the province this year 2017. He said 55 Congo cases were registered in the civil hospital since late March and of the patients, 13 had died. The deceased included 7 men and 6 women, he added.  Tamana said the virus spread from animals and people slaughtering animals should wear gloves.  A livestock farmer, who has contracted Congo virus, said: \"When I slaughtered the sheep, its blood covered my hands and later I started falling sick.\"  Ahmad Khalil Waez, animal healthcare director, said citizens should be careful while slaughtering animals to avoid contracting the Congo virus. He said a butcher should used special glasses, coat, gloves, mask, and shoes while slaughtering the animal.  People mainly contract the CCHF virus from infected ticks or contact with infected animal blood and tissue.  There are no vaccines available to immunize animals but precautionary measures include disinfection of livestock pens, submerging livestock in solutions for decontamination, and meat packaging safeguards.  The virus has had a presence in neighbouring Iran where the virus killed 3 people in 2015.  According to the World Health Organization, CCHF's mortality rate is about 30 percent and is endemic to Africa, the Balkans and Ukraine, the Middle East, and Central Asia.  CCHF was first detected in the Crimea in 1944 and then in the Congo in 1969. In 2011, it was detected for the first time in ticks in Spain.  Byline: Storai Karimi   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  In 2008, a major outbreak was reported in Herat City, western Afghanistan, with approximately 60 suspected and 6 confirmed cases. Later, a cross-sectional seroprevalence survey was conducted among livestock-owning households in the same districts of Herat City where the outbreak had occurred, which showed that IgG seroprevalence was 11.2 and 75.0 percent in humans (n = 330) and livestock (n = 132), respectively ((https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3310665/)).  In 2016, 66 cases had been reported by 7 Sep, with 12 deaths ((http://www.emro.who.int/afg/afghanistan-news/cchf-eid.html)). CCHF virus has been observed in over 30 countries, including in Africa (Democratic Republic of Congo, South Africa, Nigeria, Senegal, Uganda, Tanzania, Mauritania, Kenya), Asia (Pakistan, Afghanistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, China), the Middle East (Iran, Iraq, United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Oman), and southeastern Europe (the Russian Federation, Bulgaria, Albania, Kosovo, Turkey, Greece, and Spain) ((https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23458713)).  People most at risk of contracting CCHF include animal herders, livestock workers, butchers, slaughterhouse workers, and veterinarians. Healthcare workers are also at risk of infection through unprotected contact with infectious blood and body fluids while caring for patients. There is no vaccine available for either people or animals, which means prevention is crucial. - Mod.UBA  Maps of Afghanistan can be seen at (http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/afghanistan_admin-2009.jpg) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1757). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Albania":{},"Algeria":{},"American Samoa":{},"Andorra":{},"Angola":{},"Antigua and Barbuda":{},"Argentina":{},"Armenia":{},"Aruba":{},"Australia":{"114":{"title":"Measles update (43): Asia and Pacific, Europe, demographics\r\n\t","date":["26","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Measles update (43): Asia and Pacific, Europe, demographics\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  In this update: Asia and Pacific  <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Japan: travel alert <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia): ex Italy  Europe  <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Germany (Berlin): 2014-15 <br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Romania  Measles immunity gaps  <br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Role of demographics   Asia and Pacific  <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Japan: travel alert. Date: Mon 21 Aug 2017. Source: The Mainichi (edited) (https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20170821/p2g/00m/0dm/077000c)   Japan's health ministry has issued a warning for people traveling to Europe on the back of an outbreak of measles in countries such as Italy and Romania. The Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare is advising tourists to go to hospital if they develop a high fever or generalized rash after returning to Japan.  Although the World Health Organization verified that Japan has eliminated infections of endemic measles strains in 2015, group infections originating from people who contracted the disease abroad are spreading in the country. As of 6 Aug 2017, the number of patients reached 169 this year in Japan, already eclipsing the figure in the previous year.  About 4100 patients in Italy and around 6500 patients in Romania have already been confirmed as of August 2017 compared with about 860 and 2000, respectively, throughout 2016, according to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control.  Symptoms of the highly contagious disease include runny nose, red and watery eyes, high fever, and rash. The virus is spread through coughing and sneezing and can cause complications such as pneumonia and can even result in death in one in 1000 patients, according to the ministry. The ministry recommends people traveling overseas to check their vaccination records and take an additional shot if they have only been vaccinated once.  The disease was prevalent about a decade ago in Japan with the number of patients soaring to over 10 000 in 2008 but the country was later considered as free from infections of the virus.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Japan can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/156). - Mod.LK   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia): ex Italy. Date: Fri 25 Aug 2017 5:36 PM AEST. Source: News.com.au, Australian Associated Press (AAP) report (edited) (http://www.news.com.au/national/breaking-news/fourth-case-of-measles-at-perth-school/news-story/ece041f55111645e10f70046d92479dd)   A 4th child has been diagnosed with measles at Perth Waldorf School Western Australia, more than a week after the health department gave an on-site vaccine to students. A Health Department spokeswoman confirmed the latest case, which came 3 weeks after the highly contagious disease was first detected in an unvaccinated year 10 student who had returned from Italy.  Revelations that about half the school's 400 students were unvaccinated against the disease led the Health Department to offer a voluntary, free on-site vaccine to students, but it is unknown how many took up the offer.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Maps of Australia can be seen at (http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gi) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62426). - Mod.LK   Europe  <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Germany (Berlin): 2014-15. Date: Thu 24 Aug 2017. Source: Eurosurveillance edition 2017; 22(34) (edited) (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=22861)   ref: Werber D, Hoffmann A, Santibanez S, et al. Large measles outbreak introduced by asylum seekers and spread among the insufficiently vaccinated resident population, Berlin, October 2014 to August 2015. Euro Surveill. 2017; 22(34): pii=30599 - Abstract  The largest measles outbreak in Berlin since 2001 occurred from October 2014 to August 2015. Overall, 1344 cases were ascertained, 86 per cent (with available information) unvaccinated, including 146 (12 per cent) asylum seekers. Median age was 17 years (interquartile range: 4-29 years), 26 per cent were hospitalised and a 1 year old child died. Measles virus genotyping uniformly revealed the variant 'D8-Rostov-Don' and descendants. The virus was likely introduced by and initially spread among asylum seekers before affecting Berlin's resident population. Among Berlin residents, the highest incidence was in children younger than 2 years, yet most cases (52 per cent) were adults. Post-exposure vaccinations in homes for asylum seekers, not always conducted, occurred later (median: 7.5 days) than the recommended 72 hours after onset of the 1st case and reached only half of potential contacts. Asylum seekers should not only have non-discriminatory, equitable access to vaccination, they also need to be offered measles vaccination in a timely fashion, that is, immediately upon arrival in the receiving country. Supplementary immunisation activities targeting the resident population, particularly adults, are urgently needed in Berlin.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Germany can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5857). - Mod.LK   <br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Romania. Date: Fri 25 August 2017. Source: Romania Insider (edited) (https://www.romania-insider.com/measles-kills-iraqi-refugee/)   The ongoing measles outbreak keeps making victims in Romania. A 10 month old girl, who was a refugee from Iraq, became the 33rd person to die of the infection, reports local Digi24. The girl arrived in Romania on 7 Jul 2017 with her family, and the doctors diagnosed her with measles in August. They also discovered that the child was suffering from malnutrition and severe psychomotor retardation.  The measles outbreak is still a major problem in Romania, with more than 8900 cases reported across the country until 25 Aug 2017, including 33 deaths, according to data from the National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT). Most deaths were registered in Timis (9), Dolj (7), and Arad (6) counties.  Measles is a highly contagious respiratory infection caused by a virus. It causes a total-body skin rash and flu-like symptoms, including fever, cough, and runny nose. According to information posted on WHO's website, the virus is highly contagious, spreading by coughing and sneezing, close personal contact, and direct contact with infected nasal or throat secretions. Unvaccinated young children pose the highest risk of measles and its complications, including death.  The Romanian Government adopted earlier this month August 2017 a draft bill on the organization and financing of population vaccination (https://www.romania-insider.com/romania-draft-bill-vaccination/). The project was sent to the Parliament for approval and could come into force in January 2018.  byline: Irina Marica   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Measles tends to be more severe in children who are malnourished, especially children who are also vitamin A deficient. And complications are commoner and more serious in malnourished children. Because of complications such as diarrhoea, measles may lead to failure to thrive. Infection with measles virus may lead to kwashiorkor or marasmus in children who are underweight at the time that they get infected. Therefore, measles may result in, or aggravate, malnutrition.  Maps of Romania can be found at (http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/romania/ro111aa/romania_pol.jpg) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/122). - Mod.LK   Measles immunity gaps  <br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Role of demographics. Date: Sat 26 Aug 2017. Source: News-Medical/Life Sciences (edited) (https://www.news-medical.net/news/20170826/New-study-highlights-role-played-by-demographics-in-the-spread-of-measles.aspx)   Even if the incidence of measles infection has decreased by at least 90 per cent worldwide since the introduction of the vaccine, measles is still one of the major causes of death in children among vaccine-preventable diseases. Regular measles epidemics are reported in developing countries and recurrent episodic outbreaks occur in the developed world.  A new study by Bocconi University and Bruno Kessler Foundation analyzing 9 countries (Australia, Ethiopia, Kenya, Ireland, Italy, South Korea, Singapore, the United Kingdom, and the United States) and published in The Lancet Infectious Diseases see reference below, highlights the role played by demographics in the spread of measles and concludes that future vaccination strategies in high-fertility countries should focus on increasing childhood immunization rates, while immunization campaigns targeting adolescents and young adults are required in low fertility countries.  Using a transmission model calibrated on historical serological data the authors estimate that the susceptible proportion of the population (that is, unprotected against the infection) varies from about 3 per cent in the UK to more than 12.5 per cent in Ethiopia, with astonishing differences in its age composition, due to different vaccination strategies and divergent demographic trends. While the percentage of over-15 among susceptible individuals in Ethiopia and Kenya is, respectively, 28 per cent and 43 per cent, adolescents and young adults represent 74 per cent of unprotected individuals in South Korea, 66 per cent in Italy and 53 per cent in the US, with considerable immunity gaps in individuals aged 30-40 years.  \"Every effort to increase the vaccination coverage rate among children is praiseworthy\", says Alessia Melegaro, a Bocconi professor and principal investigator of DECIDE, the ERC European Research Council-funded project which produced the article, \"but in some developed countries it's the lack of coverage among adolescents and adults that poses a serious threat to the goal of eliminating measles.\"  \"Measles incidence could increase, in the next decades, in Italy, Australia, and Singapore and Ethiopia is at high risk of future large epidemics\", says Stefano Merler from Bruno Kessler Foundation, \"and this is particularly worrying considering that individuals get infected later in life when the disease is more severe. The median age at infection for 2015 was estimated to be 5-10 years in the UK, Ireland, and Ethiopia; 10-15 years in the USA, Australia, Singapore, and Kenya; and older than 20 years in Italy and South Korea\".  The proposed model shows that the introduction of the measles vaccine, which occurred at different times in the 9 countries, has considerably reduced the disease burden in terms of disability-adjusted life-years (DALYs), a measure expressed as the number of years lost because of illness, disability, or early death. Every vaccine dose averts 2 or 3 weeks of DALYs in the developed world and around 20 weeks in Kenya and Ethiopia. Which translates into 2-mln years 2 million DALYs since the vaccine introduction in the UK, 13-mln 13 million DALYs in the US, and 36-mln 36 million DALYs in Ethiopia.  \"Vaccination has undoubtedly achieved incredible results in terms of public health. In particular,\" continues Prof Melegaro \"our analysis showed that routine 1st dose vaccine administration has been responsible for more than 90 per cent of the overall number of vaccine-immunized individuals in most countries. In Ethiopia and Kenya, catch-up and follow-up campaigns substantially mitigated the effect of suboptimum routine vaccine coverage, generating 25-45 per cent of the immunized fraction of the population. Tailoring immunization campaigns to achieve measles eradication goals is essential and currently, for some countries, this means considering also the role of unprotected adolescents and young adults.\"   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Reference - Trentini F, Poletti P, Merler S, Melegaro A. Measles immunity gaps and the progress towards elimination: a multi-country modelling analysis. Lancet Infect Dis. 2017. pii: S1473-3099(17)30421-8. Epub ahead of print; (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28807627).   While it is recommended that children get 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine, starting with the 1st dose at 12 through 15 months of age, and the 2nd dose at 4 through 6 years of age, this study emphasizes that it is important that adolescents and young adults also are up to date on their MMR vaccination. - Mod.LK  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"115":{"title":"Dengue/DHF update (10): Asia, Pacific, Africa, research, WHO\r\n\t","date":["25","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Dengue/DHF update (10): Asia, Pacific, Africa, research, WHO\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nDENGUE/DHF UPDATE (10): ASIA, PACIFIC, AFRICA, RESEARCH, WHO\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cases in various countries Asia\n\nSri Lanka\n- National\n- National\n- National\nIndia\n- National\n- Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Assam\n- Delhi\n- Tamil Nadu (Coimbatore)\n- Tamil Nadu\n- Tamil Nadu (Chennai)\n- Tamil Nadu (Chennai)\n- Kerala\n- Karnataka\n- Karnataka (Gulbarga)\n- Karnataka (Gulbarga)\n- West Bengal (Kolkata)\n- West Bengal (Birbhum)\n- West Bengal (Siliguri)\n- Odisha (Ganjam)\n- Odisha\n- Gujarat (Ahmedabad)\n- Jharkhand (Jamshedpur)\n- Telangana (Hyderabad)\nPakistan\n- Sindh (Karachi)\n- Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar)\n- Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar)\n- Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar)\nChina\n- Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region ex Viet Nam (susp)\n- Hong Kong SAR\n- Macau SAR\n- Macau SAR\nTaiwan\nMyanmar\n- National\n- Kayah\nIndonesia\n- Papua (Jayapura)\nViet Nam\n- National\n- National\n- Mekong Delta\n- Hanoi\n- Ha Nam\nPhilippines\n- National\n- Cebu\n- Negros Occidental\n- Negros Occidental (Bacolod City)\n- Cavite (Trece Martires City)\nLaos\n- National\nJapan ex Côte d'Ivoire Pacific\n\n- Samoa\n- Samoa\n- Samoa\n- Samoa\n- Fiji\n- French Polynesia (Tahiti) Africa\n\n- Côte d'Ivoire\n- Côte d'Ivoire <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Research\n- Viral persistence\n- Air travel related spread of dengue\n- Visual impact <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> World Health Organization update \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cases in various countries\nAsia\n\nSri Lanka\n- National. 26 Jul 2017. Sri Lanka has now notified 107 015 cases,\nwhich WHO estimates is 4.3 times more than the average number of cases\nusually reported (http://tinyurl.com/ycvszzs8). - National. 19 Aug 2017. Since the beginning of 2017, Sri Lanka has\nreported 137 279 suspected dengue cases and more than 300 deaths.\nAbout 44.5 per cent of dengue cases were reported from the Western\nprovince. This compares with about 39 000 cases reported from January\nto August 2016, and 55 150 cases during the entire year 2016.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-updates-vietnam-sri-lanka-32087/) - National. 25 Aug 2017. Through Fri 25 Aug 2017, Sri Lanka has\nofficially reported 144 052 cases and, as of 3 Aug 2017, 3327 people\nhave died.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-epidemic-waning-sri-lanka-university-jaffna-science-faculty-closed-september-83024/) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Sri Lanka can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/144). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ India\n- National. 31 Jul 2017. 11 832 more cases than in 2016 and 46 deaths,\n11 more than in 2016. The total has risen to 28 702, with 2536 cases\nand 10 deaths last week week of 24 Jul 2017. Floods continued to wreak\nhavoc in the 3 states, which reported 88 more dengue-related deaths.\nOfficials said 33 more dengue-related deaths had been reported in\nUttar Pradesh over the last 2 days.\n(http://www.christianmessenger.in/floods-in-bihar-up-assam-88-die-in-dengue-related-deaths/) - Delhi. 31 Jul 2017. As of 29 Jul 2017, 180 cases of dengue (monsoon\narrived early).\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/delhi/882984/dengue-malaria-chikungunya-cases-on-the-rise-in-delhi/) - Tamil Nadu (Coimbatore). 4 Aug 2017. Deaths rise to 16 in last 2\nmonths; new admissions increasing.\n(http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/2-more-dengue-deaths-in-coimbatore-total-deaths-now-16-117080401128_1.html) - Tamil Nadu. 11 Aug 2017. Prevalence of dengue in Tamil Nadu is\ndecreasing. So far, 5000 people have been affected and due to proper\ntreatment by doctors in government and private hospitals, almost all\ndengue patients have been saved, health minister C Vijaya Baskar said\ntoday 11 Aug 2017.\n(http://www.dnaindia.com/\nhealth/report-prevalence-of-dengue-in-tn-down-health-minister-2526936) - Tamil Nadu (Chennai). 18 Aug 2017. At least 1500 new cases in 10\ndays. Over 6000 patients have been confirmed and\ntreated as in-patients; mortality has been kept to 1 per cent.\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/thiruvananthapuram/882347/mch-keeps-dengue-mortality-rate-to-1/#) - Karnataka (Gulbarga). 4 Aug 2017. 235 cases in Gulbarga district\nfrom January to July 2017. Of the 235, 171 cases were reported from\nKalaburagi taluk sub district alone, 32 from Chincholli taluk, 13\nfrom Chittapur taluk, 4 cases each from Afzalpur, Aland, and Sedam\ntaluks, and 3 cases from Jewargi taluk.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-karnataka/235-dengue-cases-in-kalaburagi-dist/article19423638.ece) - Karnataka (Gulbarga). 23 Aug 2017. A total of 474 confirmed cases in\nGulbarga district, with 1927 suspected cases; 368 cases confirmed in\nKalaburagi sub district. Only 43 cases were reported in the district\ntill the end of June 2017 and 191 cases were reported between 1 and\n10 Aug 2017, while 240 new cases have been registered, taking the\ntotal to 474.\n(http://www.uniindia.com/dengue-474-confirmed-cases-reported-in-kalaburagi-district/health-and-medicine/fullstory/968353.html) - Karnataka. 18 Aug 2017. Nearly 8000 cases in Karnataka so far in\n2017. Kerala has reported 16 000 cases and Tamil Nadu 9500 cases.\nDengue spreads easily between the 3 adjacent states.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/karnataka/central-team-to-review-dengue-outbreak-in-state/article19512224.ece) - West Bengal (Kolkata). 12 Aug 2017. Dengue scare at RG Kar Hospital\nMedical College hostel; at least 8 test positive over the last week.\nIn 2015, more than 30 were affected in the hostel campus and one died.\nOn 2016 too, more than a dozen inmates were affected.\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/dengue-scare-at-rg-kar-hostel-8-test-positive/articleshow/60029232.cms) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nAnirban Ghosh\nKasturba Medical College\n(m_anirbanghosh@hotmail.com) - West Bengal (Birbhum). 21 Aug 2017. At least 100 cases dengue have\nbeen reported from West Bengal's Birbhum district. \"We have received\nreports of at least 100 cases of dengue since 23 Jul 2017. While\nabout 60 of these cases are from the Dubrajpur town in the district's\nSuri Sadar sub-division, the rest are from other areas such as Bolpur\nand Rampurhat towns. But no one has died so far,\" the chief medical\nofficer of Birbhum, Himadri Ari, told The Hindu.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/bengal-records-100-dengue-cases/article19535541.ece) - West Bengal (Siliguri). 23 Aug 2017. The number of people suffering\nfrom dengue is rising at an alarming rate in Siliguri. According to\nrecords, the highest number of dengue cases reported was 54. This year\n2017, the mark has been crossed.\n(http://siliguritimes.com/number-dengue-patients-rise-siliguri/) - Odisha (Ganjam). 22 Jul 2017. Blood samples of 116 people of the\ndistrict were recently tested and 4 dengue positive cases were\ndetected. Disinfecting water bodies in the district has already\nstarted and a 3-member team has been entrusted with spreading\nawareness on dengue in the district.\n(http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/odisha/2017/jul/22/4-found-dengue-positive-in-odishas-ganjam-district-1632062.html) - Odisha. 18 Aug 2017. 402 cases and 2 deaths. Last year 2016 4348\npersons were tested positive for the dengue virus by this period with\n8 deaths. Out of total 402 infected persons, 67 were tested positive\nin Bhadrak district, 61 in Cuttack district, and 59 in Balasore\ndistrict. Similarly, 35 people have been infected in Khordha, 34 in\nJajpur, 24 in Puri, 20 in Jagatsinghpur . Meanwhile, Kendrapara has\nregistered 20, Ganjam 13, Keonjhar 10, Dhenkanal 11, Bolangir 6, and\nMayurbhanj 5 cases of dengue. While Nayagarh, Sonepur, Kalahandi,\nAngul, and Bargarh registered 3 cases each, Nuapada and Kandhamal\nwitnessed 2 cases. Boudh, Rayagada, Sundargarh and Deogarh districts\nrecorded with single case each. However, 12 patients have come to the\nstate from neighbouring states.\n(http://pragativadi.com/dengue-claims-two-lives-affects-402-odisha/) - Gujarat (Ahmedabad). 1 Aug 2017. A total of 59 cases in July 2017.\nThe actual number of cases is said to be 'far more'; it takes at least\n15 days to confirm cases.\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/59-dengue-cases-in-july-amc/articleshow/59853414.cms) - Jharkhand (Jamshedpur). 30 Jul 2017. 75 positive cases in Kolhan and\nadjoining area of Jamshedpur.\n(http://www.avenuemail.in/jamshedpur/dengue-cases-rise-positive-cases-shoot-75-kolhan/111026/) - Telangana (Hyderabad). 25 Jul 2017. All 4 dengue serotypes are\npresent this year 2017. A total of 15 samples found to be\nco-infected. In an earlier study done in New Delhi, such multiple\ndengue serotype infections were reported in only 19 per cent of cases.\nAll 4 dengue serotypes were detected in almost equal number in blood\nsamples, unlike in an earlier study conducted in New Delhi wherein one\nserotype was found to be dominating. This has been indicated as a\npossible reason for the high prevalence of infection due to more than\none dengue serotype. Another finding of concern is that DEN-4 strain,\nresembling the one detected in Pune in 2009, was detected in as many\nas 11 samples. DEN-4 is associated with unusual symptoms like\nrespiratory distress, pleural effusion, and elevated levels of liver\nenzymes. Also, detection of a DEN-1 strain found closely related to a\nstrain from Thailand detected in 1980 that causes high severity\ninfection has been reported. Dr Musturi Venkataramana, assistant\nprofessor of biotechnology of UoH, who led the study, said, \"When a\nperson is infected with more than one serotype of dengue, it may lead\nto dengue haemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome which can cause\nsevere health problems, and even death. Finding 45 per cent patients\nwith such infections is worrisome.\"\n(http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/hyderabad/2017/jul/25/all-four-dengue-serotypes-prevalent-in-city-1633171.html) Maps of India can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Pakistan\n- Sindh (Karachi). 8 Aug 2017. 422 dengue fever cases have been\nreported in Sindh province so far in 2017, out of them 410 were\nreported in Karachi, 5 in Hyderabad, 5 in Tharparkar/Mithi, and 2 in\nUmerkot. As per a weekly report issued by Prevention and Control\nProgram for Dengue in Sindh, as many as 27 new dengue fever cases\nsurfaced in the city from 1 to 7 Aug 2017.\n(http://www.brecorder.com/2017/08/08/363624/a27-more-dengue-cases-surface-in-karachi/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 8 Aug 2017. 3rd death due to dengue\nhemorrhagic fever and encephalitis. Most of the affected patients were\nbrought from the Tehkal Payan area from where water samples have been\ncollected to determine the situation.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1476245/third-dengue-death-\nreported-k-p/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 16 Aug 2017. The number of dengue\npatients in the city has reached 600 in almost a month. Most of the\ncases are from Tehkal, the rear of which is a rural area, where there\nis a large number of automobile repair shops. The water kept in open\ncontainers to wash tyres and for other related work serves as the\nbreeding ground for mosquitoes that transmit dengue.\nAs per the administration of Khyber Teaching Hospital, 5 of the\npatients brought to the facility since June 2017 have succumbed to\nthe dengue virus.\n(https://www.geo.tv/latest/153878-peshawar-admin-busy-in-photo-shoot-as-dengue-cases-soar-to-600) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 22 Aug 2017. An investigation report\nby WHO on the dengue outbreak in Peshawar has revealed that the\npresence of a huge number of uncovered water containers used in houses\nand at workshops is the main reason for the outbreak. Following the\ncases reported from Peshawar, a 5-member WHO team moved to the city to\ninvestigate the reasons behind the dengue epidemic. The team collected\nsamples from 2 main areas  Tehkal and Gujran Muhalla. The report\nrevealed that 87 per cent of the samples collected from 23 water\ncontainers in the Civil Dispensary area of Tehkal tested positive for\ndengue virus. Similarly, 79 per cent of the total 19 samples of water\ncontainers in Gujran Muhallah also tested positive.\nThe data compiled by the WHO team, the total number of reported cases\nexceeded 4320 which were screened for dengue in the Khyber Teaching\nHospital from 14 Jun to 17 Aug 2017. A total of 699 people tested\npositive for dengue, of which 5 have died. Of the total patients\nscreened, 325 were admitted to the hospital while 200 were discharged.\nBy 17 Aug 2017, a total of 120 patients were admitted to the facility.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1487967/reveals-water-storage-containers-behind-dengue-surge-peshawar/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 24 Aug 2017. Dengue continues in\nPeshawar, claiming 7 lives with 69 new cases reported from different\nareas of the city during the last 24 hours, raising the number of\ntotal cases to 1703. So far, he said, 7 deaths including 6 from Khyber\nTeaching Hospital and one in Hayatabad Medical Complex were reported\nfrom dengue epidemics in Peshawar. Out of 69 new cases, 41 were\nreported in Khyber Teaching Hospital (KTH), 13 in Hayatabad Medical\nComplex (HMC), 12 in Lady Reading Hospital (LRH), and 3 in Naseerullah\nKhan Babar Teaching Hospital (NBTH), Peshawar, he said. A rapid\nresponse team has also been set up with mandate to swiftly reach to\nthe affected areas from where new cases were surfaced besides helping\nthe field staff in conduct of fumigation spray, removal of larvae, and\nprovision of other necessary medicines.\n(https://dnd.com.pk/dengue-rampage-in-peshawar-kills-seven-69-new-cases-surface/133250) Maps of Pakistan can be seen at\n(http://pakistanmap.facts.co/pakistanmapof/PakistanAdministrativeMap.jpg)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ China\n- Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region ex Viet Nam (susp). 16 Aug 2017.\nGuangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in south China has reported its 1st\nimported dengue case this year 2017, local inspection and quarantine\nbureau said. The man had stayed in Hanoi, Viet Nam, for 2 months but\ndenied having been bitten by mosquitoes or having any infectious\ndisease.\n(http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-08/16/c_136531179.htm) - Hong Kong SAR Special Administrative Region. 9 Aug 2017. 1st\nlocally transmitted case of dengue in Hong Kong, this year 2017.\n(https://today.mims.com/topic/chp-investigates-first-local-dengue-fever-case-of-the-year) - Macau SAR. 1 Aug 2017. 1st locally acquired case this year 2017\nconfirmed. 53 imported cases in 2017, including 18 from Thailand, 10\nfrom Sri Lanka, and 7 from the Philippines.\n(https://macaunews.mo/first-local-dengue-case-year-confirmed/) - Macau SAR. 24 Aug 2017. A 48 year old domestic worker from the\nPhilippines is now in hospital after health authorities confirmed she\nhas dengue fever; the 7th imported case reported in Macau this year\n2017.\n(http://menafn.com/1095765055/Tests-show-that-Filipino-maid-in-Macau-has-dengue-fever) Maps of China can be seen at (http://www.sacu.org/maps/provmap.png)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/155). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Taiwan. 3 Aug 2017. 2 more indigenous dengue fever cases have been\nconfirmed in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, making that 3 cases this\nyear, said a statement issued by Kaohsiung City's Department of Health\non Thu 3 Aug 2017. The 3 cases were all members of the same family,\nhusband, wife and son, who lived together in the southern Taiwanese\nport city, according to the department. From 1 Jan to 22 Jul 2017, 14 919 cases and 81\ndeaths of dengue recorded. Most of the deaths were from Ayeyarwady\nregion, followed by Yangon and Bago regions. The current reported\ncases are higher than those of 2016, yet still lower than that of\n2015, according to Dr Zaw Lin, dengue program manager of Ministry of\nHealth and Sports. In Rakhine State, about 1800 people are infected\nand 18 died from the infection. High occurrence was observed in\nMinbya, Sittwe, and Toungup townships. Over the past 2\nmonths, around 90 patients were taken to HCM Paediatrics Hospital No 1\nper week on average.\n(http://english.vietnamnet.vn/fms/society/182701/rising-dengue-fever-cases-leave-17-dead.html) - National. 19 Aug 2017. The number of dengue fever cases in Viet Nam\nspiked by some 10 000 cases in the past week. Tran Đac Phu, head of\nthe ministry's preventive medicine department, said the country had\nrecorded 90 626 dengue cases since the beginning of 2017, a\nyear-on-year rise of 67.8 per cent, including 24 fatalities, local\nmedia reports. This is up by about 10 000 since the last total case\ncount was released on 3 Aug 207. The outbreak is stretching the\ncountry's medical system as more than 78 000 of the cases required\nhospitalization. In the capital city of Hanoi, there have been 17 027\nrecorded dengue cases, 7 of whom died since the beginning of the year\n2017.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-updates-vietnam-sri-lanka-32087/) - Mekong Delta. 24 Jul 2017. Cases increased by 125 per cent in 1st 15\ndays of July 2017 compared with same period 2016. An Giang province\nalone recorded the highest number of 120 hospitalised cases in the 1st\n10 days of July 2017, followed by Soc Trang province with 110 cases\nand Dong Thap province, 100 cases. Since the beginning of 2017,\ndengue-related deaths have been reported in Dong Thap, Tien Giang, and\nTra Vinh provinces. Dengue fever has increased sharply this year among\nchildren aged between 10-15 in the Mekong Delta, especially in Can Tho\ncity.\n(http://english.vietnamnet.vn/fms/society/182533/dengue-fever-on-the-rise-in-mekong-delta.html) - Hanoi. 5 Aug 2017. Nearly 9000 cases of dengue fever have now been\nreported in Hanoi since the beginning of the year 2017, with 2300\nreported from 24 to 30 Jul 2017 alone, state media said. From the\nbeginning of this year 2017 through July, there was a 23 per cent\nincrease in cases in the city over the number reported during the same\nperiod last year 2016, while 46 per cent more cases were reported in\nJuly than in June, the city's health department said. According to\nWHO, as of 18 Jun 2017, there were 45 074 cases of dengue reported in\nViet Nam including 13 deaths. Compared to the same period in 2016 (40\n511 cases including 12 deaths), the cumulative number of cases\nincreased by 11.3 per cent.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/vietnam-dengue-news-emergency-declared-ha-nam-hanoi-outbreak-32326/) - Hanoi. 11 Aug 2017. Nearly 5000 new cases in Hanoi, with more than\n13 200 infected and with 6 deaths since early 2017.\n(http://www.elevenmyanmar.com/world-news/11037) - Ha Nam. 5 Aug 2017. More than 10 cases a day being reported largest\noutbreak in history of Province. The Ha Nam Province People's\nCommittee declared a state of emergency on 3 Aug 2017, to deal with a\ngrowing outbreak of dengue fever, spread by infected mosquitoes, with\n100 cases confirmed year-to-date, according to local media.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/vietnam-dengue-news-emergency-declared-ha-nam-hanoi-outbreak-32326/) Maps of Viet Nam can be seen at\n(http://www.onlineasiatravel.com/images/vn/vietnam-map.png) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/152). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Philippines\n- National. 11 Aug 2017. The Department of Health (DoH) reported a\nconsiderable decrease of dengue fever cases in the 1st half of 2017 in\nwhich only 43 770 nationwide have been tallied from 1 Jan to 1 Jul\n2017. This is 36.8 per cent lower than the 69 297 recorded in the\nsame period in 2016. Among the 43 770 cases, 250 deaths were reported,\nwhich is 84 fewer than the 334 recorded in the same period in 2016.\nThe report showed that all regions, except in Metro Manila, showed\ndecreasing trends in dengue cases as compared to 2016. Majority of the\ndengue cases were recorded in Central Visayas (6281), Metro Manila\n(5567), Central Luzon (5147), Calabarzon (5007), and Soccsksargen\n(4861). Provinces with the most number of cases are Cebu with 11 per\ncent, followed by South Cotabato with 6.3 per cent, and Pampanga with\n4.6 per cent. Metro Manila is the lone region with an upward trend of\ncases, recording a 24.9 per cent increase from 4457 in 2016.\n(http://www.manilatimes.net/dengue-cases-drop-first-half-2017-report/343788/) - Cebu. 11 Aug 2017. Talisay City, Cebu Province Central Visayas,\nPhilippines 296 cases and 9 deaths; Consolacion 260 cases and 4\ndeaths; Argao 187 cases and 1 death.\n(http://www.sunstar.com.ph/cebu/local-news/2017/08/10/talisay-tops-number-dengue-cases-557829) - Negros Occidental. 2 Aug 2017. The Provincial Health Office (PHO)\nreported that dengue cases this year 2017 in Negros Occidental have\nreached 14 from January to July. The latest death was reported in\nBarangay Mambulac, Silay City. Deaths were monitored in San Carlos\nCity, with 4; Sagay City and Kabankalan City, 2 each; Escalante City,\nVictorias City, Bago City, Silay City, Hinigaran, and Calatrava, one\neach.\n(http://www.sunstar.com.ph/bacolod/local-news/2017/08/02/provincial-health-office-dengue-deaths-negocc-now-14-556270) - Negros Occidental (Bacolod City).17 Aug 2017. A total of 9 barangays\nFilipino term for a village, district or ward identified as dengue\nhot spots: Mandalagan with 31 cases from January to 12 Aug 2017;\nVillamonte, 24; Mansilingan, 22; Banago, 18; Alijis, 17; Estefania,\n17; Vista Alegre, 14; Taculing, 13; and Sum-ag, 12.\n(http://www.sunstar.com.ph/bacolod/local-news/2017/08/17/9-barangays-bacolod-tag-dengue-hot-spots-558972) - Cavite (Trece Martires City). 23 Aug 2017. Dengue fever cases have\nbeen on the rise, particularly in the past 2 months in Cavite\nprovince's 7 districts the Provincial Epidemiology Surveillance Unit\n(PESU) reported. PESU records showed that in the 1st 8 months of the\nyear, 2193 cases and 8 deaths were reported, although only 1260 cases\nand 3 deaths were reported and recorded from 1 Jan to 24 Jun 2017.\nCavite, a 1st class province with 7 districts comprising 7 cities and\n16 municipalities, has an estimated population of 4.3 million. The\nprovincial government declared a dengue fever outbreak in all\ndistricts and placed the entire area under a state of calamity in\nSeptember 2015. The year ended with 48 deaths and 12 007 cases, PESU\nrecords showed.\n(http://news.mb.com.ph/2017/08/23/dengue-fever-cases-in-cavite-rising/) Maps of the Philippines can be seen at (http://tinyurl.com/z4y3p5v)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/158). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Laos\n- National. 4 Aug 2017. Over 5000 people infected and one death in the\ncapital Vientiane. As many as 7 other deaths have been reported, one\nin each of the following provinces: Khammouane, Savannakhet, Saravane,\nand Attapeu, while Champasak has reported 3 death since the beginning\nof 2017.\n(http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-08/04/c_136500474.htm) Maps of Lao People's Democratic Republic can be seen at\n(http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Laos.gif) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/146). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Japan ex Côte d'Ivoire. June 2017. Suzuki T, Kutsuna S, Taniguchi S,\net al. Dengue virus exported from Côte d'Ivoire to Japan, June 2017.\nEmerg Infect Dis. 2017 date cited.\nAbstract. Since April 2017, a dengue fever outbreak has been ongoing\nin Côte d'Ivoire. We diagnosed dengue fever (type 2 virus) in a\ntraveler returning to Japan from Côte d'Ivoire. Phylogenetic analysis\nrevealed strain homology with the Burkina Faso 2016 strain. This case\nmay serve as an alert to possible disease spread outside Africa.\n(https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/10/17-1132_article) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Japan can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/156). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Pacific\n\n- Samoa. 22 Jul 2017. Physicians at LBJ hospital said they are seeing\napprox 30-50 cases per month, with symptoms related to dengue.\nAccording to a senior nurse, 10-15 patients with dengue like symptoms\nor tested positive for dengue, are admitted to LBJ per month.\n(http://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/335595/dengue-fever-on-the-rise-in-american-samoa) - Samoa. 14 Aug 2017. On 6 May 2017, the Ministry of Health\n(MoH) of Côte d'Ivoire WHO of a dengue fever outbreak in Abidjan, the\ncapital city of Côte d'Ivoire. Suspected cases of dengue were first\nreported on 22 Apr 2017 and confirmed by the Institut Pasteur de Côte\nd'Ivoire (IPCI) laboratory on 28 Apr 2017. As of 11 Jul 2017, a total\nof 623 suspected cases including 2 deaths (case fatality rate: 0.3 per\ncent) have been reported. A total of 192 cases have been confirmed by\nPCR, of which 66 per cent were dengue virus serotype 2 (DENV-2), 29\nper cent were DENV-3, and 5 per cent were DENV-1. In addition, 90\nsamples were confirmed IgM positive by serology. The majority of cases\nhave been reported from Abidjan city. Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted for 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. The general trend of suspected cases of dengue fever\nis increasing. From 27 Jun to 4 Jul 2017, 37 new cases were reported\nand from 4 to 11 Jul 2017, 142 new suspected cases were reported. A\ntotal of 27 per cent of the suspected cases are aged between 15 and 29\nyears old, 55 per cent are 30 years old and above. 54 per cent of the\ncases are female. Coinfection with yellow fever was suspected in 68\ncases and confirmed in one case. Further laboratory confirmation is\nongoing.\n(http://www.who.int/csr/don/04-august-2017-dengue-cote-d-ivoire/en/) - Côte d'Ivoire. 8 Aug 2017. Ivory Coast continues to affect multiple\nregions: 623 cases by mid July serotype DEN-2 (66 per cent), and DEN-3\n(29 per cent). Ninety cases were also confirmed positive for\nimmunoglobulin M (IgM), an antibody produced in the body as an immune\nresponse to dengue infection. According to WHO, the majority of cases\nhave appeared in Abidjan City, while the Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. Additionally, the general trend of suspected cases of\ndengue fever has been increasing, growing from 37 new cases from 27\nJun to 4 Jul to 142 new suspected cases appearing from 4 to 11 Jul\n2017.\n(https://homelandprepnews.com/ stories/23646-dengue-outbreak-\nivory-coast-continues- increase-according-world-\nhealth-organization/) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Côte d'Ivoire can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/52). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Research\n- Viral persistence, organ transplant-related transmission.\nDate: Sun 13 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Star Online (edited)\n(http://tinyurl.com/yd4vv2bj) \nThere is now a concern that the dengue virus can reside in the body\neven after one has recovered and the virus is non-detectable in the\nblood, said a well-known dengue scientist. This came about after 2\nkidney recipients in Taiwan were diagnosed with dengue 2 days after\nreceiving a kidney each from the same donor, said National Cheng Kung\nUniversity microbiology and immunology professor Dr Oscar Perng\nGuey-chuen. \"This indicates a potential risk,\" the Taiwan-based\nscientist said, adding that no dengue virus was detected in the\ndonor's blood. He said the donor contracted dengue in 2015 and in mid-2016, he died\nin an accident. His family donated his corneas, liver, heart, and\nkidneys. Both patients had the same strain of the dengue virus the\ndonor had in 2015 and one of the recipients died of dengue\nhaemorrhagic fever, he said. Asked where the virus could be hiding since it could not be detected\nin the blood, he said it was a question scientists are trying to\nanswer. Interestingly, those who received the donor's corneas, liver,\nand heart did not develop dengue, Dr Perng said on the sidelines of\nthe National Dengue And Arboviruses Infection Conference 2017\nyesterday 12 Aug 2017. He said although there was not enough\nevidence to show the virus came from the donor as the kidneys were not\ntested for dengue before the transplant, the same virus was found in\nthe patients' bodies after that. Dr Perng said his team had studied mice for dengue virus in the blood\ntestes, kidney, liver, spleen and brain, and found the virus present\nin the kidneys and brain. \"We believe the virus probably resided in\nthe kidneys and was not cleared by the body,\" he said, adding that the\nvirus could have been activated after transplant. He said this raised\nconcerns about asymptomatic people who are dengue carriers. Health Ministry deputy director, general Datuk Dr S Jeyaindran said\npatients with severe dengue would have better recovery if they were\ngiven colloids, a more concentrated fluid, at the early stage in fluid\nmanagement for dengue patients. Dr Jeyaindran, who was representing\nHealth Minister Datuk Seri Dr S Subramaniam, said colloids may be\nintroduced at an earlier stage, instead of saline because it has not\nbeen successful in treating patients with severe dengue. He said more\nstudies will be conducted to find out at which stage the colloids\nshould be given. byline: Loh Foon Fong \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Air travel related spread of dengue.\nDate: Thu 3 Aug 2017.\nSource: Medical Xpress (edited)\n(https://medicalxpress.com/news/2017-08-air-responsible-dengue-asia.html) \nWhile the incidences of many other infectious diseases have declined\nover the past decade, the number of cases and outbreaks of dengue\nvirus have continued to increase. The spread of dengue to new areas is\nlikely due in large part to trends in air travel, researchers now\nreport in PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases. Dengue virus affects as estimated 390 million people around the globe\neach year, and can cause symptoms ranging from a mild fever and\nheadache to severe low blood pressure. The virus has mostly caused\ndisease in tropical and subtropical areas of the world, but a 2014\noutbreak in Japan broke that pattern. Overall, the geographic area\naffected by dengue has been growing in recent years. In the new work, Huaiyu Tian and Bing Xu, both of Beijing Normal\nUniversity, China, together with colleagues from the University of\nOxford and elsewhere analyzed the spread of dengue viruses in Asia\nfrom 1956 to 2015. They used 2202 genetic sequences of dengue viruses,\ncollected in 20 countries or regions of Asia over the 59 years, to\ndetermine how different strains were related. They also investigated\ntrends in air travel, maritime mobility, migration, and\nsocio-economics to determine what factors impact the spread of\ndengue. The spread of 3 different dengue virus serotypes, DENV-1, -2, and -3,\nis associated with air traffic more so than any other factors, the\ndata revealed. Air traffic hubs such as Thailand and India, the\nresearchers found, help seed dengue epidemics, while China, Cambodia,\nIndonesia, and Singapore help diffuse the virus to other Asian\ncountries. \"Future trends in global mobility could potentially accelerate the\nappearance and diffusion of DENV worldwide,\" the researchers say.\n\"Prevention and control of dengue epidemics requires a better\nunderstanding of its mode of geographic dissemination, especially for\ncountries in the tropics.\" Reference: Tian H, Sun Z, Faria NR, et al. Increasing airline travel\nmay facilitate co-circulation of multiple dengue virus serotypes in\nAsia. PLoS Negl Trop Dis. 2017; 11(8): e0005694;\n(http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0005694) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Visual impact.\nDate: Fri 25 Aug 2017.\nSource: NYOOOZ, The Indian Express report (edited)\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/delhi/902768/drop-in-vision-traced-to-inflammation-caused-by-dengue-fever-say-doctors/) \nIn a rare symptom of dengue, a 20 year old in the capital developed\n\"ophthalmic complications\" due to which she complained of a \"drop in\nvision\". Typical symptoms of dengue range from sore throat, cough,\njoint pain, and rashes. According to the newspaper, doctors eventually discovered that the\ndrop in vision was due to \"inflammation of blood vessels in the\nretina\", as a result of dengue fever. The woman had earlier tested\npositive for the vectorborne disease. \"The patient tested positive for\ndengue and had fever for the past 8 days. She did not have any rashes\non her body, or any other systemic manifestation.\" \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> WHO update.\nDate: The 15 Aug 2017.\nSource: WHO Western Pacific region (edited)\n(http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/dengue_biweekly_20170815.pdf) \nDengue situation update no. 523\n-\nNorthern hemisphere\n-\nCambodia\nAs of 8 Aug 2017, a total of 1604 suspected dengue fever cases were\nreported in 2017. There is a\ndownward trend in the number of reported cases since week 16 (week\nending 22 Apr 2017). \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) ","keywordsMatched":[]},"124":{"title":"Septoria, wheat - Australia: (VI, SA) ","date":["24","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/PL> Septoria, wheat - Australia: (VI, SA) [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Thu 24 Aug 2017. Source: Farm Online (edited) (http://www.farmonline.com.au/story/4875310/fungal-disease-reappears-after-40-years/)   Farmers in the Victorian Wimmera and the Upper South East of South Australia are set to be confronted with a fungal disease they have not seen at damaging levels since the 1970s. Septoria tritici blotch has built up to levels that could cause significant damage this year 2017.  Agriculture Victoria cereal pathologist Grant Hollaway said septoria is now the major fungal disease issue in south-west Victoria. \"It has really emerged as a problem over the past five or six years.\" He said the major threat would be in the medium rainfall zone where the disease had not been spotted for many years. \"Septoria was common in the Wimmera in low levels last year 2016 and this has provided the carryover inoculum.\"  There are parallels in septoria's reappearance after a lengthy absence with that of stripe rust, which Dr Hollaway said returned to Victoria in 2003 following a 20 year hiatus. \"It is more of a stripe rust in terms of the damage it can cause,\" he said.  Byline: Gregor Heard   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  Septoria leaf blotch of cereals is caused by fungi in the septoria species complex, which includes _Zymoseptoria tritici_ (previously _Septoria tritici_), _Mycosphaerella graminicola_ and _Phaeosphaeria nodorum_ (previously _Stagonospora nodorum_). They affect mainly wheat, but also barley and oats and occasionally rye and some grass species. Symptoms on wheat and barley are very similar and may occur at any time during the growth cycle and on any portion of the plant. They include blotches on both leaves and glumes, which reduce the photosynthetic ability of the host. Disease development is favoured by humid conditions. Up to 50 per cent yield losses have been reported on susceptible varieties.  Spores can be spread by infected plant material, wind, water (rain splash) and mechanical means. The pathogens can overwinter on crop debris and on autumn sown crops or volunteers. Disease management includes fungicide treatments aimed at preventing the disease becoming established on the upper 3 leaves of the crop canopy (where it would affect the ears most), removal of inoculum sources and use of resistant varieties. After the cereal rusts, the disease is considered the most important challenge to plant breeders (see ProMED-mail post http://promedmail.org/post/20120831.1274190) and a threat to food security worldwide.  Pathogen strains with high levels of resistance to many fungicides are emerging, for example, in the UK and other parts of Europe (ProMED-mail post http://promedmail.org/post/20160516.4225677), as well as Australia and New Zealand (ProMED-mail posts http://promedmail.org/post/20161031.4598540, http://promedmail.org/post/20140417.2410219). In Australia, STB was reported as the 1st wheat disease developing fungicide resistance on that continent (ProMED-mail post http://promedmail.org/post/20140313.2329774). The possibility cannot be excluded that the re-emergence of STB in eastern Australia may be due to new fungal strains which have adapted to local conditions.  Stripe rust (_Puccinia striiformis_ var. _striiformis_), also mentioned above, can result in yield losses of 40 to 100 per cent. New strains with increased virulence are emerging and this disease is currently causing the most damage to wheat crops on a global scale. (For more information see previous ProMED-mail posts in the archives and links below).  Maps Australia (with states): (http://ontheworldmap.com/australia/large-detailed-topographical-map-of-australia.jpg) South Australia, regions: (http://www.pir.sa.gov.au/__data/assets/image/0004/142357/Agricultural_regions_map_2.jpg) Victoria, regions: (http://www.seedbank.com.au/images/rollover-maps/Vic-Rollover-Map.png)  Pictures Wheat crop affected by septoria: (https://www.agric.wa.gov.au/sites/gateway/files/styles/original/public/septoria_nodorum_withered_leaves.jpg?itok=-ZWZPjFM) Septoria leaf symptoms: (http://ipm.illinois.edu/bulletin/photos/septoria_wheat.jpg), (http://www.abgenternasyonel.com/images/icerik/septoria%20tritici.jpg) and (http://www.apsnet.org/edcenter/intropp/lessons/fungi/ascomycetes/Article%20Images/SeptoriaTriticiBlotch01.jpg) Septoria on resistant and susceptible wheat varieties: (http://www.fao.org/docrep/006/y4011e/y4011e1d.jpg) Septoria diseases and pathogens, photo gallery: (http://www.forestryimages.org/browse/subimages.cfm?sub=9457)  Links Story also available at: (http://www.queenslandcountrylife.com.au/story/4875310/fungal-disease-reappears-after-40-years/) Information on septoria diseases: (http://www.agroatlas.ru/en/content/diseases/Tritici/Tritici_Septoria_tritici/), (http://www.agroatlas.ru/en/content/diseases/Tritici/Tritici_Septoria_nodorum/), (http://www.apsnet.org/edcenter/intropp/lessons/fungi/ascomycetes/Pages/Septoria.aspx) and (http://cereals.ahdb.org.uk/cereal-disease-encyclopedia/diseases/septoria-leaf-blotch.aspx) (incl. life cycle) Information on wheat stripe rust: (http://www1.agric.gov.ab.ca/$department/deptdocs.nsf/all/prm11383), (http://www.ipm.ucdavis.edu/PMG/r730100511.html) and via (http://www.icarda.org/striperust2014/) Taxonomy of fungal species via: (http://www.indexfungorum.org/Names/Names.asp)  - Mod.DHA  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"130":{"title":"E. coli EHEC - Australia: (QL) O157, mild disease, mutant\r\n\ttoxin, 2013 ","date":["29","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> E. coli EHEC - Australia: (QL) O157, mild disease, mutant\r\n\ttoxin, 2013 [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Tue 29 Aug 2017. Source: Emerg Infect Dis Volume 23, Number 10October 2017 (edited) (https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/10/16-1836_article)   Mild Illness during Outbreak of Shiga Toxin-Producing _E. coli_ O157 Infections Associated with Agricultural Show, Australia \n Shiga toxin producing _E. coli_ (STEC or enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_, EHEC - Mod. LL) is a major cause of serious human gastrointestinal illness and have the potential to cause life-threatening complications, such as hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) (1). An average of 0.4 cases of EHEC illness per 100 000 persons per year are reported to public health authorities in Australia (2). Disease severity can range from asymptomatic infection to serious and sometimes fatal illness, particularly in young children and the elderly (3,4).  Healthy ruminants, particularly cattle, are the reservoir for EHEC (5). Human infection with EHEC usually occurs as a result of inadvertent ingestion of fecal matter after consumption of contaminated food, water, or unpasteurized milk; contact with animals or their environments; or secondarily, through contact with infected humans (4,5). In the largest previously reported outbreak of EHEC illness in Australia in 1995, which was associated with consumption of mettwurst (uncooked, semidry, fermented sausages), HUS developed in 23 of the 51 case-patients identified, and there was 1 death (6).  The Study  A multidisciplinary incident management team was established to investigate an outbreak of EHEC illness associated with an annual agricultural show in Brisbane, Queensland, Australia, in August 2013. The incident management team defined primary and secondary outbreak cases. Persons with laboratory-confirmed EHEC infection associated with the outbreak and their household contacts were followed up until the point of microbiological evidence of clearance, which was defined as 2 consecutive negative stool samples collected more than 24h apart (7).  Case-patients and contacts with a high risk for transmission (persons under 5 years of age; persons unable to maintain good hygiene; or childcare, healthcare, aged care, or food preparation workers) were advised to avoid childcare and work settings in accordance with Queensland Health Guidelines (7). Enhanced surveillance measures were implemented to assist with case finding. Medical practitioners were requested to avoid use of antimicrobial drugs for suspected case-patients with EHEC infections because of previously reported associations between antimicrobial drug use and HUS. We developed a case-control study to obtain additional information related to animal contact, hand hygiene, and food consumption at the agricultural show. We analyzed data by using Epi Info 7 (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Atlanta, GA, USA). EHEC identified from human, environmental, and animal samples were serotyped for O and H antigens. Expression of Shiga toxin 1 (stx1) and stx2 genes was determined for selected isolates. Shiga toxin gene subtyping and whole-genome sequencing (WGS) analysis was performed.  During 21 Aug 2013 to 27 Sep 2013, we identified 57 outbreak-associated laboratory-confirmed case-patients with EHEC infection: 54 confirmed primary case-patients, 1 probable primary case-patient, and 2 secondary case-patients (Figure 1 for figures, see original URL - Mod. LL). Of the 57 cases-patients, 32 (56 percent) were female. Case-patients ranged in age from 1 to 77 (median 9) years; 31 (56 percent) case-patients were (10 years of age. Median incubation period after attending the agricultural show was 4 (range 1-11, 25th-75th percentile 3-5) days. Case-patients reported diarrhea (96 percent), abdominal pain (93 percent), bloody diarrhea (41 percent), and fever (32 percent) (Table 1). A total of 7 case-patients were hospitalized. No cases of HUS or deaths were reported.  Public Health Units followed up 40 case-patients until microbiological evidence of clearance; the remaining case-patients were lost to follow up. Median duration of EHEC excretion among primary case-patients was 18 (range 2-52) days (Table 2). After 27 days and 6 recurrent stools positive for EHEC, and after acute diarrheal illness had resolved, 1 child was given azithromycin on day 40 for 3 days to hasten decolonization. 2 consecutive stool specimens obtained more than 48 h after treatment with antimicrobial drugs was stopped were negative for EHEC in this child. This patient did not have any adverse effects from azithromycin treatment.  A total of 45 of 55 primary case-patients and 28 household contacts who attended the agricultural show were included in the case-control study. Median age of case-patients was 8 (range 1-77) years, and median age of controls was 38 (range 1-70) years. We showed by using univariate analysis that case-patients were not more likely than controls to have entered the animal nursery at the show. Case-patients were more likely than controls to have had contact with lambs or goats, fed the animals, or had their hands licked by animals.  We identified the same multilocus variable number tandem repeat and stx subtype genotype of _E. coli_ O157:H- in human case-patients, animal bedding from the animal nursery before disposal, and fecal samples collected from lambs, goats, and calves. WGS and read mapping to an _E. coli_ O157 reference genome showed that of the human, animal, and environmental isolates analyzed, all contained an IS1203v insertion that resulted in deletion of the first 494 bp of the stx2c subunit A gene (Figure 2). Expression of stx2 was not detected in these isolates by Immunocard STAT! EHEC (Meridian Bioscience, Cincinnati, OH, USA) and Shiga toxin Quik Chek (Alere, Waltham, MA, USA) lateral flow devices. No additional stx2 genes were identified, and no disruptions were detected in the stx1 gene regions of any of the isolates.  Conclusions  We found that EHEC infection was associated with feeding lambs or goats, feeding animals, and having the hands licked by animals. The course of _E. coli_ O157 infection was relatively mild; no cases of HUS were associated with this outbreak. Heiman et al. found that of 4928 cases of 390 _E. coli_ O157 illness outbreaks in the USA during 2003-2012, HUS was detected in 299 cases (6 percent of illnesses) (8). HUS cases with stx1+/stx2 _E. coli_ O157 isolates have been reported (9,10). We speculate that the absence of severe complications in this outbreak might have been caused, in part, by disruption of the stx2 subunit A gene by the IS1203v insertion, which resulted in lack of expression or a nonfunctional Stx2 toxin.  The proportion of case-patients reporting bloody diarrhea (19/46, 41 percent) was also lower than previously reported. Ethelberg et al. reported that 69 percent (56/81) of case-patients in Denmark infected with _E. coli_ O157 had bloody diarrhea (11). A recent retrospective cohort study reported that 61 percent (2027/3323) of symptomatic case-patients infected with _E. coli_ O157 Public Health England had bloody diarrhea. Bloody diarrhea was reported to be a risk factor for HUS (odds ratio 2.10; p = 0.001) (12). In the outbreak we studied, children under 5 years of age were less likely than older children and adults to report bloody diarrhea. EHEC infection should be actively considered for young children with non-bloody diarrhea who were exposed to potential sources of EHEC.  In this outbreak, 1 child was given azithromycin for 3 days to hasten decolonization some weeks after the acute diarrheal illness had resolved. Antimicrobial drugs are generally not recommended to hasten EHEC decolonization because of major associations with HUS (13). Recommendations to avoid high risk activities (such as childcare attendance) might place a major socioeconomic burden on EHEC carriers and their families. Further studies are required to assess whether WGS can provide useful information for safe administration of antimicrobial drugs for treatment of acute illness caused by EHEC, or when chronic shedding becomes established.  Our comprehensive study of a large outbreak _E. coli_ O157 illness, characterized by an IS1203v insertion disrupting the stx2c subunit A gene, showed mild clinical illness and an absence of HUS. Further characterization by virulence studies on isolates with this stx2c subunit A gene disruption might provide further insights into the mild illness caused by this strain.  References - 1.
