(promed@promedmail.org)  ProMED reported on this outbreak in 2013 when it occurred. It may well be the case that the IS1203v insertion that resulted in deletion of the first 494 bp of the stx2c subunit A gene may have been the cause of milder illness. Regarding azithromycin use, azithromycin and the carbapenem antimicrobial class are among a small group of antibacterials that do not appear to precipitate a higher risk of hemolytic uremic syndrome. Azithromycin was used for late clearance of the EHEC here and I have had anecdotal experience doing the same thing in an asymptomatic chronic carrier of EHEC O157 without any adverse effects. - Mod.LL  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/285).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"166":{"title":"Bluetongue, bovine - Australia (NT) ","date":["30","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Bluetongue, bovine - Australia (NT) [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  <br><br><strong>{1}</strong>. Date: Tue 29 Aug 2017 21:06 (http://www.abc.net.au/news/rural/2017-08-29/bluetongue-line-moves-south-in-the-nt/8848908)   Approximately 20 new properties within Central Australia and the Barkly now fall within the bluetongue virus zone within the Northern Territory, according to the Department of Primary Industry.  Changes to the zone, introduced last month July 2017, mean 10 of those additional properties are within the transmission zone, and 10 within the surveillance zone.  Bluetongue is an insect borne, non-contagious viral disease, and the changes mean properties affected will not be able to export to a number of markets that have restrictions in place, such as China and Turkey.  Peter Saville, senior veterinary officer in Alice Springs with the Department, said in his 14 years working in the area, the line was the lowest he had ever seen it.  \"What we found is that a number of properties north of the Alice Springs districts have had cattle which have seroconverted, which means that they've been exposed to the bluetongue virus, and those properties are much further south than they normally are.\"  Weather to blame According to Mr Saville, the change earlier in the year was due to a summer of high temperatures and high rainfall, resulting in the increased number of insects. \"It is insect movement that controls this, and as such there's not a lot we can do, so we just have to wait and see, we can't speculate on what might happen,\" he said.  Mr Saville said ownership changes could affect zoning.  \"One of the things that has contributed to this is a lot of properties have amalgamated their pics property identification codes because they're now under one ownership, and that means that even if part of their property is in a zone then the whole of the property is regarded as being in that zone.\"  Fluid line movement However Mr Saville said the line could once again move north depending on weather.  \"We wait until the end of summer, the end of the transmission season, and then we go out and test a number of properties to find out if there's been any evidence of viral activity.  \"Once those results are in, the NAMP National Arbovirus Monitoring Program committee meets and decides where the blue tongue line is going to go, and where the limits of the zones are.\"  Mr Saville said producers should visit the Animal Health Australia website if they want more information about the changes, and contact their livestock agent.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong>. Date: Thu 30 Aug 2017. From: Mark Shipp (Mark.Schipp@agriculture.gov.au) (edited)   The National Arbovirus Monitoring Program (NAMP) maps areas in Australia where bluetongue virus transmission occurs, using both sentinel herds and additional sampling of herds when mustered.  Sentinel herds are bled and tested regularly, however in very remote areas where sentinel herds are not practical, cattle are sampled during the annual muster.  Bluetongue viral transmission occurs in parts of Australia but disease has not been reported.  There is a buffer zone between the zone where bluetongue virus transmission can occur and the zone free of bluetongue virus transmission. This is called the surveillance zone and is 50 Km 31.06 mi wide. The distance maintained between records of viral transmission and the boundary of the free zone is always maintained at a distance of 100 km 62.13 and follows property boundaries.  Yearly variation in the distribution of the main insect vector Culicoides brevitarisis means that the NAMP records some variation in the zone boundary from year to year. The map was most recently updated on Wed 16 Aug 2017. Detection of viral transmission immediately results in a zone expansion however zone contraction requires 2 years of negative surveillance results. The variations in the boundary are generally small and are considered routine. The NT example is confounded by changes in the management of land that have seen the amalgamation of properties. Because the zone boundary follows property boundaries this has exaggerated the zone extension. Property sizes can be extensive; up to 12 000 square km 4633.22 square miles in some cases.  There can be a lag period observed between viral transmission and antibody detection, particularly where surveillance is based on sampling mustered animals rather than sentinel herds. This maybe where the confusion has arisen in the quoted media report. Sero-conversion was detected in winter but arose from insect activity earlier in the season. The media report is inaccurate in relation to market access.  Recently negotiated conditions with China allow access for Australian feeder and slaughter cattle raised in areas where bluetongue virus transmission can occur. Parts of China record transmission of bluetongue virus year round and most of China (like parts of Australia) experiences times in the year where bluetongue viral transmission can occur (seasonal transmission).  The bulk of cattle in the Northern Territory are exported to markets that are endemic for bluetongue and while export conditions are applied, they are generally not trade restrictive.  The report of the zone expansion is publically available through the NAMP web site that is hosted on the Animal Health in Australia Web site.  It is certainly true that some markets require animals to be sourced from bluetongue virus free areas. This is the main reason that the NAMP program is maintained as it provides access for Australian cattle to these markets by confirming a zone free from viral transmission.  Objectives of the NAMP are: 1. Market access - to facilitate the export of live cattle, sheep and goats, and ruminant genetic material, to countries with concerns about bluetongue, Akabane and bovine ephemeral fever (BEF) viruses 2. Bluetongue early warning - to detect incursions of exotic strains of bluetongue virus (BTV) and vectors (Culicoides species biting midges) into Australia by surveillance of the northern BTV epidemic area. 3. Risk management - to detect changes in the seasonal distribution in Australia of endemic bluetongue, Akabane and BEF viruses and their vectors, to support livestock exporters.   Mark Schipp Chief Veterinary Officer (Australia) OIE Delegate (Australia) Vice-President OIE Assembly 7 London Cct, Canberra ACT 2600 GPO Box 858, Australia (mark.schipp@agriculture.gov.au)  In previous situations the line has been moved to reflect the seroconverstion, not actual disease discoveries. I reached out to Dr Schipp with some questions. Below are our question and answers:  ProMED-mail moderator (hence PMM): It appears this is a standard line movement based on seroconverstion - without actual disease? Could you clarify for me please?  Dr Schipp: Yes this is a regular adjustment of line to reflect seroconverstion with clinical disease.  PMM: Also the way this article is written is a bit confusing to me. As it is late August/1st of September, so I am thinking you may in late winter/early spring, yet the article above talks about frosts in the winter?  Dr Schipp: The hope expressed by Dr Saville is that the frosts currently being experienced in the central Austral winter will deplete the number of _Culicoides_ able to over winter to then become abundant in the spring and summer.  ProMED-mail thanks Dr Schipp for his promt reply and for taking the time to clarify issues regarding the surveillance line.  Information for understanding Bluetongue. Bluetongue virus (BTV) can and does affect cattle.  The disease is caused by an orbivirus belonging to the family _Reoviridae_. There are 25 serotypes of bluetongue virus and 10 of these have been isolated in Australia. Orbiviruses are insect-borne viruses (arboviruses) transmitted by _Culicoides_ midges. Many other non bluetongue orbiviruses are also endemic in Australia.  Bluetongue is an insect-borne, viral disease that can affect sheep, goats, deer, and cattle. Sheep are the most seriously affected species; clinical disease and mortalities occur and production and trade losses may result. Most infections in cattle are unapparent.  A number of bluetongue serotypes are present in Australia, but the severe clinical disease seen in other countries has not occurred here. Disease has been produced in experimentally infected sheep with some serotypes present in Australia.  Bluetongue virus serotype 1 was 1st identified in Australia in 1975 from trapped insects in the Northern Territory (NT) but despite its long-term presence, it has not caused any clinical disease. Since that time 9 more serotypes have been isolated in the NT. The distribution of BTV in Australia has been monitored in the National Arbovirus Monitoring Program (NAMP) for many years and the zones of BTV virus transmission and freedom are mapped and updated regularly on the Animal Health Australia website. - Mod.TG  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/292). The total amount of dead wild boars discovered in the woods around\nZlín, in the far east of the Czech Republic, stood at 94 at the end\nof August 2017. In this month, 23 new infected carcasses were found,\nwhich is a downward trend from July 2017, when 68 reports were sent\nto the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE). The 1st report of\nASF in Czech wild boars was on Wed 21 Jun 2017. Many neighbouring countries have alerted their local pig producers to\nbe very careful what to feed their pigs - and their inhabitants what\nto purchase and how to dispose of it. So did Slovakia, according to\nthe Slovak Spectator. Zlín is only a few km away from the western\nSlovak border, to its north is Poland where ASF has been around since\n2014 and on its eastern border is Ukraine, where ASF has been\nconfirmed since 2011. In a presentation, given in mid-July 2017 to the European\nCommission's Standing Committee On Animals, Plants, Food and Feed\n(SCoPAFF), Dr Petr Šatrán of the Czech State Veterinary\nAdministration indicated that human activities are most likely the\ncause of the spread of the virus, seeing that the nearest reported\ncases of ASF were roughly 500 km 310.68 mi away and that the\npositive dead wild boars were found in inhabited areas. In the other country where ASF was found for the 1st time in 2017,\nRomania, things appear relatively quiet. News broke early this month\nAugust 2017 that ASF was also found on 2 backyard farms in the north\nof the country. Ever since, the Romanian authorities did not report\nany further outbreaks of ASF to the OIE. Of all other countries in the European Union, especially Poland has\ncontinued to report outbreaks of African Swine Fever in smaller and\nmiddle-sized operations. In August alone, on 23 farm sites of various\nsizes, ASF was found to have infected at least one animal, after which\nthe entire herd would have to be culled. The biggest operation in this respect was a farm near Monki, Podlaskie\nprovince, where all remaining 431 pigs had to be culled after 11 had\ndied as a result of ASF, on Sat 19 Aug 2017. Noteworthy as well was\nthe ASF-related closure of 2 farms in Lack, Lubelskie province, in\nearly August. These farms had 136 and 141 pigs respectively see also\nitem 2. Byline: Vincent ter Beek \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview English Longhorns\nGut Laach\nD-52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n(http://www.cvlonghorns.de)\n(cvlonghorns@aol.com) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Poland, fence considered.\nDate: Sat 2 Sep 2017.\nSource: Current News summ., edited\n(http://currentlynews.us/articles/poland-will-18857) \nPoland wants to build along the border with Belarus and Ukraine a\nfence preventing migration of wild boars  carriers of the African\nSwine fever ASF. This was said by Poland's Minister of Agriculture,\nKrzysztof Yurgel, Niezalezna reports. As reported, the length of the fence will be 729 km 452.98 mi,\ncosting Poland 130 million zloties (more than 36.2 million USD). The\nfinal decision on a fence will be made within the next 3 weeks. According to experts, ASF has developed in the territory of Poland\n\"thanks to\" the wild boars who entered from Belarus. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) The accumulated ASF OIE data from Poland as of Thu 31 Aug 2017, are\nas follows (start of event 22 May 2014):\nNumber of follow-up reports: 189\nTotal outbreaks: 550 (Submitted)\nSpecies/ Susceptible/ Cases/ Deaths/ Killed and disposed of/\nSlaughtered\nWild boar/ - / 620 / 620 / 0 / 0\nDomestic Swine/ 6303/ 402/ 188/ 6097/ 0 A map showing ASF cases reported globally to the OIE since 1 Jan 2017,\nas of Thu 31 Aug 2017, is available at (http://tinyurl.com/ybexasqm).\nClick on the European cluster, zoom in to each of the countries of\ninterest. EU disease control measures require designation of risk areas as Part\nI (wild boar at risk, but no cases found), Part II (wild boar testing\npositive but no spill over into domestic pigs), Part III (cases in\nwild boar and occasional spill over into domestic pigs) and Part IV\nwhich concerns the island of Sardinia only. Consignments of live pigs,\nlive wild boars, meat of either source and animal by-products of\neither source are only allowed under certain derogations. For a full\nexplanation, see European Commission Implementing Decision\n2014/708/EU. ASF, a viral disease against which no vaccine has become available so\nfar, is currently threatening central and western Europe, where dense\npopulations of wild boar are present. According to a recent update of DEFRA (UK) ASF situation assessment,\nthe continuing cases in the Czech Republic, the spread in Poland which\nappears to be due to several breakdowns in biosecurity and the new\noutbreaks in Romania are \"concerning\". This signifies a spread in\ngeographic distribution, a possible drop in biosecurity awareness and\ntherefore an increase in the weight of infection in East Europe. Despite the relatively low level of trade in live pigs, there could be\na substantial movement of people, vehicles and personal imports of\npork products, therefore the risk of ASF introduction to the UK has\nbeen raised from \"very low\" (that is, \"rare but could occur\") to\n\"low\". The Russian veterinary watchdog Rosselkhoznadzor believes ASF will\nkeep moving west via 2 main pathways. The southerly route, has already\nseen the virus spread from Ukraine to Moldova. Russian vets believe it\ncould penetrate central Romania, then move to the Balkans, including\nBulgaria and Serbia. On the northern route, now that ASF has been found in the Czech\nRepublic, Rosselkhoznadzor believes, if it gains a foothold, it is\nlikely to head further west, with Germany next in the firing line. The\nsaid is included in a recent update by the Russian journalist\nVladislav Vorotnikov, available at\n(http://www.pig-world.co.uk/comment/where-next-for-african-swine-fever.html).\n- Mod.AS ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Belgium":{},"Belize":{"122":{"title":"Ciguatera fish poisoning - Belize: barracuda,\r\n\talert ","date":["26","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Ciguatera fish poisoning - Belize: barracuda,\r\n\talert [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nCIGUATERA FISH POISONING - BELIZE: BARRACUDA, ALERT\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org). Date: Sat 26 Aug 2017.\nSource: Amandala (edited)\n(http://amandala.com.bz/news/ciguatera-poisoning-linked-turneffe-barracudas/) \nEach year, between 10 000 and 50 000 people who live in or visit\ntropical and subtropical areas suffer from Ciguatera Fish Poisoning\n(CFP), which is said to be one of the most frequently reported\nseafood-toxin illness in the world. Ciguatera poisoning, which causes\nsymptoms such as tingling and numbness in fingers and toes, around\nlips, tongue, mouth and throat; nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and/or\nabdominal cramps; joint pains and headache; and breathing difficulty,\nhas also been reported in Belize, and over the past 4 days, 2 alerts\nhave been issued by the Ministry of Health in Belize, following\nreports of cases cropping up, which have been linked to the\nconsumption of barracuda fish. In the 1st alert, issued on Fri 18 Aug 2017, the Ministry of Health\nreported that \"suspected fish poisoning (Ciguatera poisoning) was\ndetected in people that had eaten fish bought from a fish vendor in\nLadyville, Belize District.\" In the 2nd alert, issued on Tue 23 Aug\n2017, the Ministry said that 2 further cases of suspected Ciguatera\npoisoning, linked to the consumption of the large predatory fish, had\nbeen identified. \"Investigations conducted so far reveal that the\nbarracuda fish from the Turneffe Islands area has been the sole\ncarrier of the ciguaxtoin or poison,\" the alert said. It warned that\ntoxic fish does not have any odor or taste and cooking and freezing\ndoes not eliminate the toxin. According to the US Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC),\nciguatera fish poisoning (or ciguatera) is an illness caused by eating\nfish that contain toxins produced by a marine microalgae called\n_Gambierdiscus toxicus_, associated with corals. Whereas the barracuda\nis believed to be the culprit for the most recent bouts of illness\ncaused by the toxin, other fish may also carry the toxin, including\ncoral trout, red snapper, donu, parrot fish, grouper, Spanish\nmackerel, red emperor, wrasse, reef cod, sturgeon fish, trevally and\nmoray eel. The CDC also lists blackfin snapper, cubera snapper, dog\nsnapper, greater amberjack, hogfish, horse-eye jack, and king mackerel\namong the fish which have been known to carry ciguatoxins. \"Anyone who consumes fish contaminated with the ciguatera toxin will\nbecome ill,\" the Ministry's alert said, adding that, \"The\ngastrointestinal or stomach symptoms normally appear within 24 hours\nof exposure and those of the nervous system can appear 1 to 2 days\nlater.\" Although some symptoms may last only a few days, in some\ncases, the toxin can continue to affect those who ingest it for\nmonths. The CDC says people who have ciguatera may find that cold\nthings feel hot and hot things feel cold. The Belize Ministry of Health has shared some guidelines for reducing\nthe risk of CFP. It advises the following:\n- Avoid eating larger reef fish that have a greater likelihood of\ncarrying ciguatoxins, especially the barracuda. - Limit the weight of a fish to less than 11 pounds, as ciguatera fish\npoisoning occurs more frequently in larger fish. - Eat other types of fish not listed above.\n- Avoid eating the head, roe or fish egg, liver, or other organs of\nthe fish, as it is where the highest level of toxin is present. Byline: Adele Ramos \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) A recent open access review of ciguatera fish poisoning (CFP) has\nbeen published in Marine Drugs:\nFriedman MA , Fernandez M, Backer LC, et al: An updated review of\nCiguatera Fish Poisoning: Clinical, epidemiological, environmental,\nand public health management. Mar Drugs 2017, 15(3): pii: E72;\ndoi:10.3390/md15030072; available at:\n(http://www.mdpi.com/1660-3397/15/3/72/htm.\nThe publication does not say that the intoxication occurs related to\nfish from European waters. The description of the acute illness with\nthe citations intact (the citations can be found at the original URL)\nhas been extracted below: \"CFP is characterized by gastrointestinal, neurological, and\ncardiovascular symptoms. In addition, after the initial or acute\nillness, neuropsychological symptoms may be reported. Clinical\nfeatures can vary depending on elapsed time since eating the toxic\nmeal, and whether the geographic source of the implicated ﬁsh was\nthe Caribbean Sea, Paciﬁc, or Indian Ocean 17,36,52-58.\nGastrointestinal symptoms and signs usually begin within 6-12 hours of\nﬁsh consumption and resolve spontaneously within 1-4 days.\nGastrointestinal symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, abdominal\npain, and diarrhea. The neurologic symptoms usually present within the\n1st 2 days of illness. They often become prominent after the\ngastrointestinal symptoms (particularly in CFP events from Caribbean\nﬁsh), although they may present concurrently with gastrointestinal\nsymptoms (K Schrank, written communication, April 2016) <br><br><strong>{59}</strong>. The\nneurologic symptoms vary among patients and include paresthesias (that\nis, numbness or tingling) in the hands and feet or oral region,\nmetallic taste, sensation of loose teeth, generalized pruritus\n(itching), myalgia (muscle pain), arthralgia (joint pain), headache,\nand dizziness. A distinctive neurologic symptom is cold allodynia,\nsometimes referred to as \"hot-cold reversal,\" an alteration of\ntemperature perception in which touching cold surfaces produces a\nburning sensation or a dysesthesia (that is, unpleasant, abnormal\nsensation) <br><br><strong>{60}</strong>. One study revealed that intra-cutaneous injection of\nCTX in humans elicited this sensation <br><br><strong>{61}</strong>. Cold allodynia is\nconsidered pathognomonic of CFP, although not all patients report\nexperiencing it and it can be seen with other human seafood poisoning\nsyndromes (such as neurotoxic shellﬁsh poisoning). Less commonly,\nsevere central nervous system symptoms, such as coma or\nhallucinations, have been reported 54,62,63. Neuropsychological\nsymptoms, which often become apparent in the days or weeks after the\ninitial or acute illness, include subjectively reported cognitive\ncomplaints such as confusion, reduced memory, and difficulty\nconcentrating 64-67, depression or irritability 64,65,68, and\nanxiety <br><br><strong>{65}</strong>. Fatigue or malaise have been reported and may be\ndebilitating 6,62,69,70. Cardiac symptoms and signs may manifest,\ngenerally in the early stage of the illness. When present, they\nusually occur in combination with gastrointestinal and/or neurologic\nsigns and symptoms 71,72. Cardiac signs often include hypotension\nand bradycardia which may necessitate emergency medical care.\" -\nMod.LL A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/19). Zika virus disease in the United States, 1\nJan 2017-23 Aug 2017\n(http://www.cdc.gov/zika/geo/united-states.html)\nState / Symptomatic cases / Viremic blood donors\nAlabama 3 / 0\nAlaska 1 / 0\nArizona 1 / 0\nArkansas 0 / 0\nCalifornia 22 / 2\nColorado 4 / 0\nConnecticut 0 / 0\nDelaware 0 / 0\nDistrict of Columbia 0 / 0\nFlorida 31 / 3\nGeorgia 2 / 0\nHawaii 1 / 0\nIdaho 0 / 0\nIllinois 3 / 0\nIndiana 1 / 0\nIowa 1 / 0\nKansas 2 / 0\nKentucky 1 / 0\nLouisiana 1 / 0\nMaine 1 / 0\nMaryland 8 / 0\nMassachusetts 7 / 0\nMichigan 7 / 0\nMinnesota 5 / 0\nMississippi 2 / 0\nMissouri 1 / 0\nMontana 0 / 0\nNebraska 1 / 0\nNevada 1 / 0\nNew Hampshire 0 / 0\nNew Jersey 6 / 0\nNew Mexico 0 / 0\nNew York 43 / 1\nNorth Carolina 5 / 0\nNorth Dakota 0 / 0\nOhio 3 / 0\nOklahoma 1 / 0\nOregon 3 / 0\nPennsylvania 4 / 1\nRhode Island 3 / 0\nSouth Carolina 2 / 0\nSouth Dakota 0 / 0\nTennessee 0 / 0\nTexas 18 / 1\nUtah 3 / 0\nVermont 3 / 0\nVirginia 5 / 0\nWashington 3 / 0\nWest Virginia 1 / 1\nWisconsin 3 / 0\nWyoming 2 / 0\nTotals 215 / 9 - Territories and Commonwealth with local transmission:\nSymptomatic / Blood donors\nAmerican Samoa 39 / 0\nPuerto Rico 475 / 3\nUS Virgin Islands 41 / 0\nTotal 555 / 3 A map of the USA showing the states and territories mentioned above\ncan be accessed at (http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/). - Mod.TY \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Ribavirin inhibits Zika virus.\nDate: 14 Aug 2017.\nSource: Antiviral Research journal (edited)\n(http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0166354217301973) \nref: Kamiyama N, Soma R, Hidano S, et al. Ribavirin inhibits Zika\nvirus (ZIKV) replication in vitro and suppresses viremia in\nZIKV-infected STAT1-deficient mice. Antiviral Res. 2017; 146: 1-11.\ndoi: 10.1016/j.antiviral.2017.08.007\n-\nHighlights\n- Ribavirin inhibits ZIKV replication in mammalian cells.\n- Ribavirin prevents ZIKV-induced apoptosis and cell death.\n- Ribavirin administration abrogates viremia in ZIKV-infected\nSTAT1-deficient mice.\n- Leading to a prolonged survival.\nAbstract\nZika fever, a mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by Zika virus\n(ZIKV), is an epidemic disease for which no effective therapy has been\nestablished. The recent outbreaks of ZIKV in Brazil and French\nPolynesia have been linked to a considerable increase in the incidence\nof fetal microcephaly and other diseases such as Guillain-Barre\nsyndrome. Because there is currently no specific therapy or vaccine,\nthe early exploitation of a method to prevent expansion of ZIKV is a\nhigh priority. To validate commonly used antiviral drugs, we evaluated\nthe effect of ribavirin, a drug used to treat hepatitis C with\ninterferon-beta (IFN-beta), on ZIKV replication. In mammalian cells,\nwe observed an inhibitory effect of ribavirin on ZIKV replication and\nZIKV-induced cell death without cytotoxic effect. Furthermore, we\nfound that STAT1-deficient mice, which lack type I IFN signaling, were\nhighly sensitive to ZIKV infection and exhibited lethal outcome.\nRibavirin abrogated viremia in ZIKV-infected STAT-1-deficient mice.\nThese data suggest that the inhibition of viral RNA-dependent RNA\npolymerases may be effective for treatment of ZIKV infection. Our data\nprovide a new insight into the mechanisms for inhibition of ZIKV\nreplication and prevention of Zika fever. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) It will be interesting to see if these encouraging results showing\ninhibition of Zika virus replication can be replicated in non-human\nprimates. The challenge for use of drugs to inhibit Zika virus\ninfection in humans is that most (around 80 percent) Zika virus\ninfections are asymptomatic or have very mild symptoms. These\nindividuals will probably not seek medical treatment, even though\ntheir fetuses are at risk of infection with teratogenic effects. -\nMod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Zika virus skewed immunosuppression.\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2017.\nSource: Nature Microbiology journal (edited)\n(http://www.nature.com/articles/s41564-017-0016-3) \nref: Foo SS, Chen W, Chan Y, et al. Asian Zika virus strains target\nCD14+ blood monocytes and induce M2-skewed immunosuppression during\npregnancy. Nat Microbiol. 2017. doi: 10.1038/s41564-017-0016-3\n-\nAbstract\nBlood CD14+ monocytes are frontline immunomodulators categorized into\nclassical, intermediate or non-classical subsets, and subsequently\ndifferentiated into M1 pro- or M2 anti-inflammatory macrophages on\nstimulation. Although the Zika virus (ZIKV) rapidly establishes\nviraemia, the target cells and immune responses, particularly during\npregnancy, remain elusive. Furthermore, it is unknown whether African-\nand Asian-lineage ZIKV have different phenotypic impacts on host\nimmune responses. Using human blood infection, we identified CD14+\nmonocytes as the primary target for African- or Asian-lineage ZIKV\ninfection. When immunoprofiles of human blood infected with ZIKV were\ncompared, a classical/intermediate monocyte-mediated M1-skewed\ninflammation by the African-lineage ZIKV infection was observed, in\ncontrast to a non-classical monocyte-mediated M2-skewed\nimmunosuppression by the Asian-lineage ZIKV infection. Importantly,\ninfection of the blood of pregnant women revealed an enhanced\nsusceptibility to ZIKV infection. Specifically, Asian-lineage ZIKV\ninfection of pregnant women's blood led to an exacerbated M2-skewed\nimmunosuppression of non-classical monocytes in conjunction with a\nglobal suppression of type I interferon-signaling pathway and an\naberrant expression of host genes associated with pregnancy\ncomplications. Also, 30 ZIKV+ sera from symptomatic pregnant patients\nshowed elevated levels of M2-skewed immunosuppressive cytokines and\npregnancy-complication-associated fibronectin-1. This study\ndemonstrates the differential immunomodulatory responses of blood\nmonocytes, particularly during pregnancy, on infection with different\nlineages of ZIKV. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Virus alters mosquito genes.\nDate: Tue 22 Aug 2017.\nSource: bioRxiv journal (edited)\n(http://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2017/08/22/179416) \nref: Etebari K, Hegde S, Saldana MA, et al. Global transcriptome\nanalysis of _Aedes aegypti_ mosquitoes in response to Zika virus\ninfection. bioRxiv 179416; doi:10.1101/179416\n-\nZika virus (ZIKV) of the Flaviviridae family is a recently emerged\nmosquito-borne virus that has been implicated in the surge of the\nnumber of microcephaly instances in South America. The recent rapid\nspread of the virus led to its declaration as a global health\nemergency by the World Health Organization. The virus is transmitted\nmainly by the mosquito _Aedes aegypti_ that also vectors dengue virus,\nhowever little is known about the interactions of the virus with the\nmosquito vector. In this study, we investigated the transcriptome\nprofiles of whole _Ae. aegypti_ mosquitoes in response to ZIKV\ninfection at 2, 7, and 14 days post-infection using RNA-Seq. Results\nshowed changes in the abundance of a large number of transcripts at\neach time point following infection, with 18 transcripts commonly\nchanged among the 3 time points. Gene ontology analysis revealed that\nmost of the altered genes are involved in metabolic process, cellular\nprocess and proteolysis. In addition, 486 long intergenic non-coding\nRNAs were identified altered upon ZIKV infection. Further, we found\ncorrelational changes of a number of potential mRNA target genes with\nthat of altered host microRNAs. The outcomes provide a basic\nunderstanding of _Ae. aegypti_ responses to ZIKV and helps to\ndetermine host factors involved in replication or mosquito host\nanti-viral response against the virus. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Mosquito vector competence depends on the relationship of virus and\nthe mosquito, and the defenses that the mosquito can mobilize against\nthe virus infection. Studies, such as the one above, can document the\nchanges that occur when the virus infects the mosquito, and if\ndifferences in relative vector efficiency of different geographic\nstrains of this mosquito might be related to alternations in mosquito\ngenes when infected. It would be interesting to know if these gene\nchanges affect fitness, and especially longevity of infected\nmosquitoes. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Virus effects on sperm, body fluids.\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Lancet Infectious Diseases journal (edited)\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(17)30444-9/abstract) \nref: Joguet G, Mansuy JM, Matusali G, et al. Effect of acute Zika\nvirus infection on sperm and virus clearance in body fluids: a\nprospective observational study. Lancet Infect Dis. 2017. pii:\nS1473-3099(17)30444-9. doi: 10.1016/S1473-3099(17)30444-9\n-\nSummary\nBackground\nEvidence of human sexual transmission during Zika virus emergence is a\nmatter of concern, particularly in procreation, but to date, kinetics\nof seminal shedding and the effects of infection on human reproductive\nfunction have not been described. To investigate the effects of Zika\nvirus infection on semen and clearance of Zika virus from semen and\nbody fluids, we aimed to study a cohort of Zika virus-infected men. Methods\nThis prospective observational study recruited men presenting with\nacute Zika virus infection at Pointe-Ã -Pitre University Hospital in\nGuadeloupe, French Caribbean, where a Zika virus outbreak occurred\nbetween April and November, 2016. Blood, urine, and semen were\ncollected at days 7, 11, 20, 30, 60, 90, and 120 after symptom onset,\nand semen characteristics, such as total sperm count, sperm motility,\nvitality, and morphology, and reproductive hormone concentrations,\nsuch as testosterone, inhibin, follicle-stimulating hormone, and\nluteinising hormone, were assessed. At days 7, 11, and 20, semen was\nprocessed to isolate motile spermatozoa. Zika virus RNA was detected\nby RT-PCR using whole blood, serum, urine, seminal plasma, semen\ncells, and motile spermatozoa fractions. Zika virus was isolated from\ndifferent sperm fractions on Vero E6 cultures. Findings\n15 male volunteers (mean age 35 years SD 5; range 25-44) with acute\nZika virus infection and positive Zika virus RNA detection in blood or\nurine were enrolled. Total sperm count was decreased from median\n119âÃâ10^6 spermatozoa (IQR interquartile range 22-234)\nat day 7, to 45.2âÃâ10^6 (16.5-89.6) at day 30, and 70\nÃ 10^6 (28.5-81.4) at day 60, respectively, after Zika virus\ninfection. Inhibin values increased from 93.5 pg/mL (IQR 55-162) at\nday 7 to 150 pg/mL (78-209) at day 120 when total sperm count\nrecovered. In motile spermatozoa obtained after density gradient\nseparation, Zika virus RNA was found in 3 of 14 patients at day 7, 4\nof 15 at day 11, and 4 of 15 at day 20, and replication-competent\nvirus was found in the tested patient. Seminal shedding kinetics\nseemed heterogeneous among patients. Whole blood was the fluid most\nfrequently positive for Zika virus RNA (62 of 92 samples) and 3\npatients remained positive at day 120. Interpretation\nSemen alterations early after acute Zika virus infection might affect\nfertility and could be explained by virus effects on the testis and\nepididymis. Frequency of shedding and high viral load in semen,\ntogether with the presence of replicative virus in a motile\nspermatozoa fraction, can lead to Zika virus transmission during\nsexual contact and assisted reproduction procedures. Whole blood seems\nto be the best specimen for Zika virus RNA detection, diagnosis, and\nfollow-up. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall In a new study that included 12 men in French Guiana who had Zika\nvirus, 4 never had any detectable Zika in their semen, 1 excreted Zika\nvirus in his semen for at least 3 days, and 7 had Zika virus in semen\nfor at least 1 month. The maximum duration of detectable Zika in semen\nin the study was 45 days ((http://tinyurl.com/y9nhtgtk)). This report\nwas provided by Roland HÃ¼bner. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Vaccine update.\nDate: 22/29 Aug 2017.\nSource: Journal of the American Medical Association, JAMA (edited)\n(http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2649168) \nref: Lyon J. Vaccines protect fetus from Zika. JAMA. 2017; 318(8):\n689. doi:10.1001/jama.2017.11200\n-\nResearchers funded in part by the National Institutes of Health have\nrecently demonstrated that 2 experimental vaccines can restrict\ntransmission of Zika virus from pregnant mice to their fetuses,\nthereby shielding offspring from congenital damage or death. Multiple candidate Zika vaccines have been shown protective against\ninfection with the virus in animal studies, with several now in human\ntrials, but none were tested in the context of pregnancy, according to\nthe authors of the study published in Cell\n(http://www.cell.com/cell/fulltext/S0092-8674(17)30759-6). The 2\nvaccine candidates investigated in the new study are the 1st to\ndemonstrate efficacy in preventing vertical transmission of the virus\nand related fetal death in an animal model. Although the vaccines were\nadministered to female mice prior to pregnancy, the result is\nconsidered an important step toward developing a vaccine that could be\nsafely given to pregnant women. One of the 2 candidates is a modified messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine\nencoding Zika genes, developed by the biotechnology company Moderna.\nIt is already in safety trials in women who are not pregnant. The\nother is a live-attenuated Zika strain developed by researchers at the\nUniversity of Texas Medical Branch (UTMB). The testing was carried out by scientists from the National Institute\nof Allergy and Infectious Diseases, Washington University School of\nMedicine, and UTMB. The researchers 1st vaccinated the mice with 1 of\nthe vaccines or a placebo. After mating, the animals were challenged\nwith the virus 6 days into pregnancy. A week later, more than 50\npercent of placentas and fetuses from mice administered the mRNA\nvaccine had virtually no Zika RNA. The remainder had \"substantially\nlower\" levels relative to placebo.\nThe live vaccine provided broader protection: 78 percent of placentas\nand 83 percent of fetuses had Zika RNA at or below the level of\ndetection, while the placebo group exhibited significantly higher\nlevels of placental and fetal Zika RNA. Mice vaccinated with either\nvaccine had significantly higher rates of fetal viability; whereas 100\npercent of fetuses from mice vaccinated with the mRNA vaccine were\nborn, none survived to term in the placebo group. A working group funded by the Wellcome Trust recently approved ethical\nguidelines for testing such vaccines in pregnant women, normally\nexcluded from drug trials. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) It is reassuring to learn that at least 2 vaccines are now entering\nclinical trials in women. Although anti-Zika virus drugs are under\ndevelopment, preventing infection through vaccination seems to be the\nmost effective measure to prevent fetal infection and adverse effects\nof the virus infection in adults. - Mod.TY ","keywordsMatched":[]},"297":{"title":"Dengue/DHF update (11): Americas","date":["28","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Dengue/DHF update (11): Americas","summary":"\nDENGUE/DHF UPDATE (11): AMERICAS\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nCases in various countries:\nAmericas regional\n\nCases in various countries not mentioned above or more recent case\nnumbers. (reported) Oswaldo Cruz Foundation (FIOCRUZ) launched a new\nstage in the fight against dengue fever in Rio de Janeiro by releasing\nspecimens of the mosquito _Aedes aegypti_ with the bacterium\n_Wolbachia_ for the 1st time on large scale.\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/brazil/more-mosquitoes-bacterium-wolbachia-released-tackle-dengue-rio) Bolivia (Santa Cruz department). 17 Aug 2017. Zika virus disease in the United States, 1\nJan 2017-23 Aug 2017\n(http://www.cdc.gov/zika/geo/united-states.html)\nState / Symptomatic cases / Viremic blood donors\nAlabama 3 / 0\nAlaska 1 / 0\nArizona 1 / 0\nArkansas 0 / 0\nCalifornia 22 / 2\nColorado 4 / 0\nConnecticut 0 / 0\nDelaware 0 / 0\nDistrict of Columbia 0 / 0\nFlorida 31 / 3\nGeorgia 2 / 0\nHawaii 1 / 0\nIdaho 0 / 0\nIllinois 3 / 0\nIndiana 1 / 0\nIowa 1 / 0\nKansas 2 / 0\nKentucky 1 / 0\nLouisiana 1 / 0\nMaine 1 / 0\nMaryland 8 / 0\nMassachusetts 7 / 0\nMichigan 7 / 0\nMinnesota 5 / 0\nMississippi 2 / 0\nMissouri 1 / 0\nMontana 0 / 0\nNebraska 1 / 0\nNevada 1 / 0\nNew Hampshire 0 / 0\nNew Jersey 6 / 0\nNew Mexico 0 / 0\nNew York 43 / 1\nNorth Carolina 5 / 0\nNorth Dakota 0 / 0\nOhio 3 / 0\nOklahoma 1 / 0\nOregon 3 / 0\nPennsylvania 4 / 1\nRhode Island 3 / 0\nSouth Carolina 2 / 0\nSouth Dakota 0 / 0\nTennessee 0 / 0\nTexas 18 / 1\nUtah 3 / 0\nVermont 3 / 0\nVirginia 5 / 0\nWashington 3 / 0\nWest Virginia 1 / 1\nWisconsin 3 / 0\nWyoming 2 / 0\nTotals 215 / 9 - Territories and Commonwealth with local transmission:\nSymptomatic / Blood donors\nAmerican Samoa 39 / 0\nPuerto Rico 475 / 3\nUS Virgin Islands 41 / 0\nTotal 555 / 3 A map of the USA showing the states and territories mentioned above\ncan be accessed at (http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/). - Mod.TY \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Ribavirin inhibits Zika virus.\nDate: 14 Aug 2017.\nSource: Antiviral Research journal (edited)\n(http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0166354217301973) \nref: Kamiyama N, Soma R, Hidano S, et al. Ribavirin inhibits Zika\nvirus (ZIKV) replication in vitro and suppresses viremia in\nZIKV-infected STAT1-deficient mice. Antiviral Res. 2017; 146: 1-11.\ndoi: 10.1016/j.antiviral.2017.08.007\n-\nHighlights\n- Ribavirin inhibits ZIKV replication in mammalian cells.\n- Ribavirin prevents ZIKV-induced apoptosis and cell death.\n- Ribavirin administration abrogates viremia in ZIKV-infected\nSTAT1-deficient mice.\n- Leading to a prolonged survival.\nAbstract\nZika fever, a mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by Zika virus\n(ZIKV), is an epidemic disease for which no effective therapy has been\nestablished. The recent outbreaks of ZIKV in Brazil and French\nPolynesia have been linked to a considerable increase in the incidence\nof fetal microcephaly and other diseases such as Guillain-Barre\nsyndrome. Because there is currently no specific therapy or vaccine,\nthe early exploitation of a method to prevent expansion of ZIKV is a\nhigh priority. To validate commonly used antiviral drugs, we evaluated\nthe effect of ribavirin, a drug used to treat hepatitis C with\ninterferon-beta (IFN-beta), on ZIKV replication. In mammalian cells,\nwe observed an inhibitory effect of ribavirin on ZIKV replication and\nZIKV-induced cell death without cytotoxic effect. Furthermore, we\nfound that STAT1-deficient mice, which lack type I IFN signaling, were\nhighly sensitive to ZIKV infection and exhibited lethal outcome.\nRibavirin abrogated viremia in ZIKV-infected STAT-1-deficient mice.\nThese data suggest that the inhibition of viral RNA-dependent RNA\npolymerases may be effective for treatment of ZIKV infection. Our data\nprovide a new insight into the mechanisms for inhibition of ZIKV\nreplication and prevention of Zika fever. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) It will be interesting to see if these encouraging results showing\ninhibition of Zika virus replication can be replicated in non-human\nprimates. The challenge for use of drugs to inhibit Zika virus\ninfection in humans is that most (around 80 percent) Zika virus\ninfections are asymptomatic or have very mild symptoms. These\nindividuals will probably not seek medical treatment, even though\ntheir fetuses are at risk of infection with teratogenic effects. -\nMod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Zika virus skewed immunosuppression.\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2017.\nSource: Nature Microbiology journal (edited)\n(http://www.nature.com/articles/s41564-017-0016-3) \nref: Foo SS, Chen W, Chan Y, et al. Asian Zika virus strains target\nCD14+ blood monocytes and induce M2-skewed immunosuppression during\npregnancy. Nat Microbiol. 2017. doi: 10.1038/s41564-017-0016-3\n-\nAbstract\nBlood CD14+ monocytes are frontline immunomodulators categorized into\nclassical, intermediate or non-classical subsets, and subsequently\ndifferentiated into M1 pro- or M2 anti-inflammatory macrophages on\nstimulation. Although the Zika virus (ZIKV) rapidly establishes\nviraemia, the target cells and immune responses, particularly during\npregnancy, remain elusive. Furthermore, it is unknown whether African-\nand Asian-lineage ZIKV have different phenotypic impacts on host\nimmune responses. Using human blood infection, we identified CD14+\nmonocytes as the primary target for African- or Asian-lineage ZIKV\ninfection. When immunoprofiles of human blood infected with ZIKV were\ncompared, a classical/intermediate monocyte-mediated M1-skewed\ninflammation by the African-lineage ZIKV infection was observed, in\ncontrast to a non-classical monocyte-mediated M2-skewed\nimmunosuppression by the Asian-lineage ZIKV infection. Importantly,\ninfection of the blood of pregnant women revealed an enhanced\nsusceptibility to ZIKV infection. Specifically, Asian-lineage ZIKV\ninfection of pregnant women's blood led to an exacerbated M2-skewed\nimmunosuppression of non-classical monocytes in conjunction with a\nglobal suppression of type I interferon-signaling pathway and an\naberrant expression of host genes associated with pregnancy\ncomplications. Also, 30 ZIKV+ sera from symptomatic pregnant patients\nshowed elevated levels of M2-skewed immunosuppressive cytokines and\npregnancy-complication-associated fibronectin-1. This study\ndemonstrates the differential immunomodulatory responses of blood\nmonocytes, particularly during pregnancy, on infection with different\nlineages of ZIKV. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Virus alters mosquito genes.\nDate: Tue 22 Aug 2017.\nSource: bioRxiv journal (edited)\n(http://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2017/08/22/179416) \nref: Etebari K, Hegde S, Saldana MA, et al. Global transcriptome\nanalysis of _Aedes aegypti_ mosquitoes in response to Zika virus\ninfection. bioRxiv 179416; doi:10.1101/179416\n-\nZika virus (ZIKV) of the Flaviviridae family is a recently emerged\nmosquito-borne virus that has been implicated in the surge of the\nnumber of microcephaly instances in South America. The recent rapid\nspread of the virus led to its declaration as a global health\nemergency by the World Health Organization. The virus is transmitted\nmainly by the mosquito _Aedes aegypti_ that also vectors dengue virus,\nhowever little is known about the interactions of the virus with the\nmosquito vector. In this study, we investigated the transcriptome\nprofiles of whole _Ae. aegypti_ mosquitoes in response to ZIKV\ninfection at 2, 7, and 14 days post-infection using RNA-Seq. Results\nshowed changes in the abundance of a large number of transcripts at\neach time point following infection, with 18 transcripts commonly\nchanged among the 3 time points. Gene ontology analysis revealed that\nmost of the altered genes are involved in metabolic process, cellular\nprocess and proteolysis. In addition, 486 long intergenic non-coding\nRNAs were identified altered upon ZIKV infection. Further, we found\ncorrelational changes of a number of potential mRNA target genes with\nthat of altered host microRNAs. The outcomes provide a basic\nunderstanding of _Ae. aegypti_ responses to ZIKV and helps to\ndetermine host factors involved in replication or mosquito host\nanti-viral response against the virus. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Mosquito vector competence depends on the relationship of virus and\nthe mosquito, and the defenses that the mosquito can mobilize against\nthe virus infection. Studies, such as the one above, can document the\nchanges that occur when the virus infects the mosquito, and if\ndifferences in relative vector efficiency of different geographic\nstrains of this mosquito might be related to alternations in mosquito\ngenes when infected. It would be interesting to know if these gene\nchanges affect fitness, and especially longevity of infected\nmosquitoes. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Virus effects on sperm, body fluids.\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Lancet Infectious Diseases journal (edited)\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(17)30444-9/abstract) \nref: Joguet G, Mansuy JM, Matusali G, et al. Effect of acute Zika\nvirus infection on sperm and virus clearance in body fluids: a\nprospective observational study. Lancet Infect Dis. 2017. pii:\nS1473-3099(17)30444-9. doi: 10.1016/S1473-3099(17)30444-9\n-\nSummary\nBackground\nEvidence of human sexual transmission during Zika virus emergence is a\nmatter of concern, particularly in procreation, but to date, kinetics\nof seminal shedding and the effects of infection on human reproductive\nfunction have not been described. To investigate the effects of Zika\nvirus infection on semen and clearance of Zika virus from semen and\nbody fluids, we aimed to study a cohort of Zika virus-infected men. Methods\nThis prospective observational study recruited men presenting with\nacute Zika virus infection at Pointe-Ã -Pitre University Hospital in\nGuadeloupe, French Caribbean, where a Zika virus outbreak occurred\nbetween April and November, 2016. Blood, urine, and semen were\ncollected at days 7, 11, 20, 30, 60, 90, and 120 after symptom onset,\nand semen characteristics, such as total sperm count, sperm motility,\nvitality, and morphology, and reproductive hormone concentrations,\nsuch as testosterone, inhibin, follicle-stimulating hormone, and\nluteinising hormone, were assessed. At days 7, 11, and 20, semen was\nprocessed to isolate motile spermatozoa. Zika virus RNA was detected\nby RT-PCR using whole blood, serum, urine, seminal plasma, semen\ncells, and motile spermatozoa fractions. Zika virus was isolated from\ndifferent sperm fractions on Vero E6 cultures. Findings\n15 male volunteers (mean age 35 years SD 5; range 25-44) with acute\nZika virus infection and positive Zika virus RNA detection in blood or\nurine were enrolled. Total sperm count was decreased from median\n119âÃâ10^6 spermatozoa (IQR interquartile range 22-234)\nat day 7, to 45.2âÃâ10^6 (16.5-89.6) at day 30, and 70\nÃ 10^6 (28.5-81.4) at day 60, respectively, after Zika virus\ninfection. Inhibin values increased from 93.5 pg/mL (IQR 55-162) at\nday 7 to 150 pg/mL (78-209) at day 120 when total sperm count\nrecovered. In motile spermatozoa obtained after density gradient\nseparation, Zika virus RNA was found in 3 of 14 patients at day 7, 4\nof 15 at day 11, and 4 of 15 at day 20, and replication-competent\nvirus was found in the tested patient. Seminal shedding kinetics\nseemed heterogeneous among patients. Whole blood was the fluid most\nfrequently positive for Zika virus RNA (62 of 92 samples) and 3\npatients remained positive at day 120. Interpretation\nSemen alterations early after acute Zika virus infection might affect\nfertility and could be explained by virus effects on the testis and\nepididymis. Frequency of shedding and high viral load in semen,\ntogether with the presence of replicative virus in a motile\nspermatozoa fraction, can lead to Zika virus transmission during\nsexual contact and assisted reproduction procedures. Whole blood seems\nto be the best specimen for Zika virus RNA detection, diagnosis, and\nfollow-up. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall In a new study that included 12 men in French Guiana who had Zika\nvirus, 4 never had any detectable Zika in their semen, 1 excreted Zika\nvirus in his semen for at least 3 days, and 7 had Zika virus in semen\nfor at least 1 month. The maximum duration of detectable Zika in semen\nin the study was 45 days ((http://tinyurl.com/y9nhtgtk)). This report\nwas provided by Roland HÃ¼bner. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Vaccine update.\nDate: 22/29 Aug 2017.\nSource: Journal of the American Medical Association, JAMA (edited)\n(http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2649168) \nref: Lyon J. Vaccines protect fetus from Zika. JAMA. 2017; 318(8):\n689. doi:10.1001/jama.2017.11200\n-\nResearchers funded in part by the National Institutes of Health have\nrecently demonstrated that 2 experimental vaccines can restrict\ntransmission of Zika virus from pregnant mice to their fetuses,\nthereby shielding offspring from congenital damage or death. Multiple candidate Zika vaccines have been shown protective against\ninfection with the virus in animal studies, with several now in human\ntrials, but none were tested in the context of pregnancy, according to\nthe authors of the study published in Cell\n(http://www.cell.com/cell/fulltext/S0092-8674(17)30759-6). The 2\nvaccine candidates investigated in the new study are the 1st to\ndemonstrate efficacy in preventing vertical transmission of the virus\nand related fetal death in an animal model. Although the vaccines were\nadministered to female mice prior to pregnancy, the result is\nconsidered an important step toward developing a vaccine that could be\nsafely given to pregnant women. One of the 2 candidates is a modified messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine\nencoding Zika genes, developed by the biotechnology company Moderna.\nIt is already in safety trials in women who are not pregnant. The\nother is a live-attenuated Zika strain developed by researchers at the\nUniversity of Texas Medical Branch (UTMB). The testing was carried out by scientists from the National Institute\nof Allergy and Infectious Diseases, Washington University School of\nMedicine, and UTMB. The researchers 1st vaccinated the mice with 1 of\nthe vaccines or a placebo. After mating, the animals were challenged\nwith the virus 6 days into pregnancy. A week later, more than 50\npercent of placentas and fetuses from mice administered the mRNA\nvaccine had virtually no Zika RNA. The remainder had \"substantially\nlower\" levels relative to placebo.\nThe live vaccine provided broader protection: 78 percent of placentas\nand 83 percent of fetuses had Zika RNA at or below the level of\ndetection, while the placebo group exhibited significantly higher\nlevels of placental and fetal Zika RNA. Mice vaccinated with either\nvaccine had significantly higher rates of fetal viability; whereas 100\npercent of fetuses from mice vaccinated with the mRNA vaccine were\nborn, none survived to term in the placebo group. A working group funded by the Wellcome Trust recently approved ethical\nguidelines for testing such vaccines in pregnant women, normally\nexcluded from drug trials. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) It is reassuring to learn that at least 2 vaccines are now entering\nclinical trials in women. Although anti-Zika virus drugs are under\ndevelopment, preventing infection through vaccination seems to be the\nmost effective measure to prevent fetal infection and adverse effects\nof the virus infection in adults. - Mod.TY ","keywordsMatched":[]},"160":{"title":"Inappropriate vaccinia virus use - USA: (CA) stem cell clinic\r\n\t","date":["28","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Inappropriate vaccinia virus use - USA: (CA) stem cell clinic\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nINAPPROPRIATE VACCINIA VIRUS USE - USA: (CALIFORNIA) STEM CELL CLINIC\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org). Date: Mon 28 Aug 2017.\nSource: New York Times (edited)\n(https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/28/health/fda-stem-cell.html?_r=1) \nThe FDA US Food and Drug Administration announced a crackdown on\ndangerous stem cell clinics on Mon 28 Aug 2017, while at the same\ntime pledging to ease the path to approval for companies and doctors\nwith legitimate treatments in the growing field. The agency reported\nactions against 2 large stem cell clinics and a biotech company,\nsaying that it was critical to shut down \"unscrupulous actors\" in\nregenerative medicine, a broad umbrella that includes stem cell and\ngene therapies and immunotherapies. \"The FDA will not allow deceitful\nactors to take advantage of vulnerable patients by purporting to have\ntreatments or cures for serious diseases without any proof that they\nactually work,\" said Dr Scott Gottlieb, the FDA commissioner. Stem cells, which can be extracted from bone marrow, blood, or fat,\ncan develop into many different types of cells, and are thought to\nhave the potential to repair or replace tissue damaged by disease,\ninjury, or aging. But so far, the FDA has approved only a few\nstem-cell products. The companies that the FDA cited have been performing liposuction to\nremove belly fat from patients, extracting stem cells and then\ninjecting those cells back into the patients to treat various\nailments. On Fri 25 Aug 2017, the agency said, federal marshals seized 500\ndoses of live vaccinia virus vaccine for smallpox belonging to\nStemImmune Inc., a San Diego firm that develops stem cell-based\nimmunotherapies for cancer. The raid came after the FDA learned that\nthe vaccine was being used to create an unapproved stem cell product,\na combination of excess amounts of vaccine and stem cells derived from\nbody fat, which was then administered to cancer patients with\npotentially compromised immune systems. The FDA said patients at the\nCalifornia Stem Cell Treatment Centers in Rancho Mirage and Beverly\nHills, California, received the treatment made with the smallpox\nvaccine. It also said it had serious concerns about how StemImmune\nobtained the vaccine for use in an unapproved and potentially\ndangerous treatment. StemImmune obtained at least some of the vaccine from the CDC,\naccording to Thomas Skinner, a CDC spokesman. In its request, the\ncompany said it was conducting cancer research involving the vaccinia\nvirus, and needed to vaccinate researchers  a seemingly legitimate\nreason. The company did not tell the CDC that it was going to inject\nthe vaccine into patients, he said. A statement from StemImmune said\nthe company had lawfully obtained the drug. The FDA also issued a warning letter to US Stem Cell, a private clinic\nin Sunrise, Florida. The company was the subject of a March 2017\nreport in The New England Journal of Medicine, describing how one\nwoman went blind and 2 others suffered severe, permanent eye damage\nafter being given shots of stem cells, extracted from fat, into their\neyes. The warning letter accused the company of impairing the FDA's\nability to conduct its inspection by refusing to allow inspectors in,\nand denying them access to employees. It also said that US Stem Cell\nhad failed to establish proper quality control and sanitary\nstandards. The entire article related to FDA issues with stem cell clinics can\nbe found at the source URL above. - Mod.LL Byline: Sheila Kaplan, Denise Grady \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Clearly scientifically inappropriate use of stem cells by\n\"unscrupulous\" clinics is occurring as discussed in the article above.\nThe posting of this on ProMED was precipitated by the report of the\nsmallpox vaccine, referred to as vaccinia, administered with stem\ncells by injecting directly into a tumor. The current vaccine\n\"ACAM2000\" is the same virus as the former \"Dryvax\" except that the\nvirus is grown in tissue culture rather than from inoculation of\ncalves. The only approved indication for the vaccine is to protect\nindividuals who are working with variations of the vaccinia vaccine in\nlaboratories and for military personnel or others who theoretically\ncould be exposed to smallpox as a biowarfare event. I recently immunized several dozen laboratory workers with ACAM2000\nrelated to work they will be doing with a recombinant vaccinia virus\nin an animal model. In order to obtain the vaccine, we had to fill out\na request form with a list of individuals to be immunized. As a\nreminder, the technique for immunization is \"scarification\" where a\nsmall amount of the reconstituted virus is introduced into the skin\nusing a bifurcated needle\n((https://jetinfectors.files.wordpress.com/2017/01/bifurcated-needle-1.jpg?w=401&h=261)).\nThe primary \"take\" is a vesicle/pustule developing about 7 days later\n(shown at\n(http://health.mo.gov/emergencies/ert/pdf/SmallpoxVaccinationReactions.pdf)).\nOne contraindication for use is in immunocompromised hosts (including\nsome patients with cancer) and the virus is never inoculated by other\ntechniques. More information about vaccination can be obtained from\nthe CDC at (https://www.cdc.gov/smallpox/vaccine-basics/index.html). Currently in press in Lancet Infectious Diseases, Clarissa Damaso from\nInstituto de Biofísica Carlos Chagas Filho, Universidade Federal do\nRio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil has written an excellent review\non the history of smallpox vaccines: Damaso CR: Revisiting Jenner's mysteries, the role of the Beaugency\nlymph in the evolutionary path of ancient smallpox vaccines. Lancet\nInfect Dis. 2017. pii: S1473-3099(17)30445-0. doi:\n10.1016/S1473-3099(17)30445-0; full text, references, and figures\navailable at\n(http://www.thelancet.com/pdfs/journals/laninf/PIIS1473-3099(17)30445-0.pdf): \"The origins of Jenner's vaccine have been intensively debated over\nthe years. British researcher Downie studied the close immunological\nrelationship of variola, cowpox, and vaccinia viruses, which led him\nto propose in 1951 that vaccinia virus had emerged from cowpox virus\nin the early years of vaccination (26). In 1965, Downie strongly\nopposed Peter Razzell's proposal that vaccinia virus had derived from\nan attenuated form of variola virus (27-29). Derrick Baxby (1940-2017)\nalso refuted Razzell's belief and proposed in 1981 that modern 20th\ncentury vaccines had derived from horsepox virus (30-32). In fact, we\ncurrently know that vaccinia virus is more closely related to horsepox\nvirus than to cowpox virus. On the basis of full-genome analysis and\nrecent phylogenetic inferences, horsepox virus is considered an\nancestor of the vaccinia lineage (33-36). Because all modern smallpox\nvaccine strains consist of vaccinia virus, one would expect that\nhorsepox virus, or even vaccinia virus, would be better candidates\nthan cowpox virus for the original source of Jenner's vaccine.\nAlthough an attractive hypothesis, the obscure history of cowpox,\nhorsepox, and vaccinia viruses further adds to the mystery. Since the\nmid-20th century, cows have been rarely found sick because of\ninfection by cowpox virus, and only felines, pet rodents, and zoo\nanimals, primarily in Europe, have been affected by the virus in the\npast decades (37-40). As for horsepox, the disease is rare and some\nbelieve it is extinct, at least in Europe (23,24,31,32,41). Only one\nexisting strain of horsepox virus obtained from Mongolian horses in\n1976 is currently known (33). However, vaccinia virus has never been\nfound naturally occurring in animals, except in India, where the\nstrain buffalopox infects buffaloes, and in Brazil, where the strain\nCantagalo (Cantagalo virus) infects dairy cows (2,42-44). In any case,\nall 3 orthopoxviruses cause zoonotic infections, and individuals\nacquire the infection when handling infected animals figures 2 and 3\n(2,22,37,40,45,46)\" \"The history and evolutionary relationships of the different smallpox\nvaccine strains remain obscure, because most strains and clonal\nvariants have not yet been completely sequenced. Historical and\nscientific evidence suggests that the Beaugency lymph lymph passed in\ncows by Chambon and Lanoix and, in October, 1866, they mixed this\nmaterial with lymph obtained from a 2nd natural case of cowpox\ndiscovered in Saint-Mandé, in the suburbs of Paris. The mixture was\nreferred to as the Beaugency lymph and was used subsequently by the\nAnimal Vaccine Institute as a seed to produce the vaccine\n(20,48,72,74) and horsepox virus made a strong contribution to the\ngenetic makeup of the existing vaccine strains, particularly those\nfrom continental Europe, USA, and Brazil. Evidence also suggests that\nthe Beaugency lymph was probably a vaccinia virus strain or a close\nancestor related to horsepox virus, and not a cowpox strain. Thus, it\nis reasonable to believe not only that cowpox virus was not used as a\nsmallpox vaccine in the 19th century, but that it might have never\nbeen used at all. Assumptions about the origins of the Beaugency lymph\nalso indicate that vaccinia virus was once a circulating virus in\nanimals in Europe in the 19th century, but later it disappeared and\nnow has no natural hosts, except in Brazil, India, and perhaps in\nEgypt, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Nepal. Many questions still persist,\nand analysis of full-genome sequences of ancient vaccine strains would\nhelp unravel this fascinating medical mystery.\" - Mod.LL A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106).
