On 6 May 2017, the Ministry of Health\n(MoH) of Côte d'Ivoire WHO of a dengue fever outbreak in Abidjan, the\ncapital city of Côte d'Ivoire. Suspected cases of dengue were first\nreported on 22 Apr 2017 and confirmed by the Institut Pasteur de Côte\nd'Ivoire (IPCI) laboratory on 28 Apr 2017. As of 11 Jul 2017, a total\nof 623 suspected cases including 2 deaths (case fatality rate: 0.3 per\ncent) have been reported. A total of 192 cases have been confirmed by\nPCR, of which 66 per cent were dengue virus serotype 2 (DENV-2), 29\nper cent were DENV-3, and 5 per cent were DENV-1. In addition, 90\nsamples were confirmed IgM positive by serology. The majority of cases\nhave been reported from Abidjan city. Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted for 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. The general trend of suspected cases of dengue fever\nis increasing. From 27 Jun to 4 Jul 2017, 37 new cases were reported\nand from 4 to 11 Jul 2017, 142 new suspected cases were reported. A\ntotal of 27 per cent of the suspected cases are aged between 15 and 29\nyears old, 55 per cent are 30 years old and above. 54 per cent of the\ncases are female. Coinfection with yellow fever was suspected in 68\ncases and confirmed in one case. Further laboratory confirmation is\nongoing.\n(http://www.who.int/csr/don/04-august-2017-dengue-cote-d-ivoire/en/) - Côte d'Ivoire. 8 Aug 2017. Ivory Coast continues to affect multiple\nregions: 623 cases by mid July serotype DEN-2 (66 per cent), and DEN-3\n(29 per cent). Ninety cases were also confirmed positive for\nimmunoglobulin M (IgM), an antibody produced in the body as an immune\nresponse to dengue infection. According to WHO, the majority of cases\nhave appeared in Abidjan City, while the Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. Additionally, the general trend of suspected cases of\ndengue fever has been increasing, growing from 37 new cases from 27\nJun to 4 Jul to 142 new suspected cases appearing from 4 to 11 Jul\n2017.\n(https://homelandprepnews.com/ stories/23646-dengue-outbreak-\nivory-coast-continues- increase-according-world-\nhealth-organization/) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Côte d'Ivoire can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/52). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Research\n- Viral persistence, organ transplant-related transmission.\nDate: Sun 13 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Star Online (edited)\n(http://tinyurl.com/yd4vv2bj) \nThere is now a concern that the dengue virus can reside in the body\neven after one has recovered and the virus is non-detectable in the\nblood, said a well-known dengue scientist. This came about after 2\nkidney recipients in Taiwan were diagnosed with dengue 2 days after\nreceiving a kidney each from the same donor, said National Cheng Kung\nUniversity microbiology and immunology professor Dr Oscar Perng\nGuey-chuen. \"This indicates a potential risk,\" the Taiwan-based\nscientist said, adding that no dengue virus was detected in the\ndonor's blood. He said the donor contracted dengue in 2015 and in mid-2016, he died\nin an accident. His family donated his corneas, liver, heart, and\nkidneys. Both patients had the same strain of the dengue virus the\ndonor had in 2015 and one of the recipients died of dengue\nhaemorrhagic fever, he said. Asked where the virus could be hiding since it could not be detected\nin the blood, he said it was a question scientists are trying to\nanswer. Interestingly, those who received the donor's corneas, liver,\nand heart did not develop dengue, Dr Perng said on the sidelines of\nthe National Dengue And Arboviruses Infection Conference 2017\nyesterday 12 Aug 2017. He said although there was not enough\nevidence to show the virus came from the donor as the kidneys were not\ntested for dengue before the transplant, the same virus was found in\nthe patients' bodies after that. Dr Perng said his team had studied mice for dengue virus in the blood\ntestes, kidney, liver, spleen and brain, and found the virus present\nin the kidneys and brain. \"We believe the virus probably resided in\nthe kidneys and was not cleared by the body,\" he said, adding that the\nvirus could have been activated after transplant. He said this raised\nconcerns about asymptomatic people who are dengue carriers. Health Ministry deputy director, general Datuk Dr S Jeyaindran said\npatients with severe dengue would have better recovery if they were\ngiven colloids, a more concentrated fluid, at the early stage in fluid\nmanagement for dengue patients. Dr Jeyaindran, who was representing\nHealth Minister Datuk Seri Dr S Subramaniam, said colloids may be\nintroduced at an earlier stage, instead of saline because it has not\nbeen successful in treating patients with severe dengue. He said more\nstudies will be conducted to find out at which stage the colloids\nshould be given. byline: Loh Foon Fong \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Air travel related spread of dengue.\nDate: Thu 3 Aug 2017.\nSource: Medical Xpress (edited)\n(https://medicalxpress.com/news/2017-08-air-responsible-dengue-asia.html) \nWhile the incidences of many other infectious diseases have declined\nover the past decade, the number of cases and outbreaks of dengue\nvirus have continued to increase. The spread of dengue to new areas is\nlikely due in large part to trends in air travel, researchers now\nreport in PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases. Dengue virus affects as estimated 390 million people around the globe\neach year, and can cause symptoms ranging from a mild fever and\nheadache to severe low blood pressure. The virus has mostly caused\ndisease in tropical and subtropical areas of the world, but a 2014\noutbreak in Japan broke that pattern. Overall, the geographic area\naffected by dengue has been growing in recent years. In the new work, Huaiyu Tian and Bing Xu, both of Beijing Normal\nUniversity, China, together with colleagues from the University of\nOxford and elsewhere analyzed the spread of dengue viruses in Asia\nfrom 1956 to 2015. They used 2202 genetic sequences of dengue viruses,\ncollected in 20 countries or regions of Asia over the 59 years, to\ndetermine how different strains were related. They also investigated\ntrends in air travel, maritime mobility, migration, and\nsocio-economics to determine what factors impact the spread of\ndengue. The spread of 3 different dengue virus serotypes, DENV-1, -2, and -3,\nis associated with air traffic more so than any other factors, the\ndata revealed. Air traffic hubs such as Thailand and India, the\nresearchers found, help seed dengue epidemics, while China, Cambodia,\nIndonesia, and Singapore help diffuse the virus to other Asian\ncountries. \"Future trends in global mobility could potentially accelerate the\nappearance and diffusion of DENV worldwide,\" the researchers say.\n\"Prevention and control of dengue epidemics requires a better\nunderstanding of its mode of geographic dissemination, especially for\ncountries in the tropics.\" Reference: Tian H, Sun Z, Faria NR, et al. Increasing airline travel\nmay facilitate co-circulation of multiple dengue virus serotypes in\nAsia. PLoS Negl Trop Dis. 2017; 11(8): e0005694;\n(http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0005694) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Visual impact.\nDate: Fri 25 Aug 2017.\nSource: NYOOOZ, The Indian Express report (edited)\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/delhi/902768/drop-in-vision-traced-to-inflammation-caused-by-dengue-fever-say-doctors/) \nIn a rare symptom of dengue, a 20 year old in the capital developed\n\"ophthalmic complications\" due to which she complained of a \"drop in\nvision\". Typical symptoms of dengue range from sore throat, cough,\njoint pain, and rashes. Sir Gangaram Hospital reported the rare case,\nwhere the woman, who went to the eye OPD outpatient department,\ncomplained of \"sudden blurring of vision in the left eye,\" as reported\nby IE Indian Express. According to the newspaper, doctors eventually discovered that the\ndrop in vision was due to \"inflammation of blood vessels in the\nretina\", as a result of dengue fever. The woman had earlier tested\npositive for the vectorborne disease. \"The patient tested positive for\ndengue and had fever for the past 8 days. She did not have any rashes\non her body, or any other systemic manifestation.\" \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> WHO update.\nDate: The 15 Aug 2017.\nSource: WHO Western Pacific region (edited)\n(http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/dengue_biweekly_20170815.pdf) \nDengue situation update no. 523\n-\nNorthern hemisphere\n-\nCambodia\nAs of 8 Aug 2017, a total of 1604 suspected dengue fever cases were\nreported in 2017. The total number of reported dengue cases including\ndengue haemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome was lower than the\n3 year-threshold of the same period from 2014-2016. China\nAs of 31 Jul 2017, there were 503 cases of dengue reported in China in\n2017. This number is higher than that reported during the same period\nsince 2012 but follows historical trend. Lao PDR People's Democratic Republic\nAs of 4 Aug 2017, there were 5740 cases of dengue with 7 deaths\nreported in Lao PDR in 2017, with 406 cases reported in epi week 31\n(week ending 5 Aug 2017). Dengue activity is high with the number of\ndengue cases reported this year 2017 being higher than the cases\nreported for same period since 2014. Malaysia\nIn week 31 of 2017 (week ending 5 Aug 2017), 1899 dengue cases were\nreported with 2 deaths, an increase of 1.1 per cent compared with week\n30. As of week 31, the cumulative number of dengue cases in 2017 were\n59 521 with 135 deaths compared with 67 437 cases with 147 deaths\nduring the same period in 2016. Singapore\nAs of 5 Aug 2017, there were 1732 dengue cases reported in Singapore\nsince January 2017. This is lower than the number of reported cases\nduring the same period since 2013. During week 31, there were 61 cases\nreported and the number of reported cases in 2017 remains lower than\nthose reported for the same time period in 2016 . Viet Nam\nAs of 3 Aug 2017, there were 80 555 cases of dengue reported in Viet\nNam including 22 deaths. Compared with the same period in 2016, the\ncumulative number of cases increased by 33.5 per cent, and the number\nof deaths rose by 5. Most cases were reported from the South (59 per\ncent). A sharp increase in the number of reported cases has been\nobserved in the North (almost 25 times higher than the same period\nlast year 2016), especially from Ha Noi, with about 13 440 cases. The number of cases reported is lower\nthan that reported during the same time period in the previous years\n(2012-2016). There is a\ndownward trend in the number of reported cases since week 16 (week\nending 22 Apr 2017). \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Latvia":{},"Lebanon":{},"Lesotho":{},"Liberia":{},"Libya":{},"Liechtenstein":{},"Lithuania":{},"Luxembourg":{},"Macao":{},"Macedonia":{},"Madagascar":{},"Malawi":{"298":{"title":"Foot & mouth disease - Malawi: (CK) bovine, st.\r\n\tpending, OIE","date":["30","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Foot & mouth disease - Malawi: (CK) bovine, st.\r\n\tpending, OIE","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Tue 5 Sep 2017. Source: OIE, WAHID (edited) (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=24732)   Foot-and-mouth disease, Malawi  Information received on and dated 5 Sep 2017 from Dr Bernard Chimera, Director of Veterinary Services, Department of Animal Health & Livestock Development, Ministry of Agriculture and Food Security, Lilongwe, Malawi  Summary Report type: immediate notification Date of start of the event: 24 Aug 2017 Date of confirmation of the event: 30 Aug 2017 Reason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease Date of previous occurrence: 25 Mar 2017 Manifestation of disease: clinical disease Causal agent: foot-and-mouth disease virus Serotype: pending Nature of diagnosis: suspicion, clinical This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.  New outbreaks (1) Summary of outbreaks Total outbreaks: 1 Outbreak 1 (MWI/FMD/2017/1): Mthumba Dip Tank, T/A Katunga, Chikwawa Date of start of the outbreak: 24 Aug 2017 Outbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided) Epidemiological unit: other Total animals affected Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered Cattle / 30 000 / 26 / 0 / 0 / 0  Affected population: The affected population is under a communal grazing system and in very close proximity to buffaloes that are in Lengwe National Park. There is occasional mixing of cattle and buffaloes, especially when the buffaloes stray out of the park and graze with cattle. The population is within the locality that is strategically vaccinated against FMD using a trivalent FMD vaccine containing the 3 SAT strains (SAT1, SAT2 and SAT3).  Outbreak statistics rates apparent, expressed as percentages Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost* Cattle / 0.09 / 0 / 0 / 0 *Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter  Epidemiology Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive Epidemiological comments: There is a strong suspicion that it originated from buffaloes found in Lengwe National Park, which occasionally mix with cattle in the area.  Control measures Measures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, quarantine, control of wildlife reservoirs, disinfection, process to inactivate the pathogenic agent in products or by-products, vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animals Measures to be applied: vaccination in response to the outbreak(s), screening, traceability, official destruction of animal products  Diagnostic test results Laboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result Malawi Central Veterinary Laboratory (National laboratory) / Cattle / ELISA 3ABC / - / Pending  \nFuture reporting The event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.  The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  The previous FMD event was reported on 30 Aug 2015, where the serotype SAT1 was identified in 2 outbreaks; these were located in the districts of Chikwawa and Nsanje. The event was resolved on 25 Mar 2016. See a summary and updated map of this event at: (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=18698).  Chikwawa is a district in the southern region of Malawi (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chikwawa_District). A map of Malawi can be seen at (http://www.nationsonline.org/oneworld/map/malawi_map.htm). - Mod.CRD  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8665).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"299":{"title":"Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (95): Africa, Asia","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (95): Africa, Asia","summary":"\nCHOLERA, DIARRHEA AND DYSENTERY UPDATE (95): AFRICA, ASIA\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Nairobi)\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Nairobi) police\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Tana River county)\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong>, <br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Cholera - Nigeria (Borno state) IDPs\n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Cholera - Sudan\n<br><br><strong>{7}</strong> Cholera, diarrhea - Eastern and Southern Africa Region\nAsia\n\n<br><br><strong>{8}</strong> Cholera - Pakistan (Punjab) \nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Nairobi).\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017 9:09 AM EAT.\nSource: Capital FM (edited)\n(https://www.capitalfm.co.ke/news/2017/09/cholera-cases-in-nairobi-rise-to-88/) \nThe number of people admitted to various hospitals in Nairobi after\ntesting positive for cholera has now risen to 88. Nairobi Governor\nMike Sonko stated that as at 8 pm Sunday night, 3 Sep 2017, Sinai\nHospital in Rongai had admitted 50 patients who tested positive, while\nNairobi Women's Hospital had 26. Sonko indicated that those admitted\nto Kenyatta National Hospital were 12 and that \"teams from the\nnational and county governments have been on the ground all day.\" He\nsaid that investigations are still ongoing to ascertain and confirm\nthe diagnosis and the sources of the infection. \"The status of all patients is reported to be stable and under\ncontrol.\" He further appealed to city residents not to panic, as\nadequate controls have been put in place to prevent the spread of the\ndisease. \"Above all, let's continue observing high standards of\nhygiene, while ensuring we eat properly cooked food, cleaned\nvegetables and fruits,\" he stated. Byline: Simon Ndonga \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Kenya can be seen at (http://tinyurl.com/kck73tk) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/174). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Nairobi) police.\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017.\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, EstAfrican report (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/kenya/more-90-police-officers-hit-cholera-nairobi) \nAt least 95 police officers have been hospitalized in Kenya with\nsuspected cases of cholera. According to the Health ministry, the\nofficers are said to have been infected after taking meals at the\nNairobi Area Police Canteen. On Sun 3 Sep 2017, some 59 officers were hospitalised in various\nhospitals in Nairobi with another 36 admitted Mon 4 Sep 2017, after\ncontracting the disease. They were part of a group of 430 officers\ndeployed to Nairobi ahead of the Supreme Court ruling on presidential\npoll petition on Fri 1 Sep 2017. They were residing at the\nMultimedia University Hotel in Rongai, about 17 kilometers 10.6 mi\nsouth of the capital. \"Those infected did not get the disease from the Multimedia University\nsince they had their lunch away from the institution. Investigations\nshow that the source is the Nairobi Area Police Canteen,\" said Dr\nRalph Muli, the Nairobi County head of Diseases Surveillance.\nConsequently, the City has temporarily closed the canteen. The Health Cabinet Secretary Cleopa Mailu said the officers were in\nstable condition. Dr Mailu said investigations were underway to\nestablish whether the canteen had outsourced services to cater for the\nlarge number of officers. He said the ministry was concerned that\ninstead of eliminating cholera, new cases were emerging. Nairobi was first hit by the outbreak on 19 May 2017, with 56 cases\nhaving been reported. One of the police officers who requested anonymity said they ate ugali\n(a Kenyan staple made of maize flour) and meat stew at the canteen on\nSat 2 Sep 2017. He said he started feeling sick in the evening. Byline: Lillian Mutavi \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Tana River county).\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017 10:33 AM.\nSource: KDRTV News, The Daily Nation report (edited)\n(http://www.kdrtv.com/21-people-test-positive-for-cholera-in-tana-river/) \nAt least 20 National Youth Service (NYS) officers have been infected\nwith cholera in Tana River county. County health officials said the 20\nofficers from Bura NYS camp have been admitted to the Bura Sub-County\nHospital. According to Oscar Endekwa, the County Director for Public\nHealth, 21 cholera cases have been reported in the county. Speaking to Nation in his office in Hola, Dr Endekwa said the\nsituation at the NYS camp was under control. \"The officers are\nresponding well to treatment. The other case is of a resident and he\nhas been placed under treatment,\" he said. He added that the symptoms\nwere noted on August 30, though they had not been confirmed, adding\nthat health officials are investigating the cause of the disease. Besides isolating victims, Dr Endekwa said the county is also\nsensitizing residents on hygiene and sanitation. \"We are trying to\ncombat it before it spreads to a larger population,\" he added. He\nasked residents to report any suspicious cases and urged them to drink\nclean water and wash their hands after visiting toilets. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Nigeria (Borno state) IDPs.\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017 2:10 AM WAT.\nSource: Daily Trust (edited)\n(https://www.dailytrust.com.ng/cholera-outbreak-kills-7-idps-in-borno.html) \nOn 3 Sep 2017, 7 internally displaced persons (IDPs) were confirmed\ndead as a result of a cholera outbreak at some IDP camps in Borno\nState This came just 3 weeks after about 100 others were discharged\nfrom Muna and Dala Lawanti Cholera treatment centers. The Médecins\nSans Frontières (MSF) in Maiduguri said the cholera outbreak was due\nto downpours in the last 3 days that caused flood at the affected IDP\ncamps. The Commissioner of Health in the state, Dr Haruna Mshelia said\nmeasures had been taken to contain it from further spread. \"I cannot\ntell you the death toll, as I continue to visit all camps in Maiduguri\nand ensure that the epidemic does not further spread to claim more\nlives,\" he said. One of the rescue workers at Muna Garage IDP camp told newsmen that\nfor only yesterday 3 Sep 2017, they had admitted over 50 patients. \"We have holistic measures to address this cholera outbreak urgently\nalthough people are dying day by day. More than 100 people are\naffected so far, and 51 people were admitted. In the last 24 hours, we\nhave received over 50 patients at MSF's Cholera Treatment Unit at\nDala. Total patients admitted from the start of the outbreak till now\nis over 200 with 100 discharges and 7 dead,\" the rescue worker who\nspoke in confidence, said. The Medical Director of the Médecins Sans Frontières, Anna Cillers,\nalso told newsmen in Maiduguri measures had been put in place to\nprevent further spread of cholera across the metropolis and IDP\ncamps. Byline: Uthman Abubakar, Ibrahim Sawab, Omirin Olatunji \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Nigeria can be seen at\n(ttp://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12103). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Cholera - Nigeria (Borno state) IDPs.\nDate: Tue 5 Sep 2017.\nSource: Medical Xpress (edited)\n(https://medicalxpress.com/news/2017-09-death-toll-nigeria-cholera.html) \nThe death toll from a cholera outbreak in restive northeast Nigeria\nhas risen to 21, with most of the victims living in a camp for people\ndisplaced by Boko Haram violence, the health ministry said Tue 5 Sep\n2017. On Sat 2 Sep 2017, the ministry had said the cholera toll was 14 in\nthe town of Maiduguri, with most of the victims living in a camp for\npeople displaced by Boko Haram violence. \"As of 4 Sep 2017, 21 deaths\nhave been reported,\" the Borno state health ministry said, as the toll\nmounts. \"The total number of suspected cholera cases is now 375 in\nMaiduguri,\" it said, up from 186 at the weekend. Most of the suspected\ncases and deaths are in Muna Garage, a camp for displaced people on\nthe outskirts of Maiduguri, while other victims come from neighboring\ndistricts, it said. The government and NGOs are working to contain the outbreak which has\nspread to the town of Dikwa, 60 kilometres (40 miles) away, where 5\ncases had been reported, it added. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Cholera - Sudan.\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017.\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, Radio Dabanga report (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/sudan/west-darfur-camp-records-six-cholera-deaths) \nWest Darfur\n\nA sheikh in Murnei camp for displaced people told Radio Dabanga that\nby Sun 3 Sep 2017, a total of 22 patients were admitted to the\ncamp's isolation ward. From 27 Aug until 31 Aug 2017, 17 people\nreportedly succumbed to cholera. In Zamzam camp, south of El Fasher\ncity, 4 new cases of cholera were recorded on 1 and 2 Sep 2017. A camp\nelder told this station that the isolation ward was closed on the 1st\nday of Eid Al Adha Sacrifice Feast, 31 Aug-4 Sep 2017, \"because of\nthe absence of medical personnel, so the 4 new patients had to be\ntransferred to El Fasher for treatment.\" Central Darfur\n\nIsolation centers in Zalingei and Abta village, Central Darfur,\nrecorded 3 deaths and 37 new infection cases from 1-3 Sep 2017,\naccording to the coordinator of camps in the state, El Shafee\nAbdallah. In Hamidiya camp, 3 cholera patients died and 13 people\ninfected with cholera reported to the isolation centre. Meanwhile in\nthe last 3 days, the Hassahissa, Khamsa Degaig and Teiba camps\nrecorded 17 new cases. The total number of hospitalized cholera cases\nin the Zalingei Royal Hospital amounted to 76 people as of Sun, 3 Sep\n2017. \"From 1-3 Sep 2017, the isolation center in Abta village near Zalingei\nrecorded 7 new cases. The people are from Abta, Tiri, Dirlo, and\nKalgo,\" El Shafee said. Blue Nile\n\nIn Blue Nile state, 2 people died from cholera and 31 people\ncontracted the disease in the localities Ed Damazin and El Roseires in\nthe last week. A medical source in the area told Radio Dabanga that\nthe Royal Hospital in Ed Damazin received 4 cholera cases of cholera,\nfrom Arquette North. \"2 of them died on Wed 30 Aug 2017.\" Another medical source reported that last week week of 28 Aug 2017,\nthe hospital received 25 cases of cholera from different parts of El\nRoseires. 4 cases were recorded in Gisan locality. \"El Roseires\nlocality recorded the highest number of casualties of all localities\nin Blue Nile. There is a severe neglect of the number of staff in the\nisolation wards, because they were off for the Eid Al Adha holiday.\" Blue Nile was the 1st state to report cases of cholera in September\n2016, or 'acute watery diarrhea' as the Sudanese government has\nreferred to it since the start of the cholera outbreak. A UK-based\nSudanese specialist told Radio Dabanga in January 2017 that cholera\n\"seems to be a stigma for the government.\" \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Sudan can be seen at\n(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Sudan) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/96). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{7}</strong> Cholera, diarrhea - Eastern and Southern Africa Region.\nDate: Thu 31 Aug 2017.\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, UNICEF report (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/somalia/bulletin-choleraawd-outbreaks-eastern-and-southern-africa-regional-update-31-august) \nMore than 100 780 cholera/AWD acute watery diarrhea cases and 1496\ndeaths (CFR: 1.5 percent) have been reported in 12 of 21 countries of\nEastern and Southern Africa Region (ESAR) since the beginning of 2017.\nThese countries include: Somalia, Kenya, South Sudan, Tanzania,\nBurundi, Malawi, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Angola, Uganda, Zambia, and\nRwanda. Somalia accounts for 76.6 percent of the total cases reported\nin the outbreak in 2017, followed by South Sudan at 15.7 percent. In the past 2-3 weeks (weeks 32-34/6-27 Aug 2017), 6 out of the 21\ncountries in ESAR have reported active transmission of cholera/AWD\n(Burundi, Malawi, Somalia, South Sudan, Kenya, and Tanzania). Tanzania\nhas recorded the highest CFR (1.8 percent) followed by South Sudan\n(1.7 percent) in 2017. CFR for Somalia was above 2 percent at the\nbeginning of 2017 but has since dropped to 1.4 percent. Somalia\n-\nThere has been a decrease in the epidemic trend. During week 33 (week\nending 20 Aug 2017), 222 new cases and no deaths were reported in the\ncountry; compared to 282 cases reported in week 32 (week ending 13 Aug\n2017). Out of the 222 new cases, 97 were reported from South Central\nand 125 were from Somali land. Most affected regions are Banadir,\nTogdheer, Awdal, Mjeex, and Lower Jubba. Kenya\n\n4 out of the 47 counties (Garissa, Nairobi, Turkana, and Nakuru) have\nan active cholera outbreak. During week 33, 19 new cases were reported\ncompared to 69 cases in week 32. South Sudan\n\nMost affected populations are nomadic pastoralists and communities\nliving in hard to reach villages and cattle camps. There has been a\ndecrease in the epidemic trend over the past 3 weeks. During week 32,\n30 new cases were reported; compared to 102 cases including 1 death\n(CFR 1 percent) in week 31 (week ending 6 Aug 2017). Active\ntransmission reported in Kapoeta East, South and North, Tonj East,\nYirol East, Nyirol, Ayod, Duk, and Juba. Tanzania\n\nAn increase in epidemic trend. During week 34 (week ending 27 Aug\n2017), 102 new cases have been reported in Tanzanian mainland;\ncompared to 67 cases in week 33. Cases emerged from Mbeya, Iringa, and\nKatavi regions. Malawi\n\nThe current outbreak started within the catchment area of the Chikwawa\nHospital. 11 new cases have been reported in week 34; compared to 2\ncases reported in week 33. Burundi\n-\nThe first case of the current outbreak was identified on 13 Aug 2017\nfrom Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Since then there has been an\nincrease in the epidemic trend with 24 cases reported in week 34; as\ncompared to 13 cases reported in week 33. No death has been reported\nand most of the cases emerged from the city center of Nyanza Lac. Uganda\n\nNo confirmed case of cholera in 2017, only AWD cases reported. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) The countries mentioned above can be seen located on the map of\nAfrica at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6075). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \nAsia\n<br><br><strong>{8}</strong> Cholera - Pakistan (Punjab).\nDate: Tue 5 Sep 2017 12:32 AM IST.\nSource: The Tribune India (edited)\n(http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/this-day-that-year/cholera-in-lahore/462284.html) \nWe understand that cholera is assuming a virulent form in Lahore\nPunjab and that strong and effective measures are called for to\ncombat and stamp out the disease. In Kucha Kharasian in Haveli Mian\nKhan it is said 4 persons were taken ill at about noon and died the\nsame day. The next day, 5 persons were taken ill of the same disease.\nIt is, of course, impossible for laymen to make out whether all these\ncases were of cholera, but the nature of the deaths would seem to\nsuggest the urgent need of effective action. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Pakistan can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofworld.com/pakistan/pakistan-political-map.html) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2128). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Aggressive interventions to stem outbreaks of cholera include\nproviding sources of clean water and a vaccination campaign. The\nfollowing is extracted from Lutwick LI, Preis J, Choi P: Cholera. In:\nChronic illness and disability: the pediatric gastrointestinal tract.\nGreydanus DE, Atay O, Merrick J (eds). NY: Nova Bioscience, 2017 (in\npress): \"For a variety of logistic, financial, and historical reasons,\nvaccines have not been available for cholera control programs outside\nof Viet Nam. Given as 2 or 3 dose courses, efficacy can be as high as\n60-80 per cent for at least 2-3 years but much shorter protection\nlengths in children younger than 5 years of age. Cost-effectiveness,\nespecially once an outbreak has occurred, had remained unproven until\nreports from Guinea (57) and Haiti (58) demonstrated utility. \"The current vaccines prequalified for use by WHO (59) are:\n- Dukoral (produced in Sweden) that contains several biotypes of O1\nwith recombinant cholera toxin B subunit, which also offers some\nprotection against enterotoxigenic _E. coli_;\n- Shanchol (produced in India) that contains biotypes of both O1 and\nO139 without the recombinant B unit. In a large study in Kolkata,\nIndia, a cluster-randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled study of\nthis product (60), the cumulative efficacy of the vaccine at 5 years\nwas 65 per cent (95 per cent CI 52-74, p less than 0.0001). A\nlocally-produced vaccine similar to this vaccine (mORCVAX) is produced\nin Viet Nam;\n- Euvichol (produced in South Korea) that, like Shanchol, contains\nboth O1 and O139 without recombinant B subunit. This vaccine has been\nreported to be non-inferior to Shanchol in a Philippine study (61). \"In June 2016, the US FDA for the 1st time approved a cholera vaccine\nfor use locally in travelers to cholera-endemic areas. This vaccine,\nVaxchora, is an oral live, attenuated biologic (62) that is a\nreformulation of a previous product. This product, a single dose\nimmunization also referred to as CVD 102-HgR, must be stored in the\nfrozen state and as a live, attenuated bacterial vaccine is not given\nuntil at least 14 days after antibacterials were used and should be\ngiven at least 10 days before oral chloroquine antimalarial\nprophylaxis. Single dose use is an advantage over the older\ninactivated products which are given in 2 doses. Studies, however,\nhave suggested that one dose of these inactivated oral vaccines can be\neffective when the vaccines are in short supply in both endemic and\noutbreak situations (63, 64). \"References\n\n57. Luquero FJ, Grout L, Ciglenecki I, et al. Use of _Vibrio cholerae_\nvaccine in an outbreak in Guinea. N Engl J Med. 2014; 370(22):\n2111-2120; (http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1312680).\n58. Sévère K, Rouzier V, Anglade SB, et al. Effectiveness of oral\ncholera vaccine in Haiti: 37-month follow-up. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 2016;\n94(5): 1136-1142;\n(http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.15-0700).\n59. Bhattacharya SK, Sur D, Ali M, et al. 5 year efficacy of a\nbivalent killed whole-cell oral cholera vaccine in Kolkata, India: a\ncluster-randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Lancet Inf\nDis. 2013; 13(12): 1050-1056;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(13)70273-1/fulltext).\n60. WHO. WHO prequalified vaccines.\n(https://extranet.who.int/gavi/PQ_Web/).\n61. Balk YO, Choi SK, Olveda RM, et al. A randomized, non-inferiority\ntrial comparing two bivalent killed, whole cell, oral cholera vaccines\n(Euvichol vs Shanchol) in the Philippines. Vaccine 2015; 33(46):\n6350-65; (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26348402).\n62. Freedman DO. Re-born in the USA: another cholera vaccine for\ntravellers. Travel Med Infect Dis. 2016; 14(4): 295-6; abstract\navailable at\n(http://www.travelmedicinejournal.com/article/S1477-8939(16)30087-4/abstract).\n63. Qadri F, Wierzba TF, Ali M, et al. Efficacy of a single dose,\ninactivated oral cholera vaccine in Bangladesh. N Engl J Med. 2016;\n374(18): 1723-32;\n(http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1510330).\n64. Azman AS, Parker LA, Rumunu J, et al. Effectiveness of one dose of\noral cholera vaccine in response to an outbreak: a case-cohort study.\nLancet Global Health 2016; 4(11): e856-e863;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(16)30211-X/fulltext).\"\n- Mod.LL ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Malaysia":{},"Maldives":{},"Mali":{},"Malta":{},"Marshall Islands":{"136":{"title":"Zika virus (17): Americas, research, observations ","date":["24","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Zika virus (17): Americas, research, observations [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nZIKA VIRUS (16): AMERICAS, RESEARCH, OBSERVATIONS\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cases in various countries: Americas\n\nAmericas cumulative case numbers Cases in various countries not mentioned above or more recent case\nnumbers. mentioned above or more recent case\nnumbers.\nMexico\n\nMexico (Coahuila state). 24 Aug 2017. Zika virus disease in the United States, 1\nJan 2017-23 Aug 2017\n(http://www.cdc.gov/zika/geo/united-states.html)\nState / Symptomatic cases / Viremic blood donors\nAlabama 3 / 0\nAlaska 1 / 0\nArizona 1 / 0\nArkansas 0 / 0\nCalifornia 22 / 2\nColorado 4 / 0\nConnecticut 0 / 0\nDelaware 0 / 0\nDistrict of Columbia 0 / 0\nFlorida 31 / 3\nGeorgia 2 / 0\nHawaii 1 / 0\nIdaho 0 / 0\nIllinois 3 / 0\nIndiana 1 / 0\nIowa 1 / 0\nKansas 2 / 0\nKentucky 1 / 0\nLouisiana 1 / 0\nMaine 1 / 0\nMaryland 8 / 0\nMassachusetts 7 / 0\nMichigan 7 / 0\nMinnesota 5 / 0\nMississippi 2 / 0\nMissouri 1 / 0\nMontana 0 / 0\nNebraska 1 / 0\nNevada 1 / 0\nNew Hampshire 0 / 0\nNew Jersey 6 / 0\nNew Mexico 0 / 0\nNew York 43 / 1\nNorth Carolina 5 / 0\nNorth Dakota 0 / 0\nOhio 3 / 0\nOklahoma 1 / 0\nOregon 3 / 0\nPennsylvania 4 / 1\nRhode Island 3 / 0\nSouth Carolina 2 / 0\nSouth Dakota 0 / 0\nTennessee 0 / 0\nTexas 18 / 1\nUtah 3 / 0\nVermont 3 / 0\nVirginia 5 / 0\nWashington 3 / 0\nWest Virginia 1 / 1\nWisconsin 3 / 0\nWyoming 2 / 0\nTotals 215 / 9 - Territories and Commonwealth with local transmission:\nSymptomatic / Blood donors\nAmerican Samoa 39 / 0\nPuerto Rico 475 / 3\nUS Virgin Islands 41 / 0\nTotal 555 / 3 A map of the USA showing the states and territories mentioned above\ncan be accessed at (http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/). - Mod.TY \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Ribavirin inhibits Zika virus.\nDate: 14 Aug 2017.\nSource: Antiviral Research journal (edited)\n(http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0166354217301973) \nref: Kamiyama N, Soma R, Hidano S, et al. Ribavirin inhibits Zika\nvirus (ZIKV) replication in vitro and suppresses viremia in\nZIKV-infected STAT1-deficient mice. Antiviral Res. 2017; 146: 1-11.\ndoi: 10.1016/j.antiviral.2017.08.007\n-\nHighlights\n- Ribavirin inhibits ZIKV replication in mammalian cells.\n- Ribavirin prevents ZIKV-induced apoptosis and cell death.\n- Ribavirin administration abrogates viremia in ZIKV-infected\nSTAT1-deficient mice.\n- Leading to a prolonged survival.\nAbstract\nZika fever, a mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by Zika virus\n(ZIKV), is an epidemic disease for which no effective therapy has been\nestablished. The recent outbreaks of ZIKV in Brazil and French\nPolynesia have been linked to a considerable increase in the incidence\nof fetal microcephaly and other diseases such as Guillain-Barre\nsyndrome. Because there is currently no specific therapy or vaccine,\nthe early exploitation of a method to prevent expansion of ZIKV is a\nhigh priority. To validate commonly used antiviral drugs, we evaluated\nthe effect of ribavirin, a drug used to treat hepatitis C with\ninterferon-beta (IFN-beta), on ZIKV replication. In mammalian cells,\nwe observed an inhibitory effect of ribavirin on ZIKV replication and\nZIKV-induced cell death without cytotoxic effect. Furthermore, we\nfound that STAT1-deficient mice, which lack type I IFN signaling, were\nhighly sensitive to ZIKV infection and exhibited lethal outcome.\nRibavirin abrogated viremia in ZIKV-infected STAT-1-deficient mice.\nThese data suggest that the inhibition of viral RNA-dependent RNA\npolymerases may be effective for treatment of ZIKV infection. Our data\nprovide a new insight into the mechanisms for inhibition of ZIKV\nreplication and prevention of Zika fever. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) It will be interesting to see if these encouraging results showing\ninhibition of Zika virus replication can be replicated in non-human\nprimates. The challenge for use of drugs to inhibit Zika virus\ninfection in humans is that most (around 80 percent) Zika virus\ninfections are asymptomatic or have very mild symptoms. These\nindividuals will probably not seek medical treatment, even though\ntheir fetuses are at risk of infection with teratogenic effects. -\nMod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Zika virus skewed immunosuppression.\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2017.\nSource: Nature Microbiology journal (edited)\n(http://www.nature.com/articles/s41564-017-0016-3) \nref: Foo SS, Chen W, Chan Y, et al. Asian Zika virus strains target\nCD14+ blood monocytes and induce M2-skewed immunosuppression during\npregnancy. Nat Microbiol. 2017. doi: 10.1038/s41564-017-0016-3\n-\nAbstract\nBlood CD14+ monocytes are frontline immunomodulators categorized into\nclassical, intermediate or non-classical subsets, and subsequently\ndifferentiated into M1 pro- or M2 anti-inflammatory macrophages on\nstimulation. Although the Zika virus (ZIKV) rapidly establishes\nviraemia, the target cells and immune responses, particularly during\npregnancy, remain elusive. Furthermore, it is unknown whether African-\nand Asian-lineage ZIKV have different phenotypic impacts on host\nimmune responses. Using human blood infection, we identified CD14+\nmonocytes as the primary target for African- or Asian-lineage ZIKV\ninfection. When immunoprofiles of human blood infected with ZIKV were\ncompared, a classical/intermediate monocyte-mediated M1-skewed\ninflammation by the African-lineage ZIKV infection was observed, in\ncontrast to a non-classical monocyte-mediated M2-skewed\nimmunosuppression by the Asian-lineage ZIKV infection. Importantly,\ninfection of the blood of pregnant women revealed an enhanced\nsusceptibility to ZIKV infection. Specifically, Asian-lineage ZIKV\ninfection of pregnant women's blood led to an exacerbated M2-skewed\nimmunosuppression of non-classical monocytes in conjunction with a\nglobal suppression of type I interferon-signaling pathway and an\naberrant expression of host genes associated with pregnancy\ncomplications. Also, 30 ZIKV+ sera from symptomatic pregnant patients\nshowed elevated levels of M2-skewed immunosuppressive cytokines and\npregnancy-complication-associated fibronectin-1. This study\ndemonstrates the differential immunomodulatory responses of blood\nmonocytes, particularly during pregnancy, on infection with different\nlineages of ZIKV. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Virus alters mosquito genes.\nDate: Tue 22 Aug 2017.\nSource: bioRxiv journal (edited)\n(http://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2017/08/22/179416) \nref: Etebari K, Hegde S, Saldana MA, et al. Global transcriptome\nanalysis of _Aedes aegypti_ mosquitoes in response to Zika virus\ninfection. bioRxiv 179416; doi:10.1101/179416\n-\nZika virus (ZIKV) of the Flaviviridae family is a recently emerged\nmosquito-borne virus that has been implicated in the surge of the\nnumber of microcephaly instances in South America. The recent rapid\nspread of the virus led to its declaration as a global health\nemergency by the World Health Organization. The virus is transmitted\nmainly by the mosquito _Aedes aegypti_ that also vectors dengue virus,\nhowever little is known about the interactions of the virus with the\nmosquito vector. In this study, we investigated the transcriptome\nprofiles of whole _Ae. aegypti_ mosquitoes in response to ZIKV\ninfection at 2, 7, and 14 days post-infection using RNA-Seq. Results\nshowed changes in the abundance of a large number of transcripts at\neach time point following infection, with 18 transcripts commonly\nchanged among the 3 time points. Gene ontology analysis revealed that\nmost of the altered genes are involved in metabolic process, cellular\nprocess and proteolysis. In addition, 486 long intergenic non-coding\nRNAs were identified altered upon ZIKV infection. Further, we found\ncorrelational changes of a number of potential mRNA target genes with\nthat of altered host microRNAs. The outcomes provide a basic\nunderstanding of _Ae. aegypti_ responses to ZIKV and helps to\ndetermine host factors involved in replication or mosquito host\nanti-viral response against the virus. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Mosquito vector competence depends on the relationship of virus and\nthe mosquito, and the defenses that the mosquito can mobilize against\nthe virus infection. Studies, such as the one above, can document the\nchanges that occur when the virus infects the mosquito, and if\ndifferences in relative vector efficiency of different geographic\nstrains of this mosquito might be related to alternations in mosquito\ngenes when infected. It would be interesting to know if these gene\nchanges affect fitness, and especially longevity of infected\nmosquitoes. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Virus effects on sperm, body fluids.\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Lancet Infectious Diseases journal (edited)\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(17)30444-9/abstract) \nref: Joguet G, Mansuy JM, Matusali G, et al. Effect of acute Zika\nvirus infection on sperm and virus clearance in body fluids: a\nprospective observational study. Lancet Infect Dis. 2017. pii:\nS1473-3099(17)30444-9. doi: 10.1016/S1473-3099(17)30444-9\n-\nSummary\nBackground\nEvidence of human sexual transmission during Zika virus emergence is a\nmatter of concern, particularly in procreation, but to date, kinetics\nof seminal shedding and the effects of infection on human reproductive\nfunction have not been described. To investigate the effects of Zika\nvirus infection on semen and clearance of Zika virus from semen and\nbody fluids, we aimed to study a cohort of Zika virus-infected men. Methods\nThis prospective observational study recruited men presenting with\nacute Zika virus infection at Pointe-Ã -Pitre University Hospital in\nGuadeloupe, French Caribbean, where a Zika virus outbreak occurred\nbetween April and November, 2016. Blood, urine, and semen were\ncollected at days 7, 11, 20, 30, 60, 90, and 120 after symptom onset,\nand semen characteristics, such as total sperm count, sperm motility,\nvitality, and morphology, and reproductive hormone concentrations,\nsuch as testosterone, inhibin, follicle-stimulating hormone, and\nluteinising hormone, were assessed. At days 7, 11, and 20, semen was\nprocessed to isolate motile spermatozoa. Zika virus RNA was detected\nby RT-PCR using whole blood, serum, urine, seminal plasma, semen\ncells, and motile spermatozoa fractions. Zika virus was isolated from\ndifferent sperm fractions on Vero E6 cultures. Findings\n15 male volunteers (mean age 35 years SD 5; range 25-44) with acute\nZika virus infection and positive Zika virus RNA detection in blood or\nurine were enrolled. Total sperm count was decreased from median\n119âÃâ10^6 spermatozoa (IQR interquartile range 22-234)\nat day 7, to 45.2âÃâ10^6 (16.5-89.6) at day 30, and 70\nÃ 10^6 (28.5-81.4) at day 60, respectively, after Zika virus\ninfection. Inhibin values increased from 93.5 pg/mL (IQR 55-162) at\nday 7 to 150 pg/mL (78-209) at day 120 when total sperm count\nrecovered. In motile spermatozoa obtained after density gradient\nseparation, Zika virus RNA was found in 3 of 14 patients at day 7, 4\nof 15 at day 11, and 4 of 15 at day 20, and replication-competent\nvirus was found in the tested patient. Seminal shedding kinetics\nseemed heterogeneous among patients. Whole blood was the fluid most\nfrequently positive for Zika virus RNA (62 of 92 samples) and 3\npatients remained positive at day 120. Interpretation\nSemen alterations early after acute Zika virus infection might affect\nfertility and could be explained by virus effects on the testis and\nepididymis. Frequency of shedding and high viral load in semen,\ntogether with the presence of replicative virus in a motile\nspermatozoa fraction, can lead to Zika virus transmission during\nsexual contact and assisted reproduction procedures. Whole blood seems\nto be the best specimen for Zika virus RNA detection, diagnosis, and\nfollow-up. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall In a new study that included 12 men in French Guiana who had Zika\nvirus, 4 never had any detectable Zika in their semen, 1 excreted Zika\nvirus in his semen for at least 3 days, and 7 had Zika virus in semen\nfor at least 1 month. The maximum duration of detectable Zika in semen\nin the study was 45 days ((http://tinyurl.com/y9nhtgtk)). This report\nwas provided by Roland HÃ¼bner. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Vaccine update.\nDate: 22/29 Aug 2017.\nSource: Journal of the American Medical Association, JAMA (edited)\n(http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2649168) \nref: Lyon J. Vaccines protect fetus from Zika. JAMA. 2017; 318(8):\n689. doi:10.1001/jama.2017.11200\n-\nResearchers funded in part by the National Institutes of Health have\nrecently demonstrated that 2 experimental vaccines can restrict\ntransmission of Zika virus from pregnant mice to their fetuses,\nthereby shielding offspring from congenital damage or death. Multiple candidate Zika vaccines have been shown protective against\ninfection with the virus in animal studies, with several now in human\ntrials, but none were tested in the context of pregnancy, according to\nthe authors of the study published in Cell\n(http://www.cell.com/cell/fulltext/S0092-8674(17)30759-6). The 2\nvaccine candidates investigated in the new study are the 1st to\ndemonstrate efficacy in preventing vertical transmission of the virus\nand related fetal death in an animal model. Although the vaccines were\nadministered to female mice prior to pregnancy, the result is\nconsidered an important step toward developing a vaccine that could be\nsafely given to pregnant women. One of the 2 candidates is a modified messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine\nencoding Zika genes, developed by the biotechnology company Moderna.\nIt is already in safety trials in women who are not pregnant. The\nother is a live-attenuated Zika strain developed by researchers at the\nUniversity of Texas Medical Branch (UTMB). The testing was carried out by scientists from the National Institute\nof Allergy and Infectious Diseases, Washington University School of\nMedicine, and UTMB. The researchers 1st vaccinated the mice with 1 of\nthe vaccines or a placebo. After mating, the animals were challenged\nwith the virus 6 days into pregnancy. A week later, more than 50\npercent of placentas and fetuses from mice administered the mRNA\nvaccine had virtually no Zika RNA. The remainder had \"substantially\nlower\" levels relative to placebo.\nThe live vaccine provided broader protection: 78 percent of placentas\nand 83 percent of fetuses had Zika RNA at or below the level of\ndetection, while the placebo group exhibited significantly higher\nlevels of placental and fetal Zika RNA. Mice vaccinated with either\nvaccine had significantly higher rates of fetal viability; whereas 100\npercent of fetuses from mice vaccinated with the mRNA vaccine were\nborn, none survived to term in the placebo group. A working group funded by the Wellcome Trust recently approved ethical\nguidelines for testing such vaccines in pregnant women, normally\nexcluded from drug trials. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) It is reassuring to learn that at least 2 vaccines are now entering\nclinical trials in women. Although anti-Zika virus drugs are under\ndevelopment, preventing infection through vaccination seems to be the\nmost effective measure to prevent fetal infection and adverse effects\nof the virus infection in adults. - Mod.TY ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Mauritania":{"126":{"title":"Undiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - Mauritania: (TR) RFI\r\n\t","date":["24","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Undiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - Mauritania: (TR) RFI\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nUNDIAGNOSED HEMORRHAGIC ILLNESS - MAURITANIA: (TRARZA) REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org). Date: Thu 24 Aug 2017 10:38.\nSource: APA (Agence de Presse Africaine) News in French, trans.\nCorr.SB, edited\n(http://apanews.net/index.php/fr/news/apparition-dun-cas-de-fievre-hemorragique-en-mauritanie) \nA case of confirmed haemorrhagic fever has been detected in\nMauritania, medical sources said Thu 24 Aug 2017 in Nouakchott. A male patient is currently hospitalized at Hamed Ben Khalifa hospital\nin Boutilimit Trarza region, 160 km 99 mi southeast of Nouakchott,\nthe same sources added, without specifying what type of haemorrhagic\nfever. The patient was evacuated Tue 22 Aug 2017 from an area located 140\nkm 87 mi south of Boutilimit and some 30 km 19 mi north of the\ntown of Boghé Brakna region on the Senegal River. After suspecting the illness, the attending medical staff sent a\nsample of the patient's blood to Nouakchott for further analysis and\neventually confirmed the existence of the virus which virus? -\nMod.TY The Mauritanian Ministry of Health immediately dispatched a mission to\nBoutilimit, which carried out investigations to verify that no other\nperson had been reached by the virus in the area from which the\npatient came. The investigations also seek to ensure that there was no contamination\ninfection among the persons who had been in contact with the patient\nbefore the diagnosis of his case. This wintering period in Mauritania is generally conducive to the\nappearance of several types of diseases, including haemorrhagic\nfevers. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Unfortunately, the virus responsible for this case is not stated in\nthe report above. Several viruses are possible, including Rift Valley\nfever, yellow fever, Lassa fever, and the Ebola-related viruses.\nApparently, no other individuals have been affected in the area from\nwhich the patient came. The current clinical status of the patient is\nnot stated. ProMED-mail would appreciate receiving additional\ninformation about the symptoms that the patient is presenting and the\nidentification of the virus involved. There is a 3 Jun 2017 reported case of Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV)\ninfection in Mauritania. That case appears to have occurred 2 months\nprior to the case reported above, but it raises the possibility that\nRVFV is responsible for this latest case (see Rift Valley fever -\nMauritania: RFI http://promedmail.org/post/20170605.5085590). Maps of Mauritania can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofworld.com/mauritania/maps/map-of-mauritania.jpg) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11620). - Mod.TY ","keywordsMatched":[]},"145":{"title":"Crimean-Congo hem. fever - Mauritania: (BT) ","date":["28","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Crimean-Congo hem. fever - Mauritania: (BT) [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: 28 Aug 2017. Source: Outbreak News Today (edited) (http://outbreaknewstoday.com/mauritania-reports-confirmed-crimean-congo-hemorrhagic-fever-case-21416/)   On 24 Aug 2017, the Mauritania Ministry of Health notified WHO of a confirmed case of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) in a 47-year-old shepherd, from Arafat Village in Mohammedia, Boutilimit Prefecture, located about 150 km southeast of the capital, Nouakchott.  In May 2017, health officials reported 2 imported cases of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) in Senegal imported from Mauritania. A 3rd imported case was reported in June 2017.  He developed headache, muscle and joints pains and diarrhea on 20 Aug 2017 and sought medical attention. He was treated with anti-malarial medicines and analgesics.  After 2 days, he returned for medical care as his condition worsened. He was tested for CCHF because of bleeding manifestations and was IgM positive for Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). The patient is still hospitalized and in stable clinical condition.  Mauritania experienced a fairly large CCHF outbreak in 2003, involving 38 cases with a case fatality rate of 28.6 percent. According to the WHO, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever is a widespread disease caused by a tick-borne virus (Nairovirus) of the Bunyaviridae family. The CCHF virus causes severe viral hemorrhagic fever outbreaks, with a case fatality rate of 10-40 percent.  CCHF is endemic in Africa, the Balkans, the Middle East and Asian countries south of the 50th parallel north, the geographical limit of the principal tick vector. The hosts of the CCHF virus include a wide range of wild and domestic animals such as cattle, sheep and goats.  Animals become infected by the bite of infected ticks, and the virus remains in their bloodstream for about one week after infection, allowing the tick-animal-tick cycle to continue when another tick bites. Although a number of tick genera are capable of becoming infected with CCHF virus, ticks of the genus _Hyalomma_ are the principal vectors.  The CCHF virus is transmitted to people either by tick bites or through contact with infected animal blood or tissues during and immediately after slaughter. The majority of cases have occurred in people involved in the livestock industry, such as agricultural workers, slaughterhouse workers and veterinarians. Human-to-human transmission is possible.  Byline: Robert Herriman   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  An outbreak of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever was documented in Nouakchott, the capital of Mauritania in 2003. The index case was detected on 18 Feb 2003. By 21 Mar 2003, the Ministry of Health of Mauritania had reported a total of 35 cases (18 laboratory confirmed) of Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF), including 6 deaths Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever - Mauritania (04) http://promedmail.org/post/20030324.0732.  In the period from February to August 2003, 38 persons were infected with Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) virus; 35 of these persons were residents of Nouakchott. The 1st patient was a young woman who became ill shortly after butchering a goat. She transmitted the infection to 15 persons in the hospital where she was admitted and 4 members of her family. In Nouakchott, 2 disease clusters and 11 isolated cases were identified. Of the patients not infected by the 1st case-patient, almost half were butchers, which suggests that the primary mode of animal-to-human transmission was direct contact with blood of infected animals.  Cattle heavily infested with ticks were more likely to be CCHFV seropositive, and vector control to reduce the tick burden can result in reduced seroprevalence. Cattle are noted as the most sensitive indicator of low-level CCHFV circulation because they tend to be highly infested with _Hyalomma_ spp. ticks, which are the most common vectors of CCHF (http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0004210).  The circulation of CCHF virus and the high prevalence of infected animals and ticks have been well documented in Mauritanian farming areas since 1983 Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever and Rift Valley fever in south-eastern Mauritania. Saluzzo JF, Digoutte JP, Camicas JL, Chauvancy G Lancet. 1985 Jan 12; 1(8420):116.  Since then, this is the latest case reported from that country, with history of exposure to livestock. - Mod.UBA  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/13859).  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Mauritius":{},"Mexico":{"87":{"title":"E. coli EHEC - USA (26): (MI) O157,\r\n\tantimicrobial resistance ","date":["24","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> E. coli EHEC - USA (26): (MI) O157,\r\n\tantimicrobial resistance [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Thu 24 Aug 2017. Source: Emerg Infect Dis. 2017;23(9):1609-1611. (https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/9/17-0523_article)   Antimicrobial drug-resistant Shiga toxin-producing _Escherichia coli_ infections, Michigan, USA  Shiga toxin-producing _Escherichia coli_ (STEC) also called enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_ - EHEC - Mod.LL contributes to 265 000 cases of foodborne illness annually in the USA (1). Most infections are caused by O157 strains; however, non-O157 EHEC infections have increased (2). Antimicrobial drug resistance among EHEC has been reported (3-5) but is probably underestimated. Given the importance of resistance in _E. coli_ pathotypes, we sought to determine the prevalence of resistant EHEC infections and assess the effects of resistance on disease.  We obtained 358 STEC isolates from the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services (MDHHS) Reference Laboratory (Lansing, MI, USA), collected during 2010-2014. Of these, 14 were outbreak associated. We examined one strain per outbreak using protocols approved by Michigan State University and MDHHS. Overall, 31 (8.8 per cent) strains (23 non-O157, 8 O157) were resistant to antimicrobial drugs (table for table and figures, see original URL - Mod.LL). Resistance to ampicillin (7.4 per cent) was the commonest, followed by trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (SXT) (4.0 per cent) and ciprofloxacin (0.3 per cent). Compared with national rates, resistance to ampicillin and SXT was higher, but not significantly different, for O157 isolates from Michigan (figure 1) (6). One strain was resistant to all drugs, and all resistant strains had high MICs (ampicillin, )64 ug/mL; ciprofloxacin, )32 ug/mL; SXT, in 1:19 ratio, )32/608 ug/mL). Notably, resistance was twice as common for non-O157 (11.1 per cent) than for O157 (5.5 per cent) strains. O111 strains (n=7) had significantly higher resistance frequencies (24.1 per cent) than other non-O157 serogroups (p=0.03). We found variation by year and season; resistance frequencies were highest in 2012 (figure 2) and during winter/spring (table 1), but neither trend was significant. We also observed a strong but nonsignificant association between resistance and hospitalization but no association for urban versus rural residence (7) or county after stratifying by prescription rates (8) in the univariate analyses.  We conducted a multivariate analysis using logistic regression, with hospitalization as the dependent variable; we included variables with significant (p(0.05) and strong (p(0.20) associations from the univariate analysis as independent variables. Forward selection indicated that hospitalized patients were more likely to have resistant infections (odds ratio OR 2.4, 95 per cent confidence interval CI 1.00-5.82) and less likely to have non-O157 infections (OR 0.4, CI 0.21-0.61) (table 2), suggesting that resistant infections or O157 infections may cause more severe clinical outcomes. Patients over 18 years of age, women, and patients with bloody diarrhea were also more likely to be hospitalized.  Although we found no significant difference by stx profile, strains possessing stx1 only were more commonly resistant than strains with stx2 alone (p=0.27 by Fisher exact test). All 23 (100 per cent) resistant non-O157 EHEC and 1 (12.5 per cent) resistant O157 strain had stx1 only. Strains positive for eae were less likely to be resistant (n=27; 8.4 per cent) than eae-negative strains (n=4; 23.5 per cent); this nonsignificant difference (p=0.07 by Fisher exact test) could be due to small sample sizes. All 8 resistant O157 strains and 18 (78.3 per cent) of 23 resistant non-O157 strains had eae, demonstrating correlations between virulence genes and serogroups.  Overall, we detected a high frequency of resistance among non-O157 EHEC (11.2 per cent), similar to findings from Mexico (15 per cent), although we evaluated fewer drugs (5). Resistance to ciprofloxacin was low despite its routine use for treating enteric infections, perhaps because resistance development in _E. coli_ requires multiple mutations (9). Resistance frequencies in EHEC were low relative to other _E. coli_ pathotypes such as extraintestinal _E. coli_, which may be attributable to differences in the source of the infections (3).  The higher O157 resistance frequencies in Michigan than nationwide indicate that selection pressures vary by location and source. Although we observed no difference in resistance frequencies for counties with high versus low antimicrobial drug prescription rates (8), we have not investigated selection pressures from drug use in farm environments that may affect resistance emergence in Michigan. Approximately 12 million kg of antimicrobial drugs are administered to food animals annually in the USA; roughly 61 per cent of these are medically relevant. Higher resistance frequencies in winter/spring (12.2 per cent) than summer/fall (7.5 per cent) could be attributed to variation in prescription rates by season (10).  Because Michigan is not part of the CDC Foodborne Diseases Active Surveillance Network and resistance in EHEC has not been widely researched, data about the prevalence and impact of resistance are lacking. This study detected a high frequency of EHEC resistance to antimicrobial drugs commonly used in human and veterinary medicine, particularly for non-O157 serotypes, which have increased in frequency (2). Monitoring resistance in EHEC is essential because of the risk of transmitting resistant strains from food animals to humans and the high likelihood of horizontal transfer of resistance genes from EHEC to other pathogens. Routine monitoring can uncover new treatment approaches and guide development of strategies for controlling emergence and spread of resistance in EHEC and other _E. coli_ pathotypes.  References - 1. Scallan E, Hoekstra RM, Angulo FJ, Tauxe RV, Widdowson MA, Roy SL, et al. Foodborne illness acquired in the United Statesmajor pathogens. Emerg Infect Dis. 2011;17: 7-15. 2. Tseng M, Sha Q, Rudrik JT, Collins J, Henderson T, Funk JA, et al: Increasing incidence of non-O157 Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC) in Michigan and association with clinical illness. Epidemiol Infect. 2016;144: 1394-1405. 3. Schroeder CM, Meng J, Zhao S, DebRoy C, Torcolini J, Zhao C, et al: Antimicrobial resistance of Escherichia coli O26, O103, O111, O128, and O145 from animals and humans. Emerg Infect Dis. 2002;8: 1409-1414. 4. Mora A, Blanco JE, Blanco M, Alonso MP, Dhabi G, Echeita A, et al: Antimicrobial resistance of Shiga toxin (verotoxin)-producing Escherichia coli O157:H7 and non-O157 strains isolated from humans, cattle, sheep and food in Spain. Res Microbiol. 2005;156: 793-806. 5. Antimicrob Resist Infect Control. 2016;5: 1-6. 6. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: NARMS now: human data 2016 cited 2016 Oct 12. (http://wwwn.cdc.gov/narmsnow/) 7. Jacoby GA: Mechanisms of resistance to quinolones. Clin Infect Dis. 2005;41(Suppl 2): S120-S126. 10. Suda KJ, Hicks LA, Roberts RM, Hunkler RJ, Taylor TH: Trends and seasonal variation in outpatient antibiotic prescription rates in the United States, 2006 to 2010. Antimicrob Agents Chemother. 2014;58: 2763-2766.  authors: Mukherjee S, Mosci RE, Anderson CM, Snyder BA, Collins J, Rudrik JT, et al   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  The degree of antimicrobial resistance in this report seems no more than what is seen in community-acquired non-EHEC infections.  Regarding the use of antimicrobials in EHEC is often a moot point since in most cases they are not utilized, at least early, because of the increased risk of hemolytic uremic syndrome but is relevant in cases where embarrassment of the colonic lumen occurs. In the large _E. coli_ O104:H4 outbreak in northern Germany, antimicrobial therapy was used especially in those cases where the colon was perforated. In those reports, the carbapenem antimicrobials also did not increase toxin production. Whether these effects are strain specific is not clear at this time so should not necessarily be generalized to all EHEC. Of note, the _E. coli_ O104:H4 strain is a genetic hybrid between EHEC and enteroaggregative _E. coli_ and not thought to be a zoonosis.  Extraintestinal invasive strains of EHEC (ProMED-mail. E. coli EHEC - France: O80:H2, hybrid invasive pathogen, 2005-2014 http://promedmail.org/post/20160909.4474015 and other reports) indeed introduces another layer of concern about these infections. - Mod.LL  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/225). The\nmother was unaware that she had been infected.\n(https://www.thedailyherald.sx/islands/68711-country-sees-first-case-of-suspected-zika-related-microcephaly-at-smmc) South America\n\nBolivia (Santa Cruz department). 17 Aug 2017 (registered) 145 cases of\nwhom 40 are pregnant.
