Zika virus disease in the United States, 1\nJan 2017-23 Aug 2017\n(http://www.cdc.gov/zika/geo/united-states.html)\nState / Symptomatic cases / Viremic blood donors\nAlabama 3 / 0\nAlaska 1 / 0\nArizona 1 / 0\nArkansas 0 / 0\nCalifornia 22 / 2\nColorado 4 / 0\nConnecticut 0 / 0\nDelaware 0 / 0\nDistrict of Columbia 0 / 0\nFlorida 31 / 3\nGeorgia 2 / 0\nHawaii 1 / 0\nIdaho 0 / 0\nIllinois 3 / 0\nIndiana 1 / 0\nIowa 1 / 0\nKansas 2 / 0\nKentucky 1 / 0\nLouisiana 1 / 0\nMaine 1 / 0\nMaryland 8 / 0\nMassachusetts 7 / 0\nMichigan 7 / 0\nMinnesota 5 / 0\nMississippi 2 / 0\nMissouri 1 / 0\nMontana 0 / 0\nNebraska 1 / 0\nNevada 1 / 0\nNew Hampshire 0 / 0\nNew Jersey 6 / 0\nNew Mexico 0 / 0\nNew York 43 / 1\nNorth Carolina 5 / 0\nNorth Dakota 0 / 0\nOhio 3 / 0\nOklahoma 1 / 0\nOregon 3 / 0\nPennsylvania 4 / 1\nRhode Island 3 / 0\nSouth Carolina 2 / 0\nSouth Dakota 0 / 0\nTennessee 0 / 0\nTexas 18 / 1\nUtah 3 / 0\nVermont 3 / 0\nVirginia 5 / 0\nWashington 3 / 0\nWest Virginia 1 / 1\nWisconsin 3 / 0\nWyoming 2 / 0\nTotals 215 / 9 - Territories and Commonwealth with local transmission:\nSymptomatic / Blood donors\nAmerican Samoa 39 / 0\nPuerto Rico 475 / 3\nUS Virgin Islands 41 / 0\nTotal 555 / 3 A map of the USA showing the states and territories mentioned above\ncan be accessed at (http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/). - Mod.TY \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Ribavirin inhibits Zika virus.\nDate: 14 Aug 2017.\nSource: Antiviral Research journal (edited)\n(http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0166354217301973) \nref: Kamiyama N, Soma R, Hidano S, et al. Ribavirin inhibits Zika\nvirus (ZIKV) replication in vitro and suppresses viremia in\nZIKV-infected STAT1-deficient mice. Antiviral Res. 2017; 146: 1-11.\ndoi: 10.1016/j.antiviral.2017.08.007\n-\nHighlights\n- Ribavirin inhibits ZIKV replication in mammalian cells.\n- Ribavirin prevents ZIKV-induced apoptosis and cell death.\n- Ribavirin administration abrogates viremia in ZIKV-infected\nSTAT1-deficient mice.\n- Leading to a prolonged survival.\nAbstract\nZika fever, a mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by Zika virus\n(ZIKV), is an epidemic disease for which no effective therapy has been\nestablished. The recent outbreaks of ZIKV in Brazil and French\nPolynesia have been linked to a considerable increase in the incidence\nof fetal microcephaly and other diseases such as Guillain-Barre\nsyndrome. Because there is currently no specific therapy or vaccine,\nthe early exploitation of a method to prevent expansion of ZIKV is a\nhigh priority. To validate commonly used antiviral drugs, we evaluated\nthe effect of ribavirin, a drug used to treat hepatitis C with\ninterferon-beta (IFN-beta), on ZIKV replication. In mammalian cells,\nwe observed an inhibitory effect of ribavirin on ZIKV replication and\nZIKV-induced cell death without cytotoxic effect. Furthermore, we\nfound that STAT1-deficient mice, which lack type I IFN signaling, were\nhighly sensitive to ZIKV infection and exhibited lethal outcome.\nRibavirin abrogated viremia in ZIKV-infected STAT-1-deficient mice.\nThese data suggest that the inhibition of viral RNA-dependent RNA\npolymerases may be effective for treatment of ZIKV infection. Our data\nprovide a new insight into the mechanisms for inhibition of ZIKV\nreplication and prevention of Zika fever. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) It will be interesting to see if these encouraging results showing\ninhibition of Zika virus replication can be replicated in non-human\nprimates. The challenge for use of drugs to inhibit Zika virus\ninfection in humans is that most (around 80 percent) Zika virus\ninfections are asymptomatic or have very mild symptoms. These\nindividuals will probably not seek medical treatment, even though\ntheir fetuses are at risk of infection with teratogenic effects. -\nMod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Zika virus skewed immunosuppression.\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2017.\nSource: Nature Microbiology journal (edited)\n(http://www.nature.com/articles/s41564-017-0016-3) \nref: Foo SS, Chen W, Chan Y, et al. Asian Zika virus strains target\nCD14+ blood monocytes and induce M2-skewed immunosuppression during\npregnancy. Nat Microbiol. 2017. doi: 10.1038/s41564-017-0016-3\n-\nAbstract\nBlood CD14+ monocytes are frontline immunomodulators categorized into\nclassical, intermediate or non-classical subsets, and subsequently\ndifferentiated into M1 pro- or M2 anti-inflammatory macrophages on\nstimulation. Although the Zika virus (ZIKV) rapidly establishes\nviraemia, the target cells and immune responses, particularly during\npregnancy, remain elusive. Furthermore, it is unknown whether African-\nand Asian-lineage ZIKV have different phenotypic impacts on host\nimmune responses. Using human blood infection, we identified CD14+\nmonocytes as the primary target for African- or Asian-lineage ZIKV\ninfection. When immunoprofiles of human blood infected with ZIKV were\ncompared, a classical/intermediate monocyte-mediated M1-skewed\ninflammation by the African-lineage ZIKV infection was observed, in\ncontrast to a non-classical monocyte-mediated M2-skewed\nimmunosuppression by the Asian-lineage ZIKV infection. Importantly,\ninfection of the blood of pregnant women revealed an enhanced\nsusceptibility to ZIKV infection. Specifically, Asian-lineage ZIKV\ninfection of pregnant women's blood led to an exacerbated M2-skewed\nimmunosuppression of non-classical monocytes in conjunction with a\nglobal suppression of type I interferon-signaling pathway and an\naberrant expression of host genes associated with pregnancy\ncomplications. Also, 30 ZIKV+ sera from symptomatic pregnant patients\nshowed elevated levels of M2-skewed immunosuppressive cytokines and\npregnancy-complication-associated fibronectin-1. This study\ndemonstrates the differential immunomodulatory responses of blood\nmonocytes, particularly during pregnancy, on infection with different\nlineages of ZIKV. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Virus alters mosquito genes.\nDate: Tue 22 Aug 2017.\nSource: bioRxiv journal (edited)\n(http://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2017/08/22/179416) \nref: Etebari K, Hegde S, Saldana MA, et al. Global transcriptome\nanalysis of _Aedes aegypti_ mosquitoes in response to Zika virus\ninfection. bioRxiv 179416; doi:10.1101/179416\n-\nZika virus (ZIKV) of the Flaviviridae family is a recently emerged\nmosquito-borne virus that has been implicated in the surge of the\nnumber of microcephaly instances in South America. The recent rapid\nspread of the virus led to its declaration as a global health\nemergency by the World Health Organization. The virus is transmitted\nmainly by the mosquito _Aedes aegypti_ that also vectors dengue virus,\nhowever little is known about the interactions of the virus with the\nmosquito vector. In this study, we investigated the transcriptome\nprofiles of whole _Ae. aegypti_ mosquitoes in response to ZIKV\ninfection at 2, 7, and 14 days post-infection using RNA-Seq. Results\nshowed changes in the abundance of a large number of transcripts at\neach time point following infection, with 18 transcripts commonly\nchanged among the 3 time points. Gene ontology analysis revealed that\nmost of the altered genes are involved in metabolic process, cellular\nprocess and proteolysis. In addition, 486 long intergenic non-coding\nRNAs were identified altered upon ZIKV infection. Further, we found\ncorrelational changes of a number of potential mRNA target genes with\nthat of altered host microRNAs. The outcomes provide a basic\nunderstanding of _Ae. aegypti_ responses to ZIKV and helps to\ndetermine host factors involved in replication or mosquito host\nanti-viral response against the virus. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Mosquito vector competence depends on the relationship of virus and\nthe mosquito, and the defenses that the mosquito can mobilize against\nthe virus infection. Studies, such as the one above, can document the\nchanges that occur when the virus infects the mosquito, and if\ndifferences in relative vector efficiency of different geographic\nstrains of this mosquito might be related to alternations in mosquito\ngenes when infected. It would be interesting to know if these gene\nchanges affect fitness, and especially longevity of infected\nmosquitoes. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Virus effects on sperm, body fluids.\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Lancet Infectious Diseases journal (edited)\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(17)30444-9/abstract) \nref: Joguet G, Mansuy JM, Matusali G, et al. Effect of acute Zika\nvirus infection on sperm and virus clearance in body fluids: a\nprospective observational study. Lancet Infect Dis. 2017. pii:\nS1473-3099(17)30444-9. doi: 10.1016/S1473-3099(17)30444-9\n-\nSummary\nBackground\nEvidence of human sexual transmission during Zika virus emergence is a\nmatter of concern, particularly in procreation, but to date, kinetics\nof seminal shedding and the effects of infection on human reproductive\nfunction have not been described. To investigate the effects of Zika\nvirus infection on semen and clearance of Zika virus from semen and\nbody fluids, we aimed to study a cohort of Zika virus-infected men. Methods\nThis prospective observational study recruited men presenting with\nacute Zika virus infection at Pointe-Ã -Pitre University Hospital in\nGuadeloupe, French Caribbean, where a Zika virus outbreak occurred\nbetween April and November, 2016. Blood, urine, and semen were\ncollected at days 7, 11, 20, 30, 60, 90, and 120 after symptom onset,\nand semen characteristics, such as total sperm count, sperm motility,\nvitality, and morphology, and reproductive hormone concentrations,\nsuch as testosterone, inhibin, follicle-stimulating hormone, and\nluteinising hormone, were assessed. At days 7, 11, and 20, semen was\nprocessed to isolate motile spermatozoa. Zika virus RNA was detected\nby RT-PCR using whole blood, serum, urine, seminal plasma, semen\ncells, and motile spermatozoa fractions. Zika virus was isolated from\ndifferent sperm fractions on Vero E6 cultures. Findings\n15 male volunteers (mean age 35 years SD 5; range 25-44) with acute\nZika virus infection and positive Zika virus RNA detection in blood or\nurine were enrolled. Total sperm count was decreased from median\n119âÃâ10^6 spermatozoa (IQR interquartile range 22-234)\nat day 7, to 45.2âÃâ10^6 (16.5-89.6) at day 30, and 70\nÃ 10^6 (28.5-81.4) at day 60, respectively, after Zika virus\ninfection. Inhibin values increased from 93.5 pg/mL (IQR 55-162) at\nday 7 to 150 pg/mL (78-209) at day 120 when total sperm count\nrecovered. In motile spermatozoa obtained after density gradient\nseparation, Zika virus RNA was found in 3 of 14 patients at day 7, 4\nof 15 at day 11, and 4 of 15 at day 20, and replication-competent\nvirus was found in the tested patient. Seminal shedding kinetics\nseemed heterogeneous among patients. Whole blood was the fluid most\nfrequently positive for Zika virus RNA (62 of 92 samples) and 3\npatients remained positive at day 120. Interpretation\nSemen alterations early after acute Zika virus infection might affect\nfertility and could be explained by virus effects on the testis and\nepididymis. Frequency of shedding and high viral load in semen,\ntogether with the presence of replicative virus in a motile\nspermatozoa fraction, can lead to Zika virus transmission during\nsexual contact and assisted reproduction procedures. Whole blood seems\nto be the best specimen for Zika virus RNA detection, diagnosis, and\nfollow-up. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall In a new study that included 12 men in French Guiana who had Zika\nvirus, 4 never had any detectable Zika in their semen, 1 excreted Zika\nvirus in his semen for at least 3 days, and 7 had Zika virus in semen\nfor at least 1 month. The maximum duration of detectable Zika in semen\nin the study was 45 days ((http://tinyurl.com/y9nhtgtk)). This report\nwas provided by Roland HÃ¼bner. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Vaccine update.\nDate: 22/29 Aug 2017.\nSource: Journal of the American Medical Association, JAMA (edited)\n(http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2649168) \nref: Lyon J. Vaccines protect fetus from Zika. JAMA. 2017; 318(8):\n689. doi:10.1001/jama.2017.11200\n-\nResearchers funded in part by the National Institutes of Health have\nrecently demonstrated that 2 experimental vaccines can restrict\ntransmission of Zika virus from pregnant mice to their fetuses,\nthereby shielding offspring from congenital damage or death. Multiple candidate Zika vaccines have been shown protective against\ninfection with the virus in animal studies, with several now in human\ntrials, but none were tested in the context of pregnancy, according to\nthe authors of the study published in Cell\n(http://www.cell.com/cell/fulltext/S0092-8674(17)30759-6). The 2\nvaccine candidates investigated in the new study are the 1st to\ndemonstrate efficacy in preventing vertical transmission of the virus\nand related fetal death in an animal model. Although the vaccines were\nadministered to female mice prior to pregnancy, the result is\nconsidered an important step toward developing a vaccine that could be\nsafely given to pregnant women. One of the 2 candidates is a modified messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine\nencoding Zika genes, developed by the biotechnology company Moderna.\nIt is already in safety trials in women who are not pregnant. The\nother is a live-attenuated Zika strain developed by researchers at the\nUniversity of Texas Medical Branch (UTMB). The testing was carried out by scientists from the National Institute\nof Allergy and Infectious Diseases, Washington University School of\nMedicine, and UTMB. The researchers 1st vaccinated the mice with 1 of\nthe vaccines or a placebo. After mating, the animals were challenged\nwith the virus 6 days into pregnancy. A week later, more than 50\npercent of placentas and fetuses from mice administered the mRNA\nvaccine had virtually no Zika RNA. The remainder had \"substantially\nlower\" levels relative to placebo.\nThe live vaccine provided broader protection: 78 percent of placentas\nand 83 percent of fetuses had Zika RNA at or below the level of\ndetection, while the placebo group exhibited significantly higher\nlevels of placental and fetal Zika RNA. Mice vaccinated with either\nvaccine had significantly higher rates of fetal viability; whereas 100\npercent of fetuses from mice vaccinated with the mRNA vaccine were\nborn, none survived to term in the placebo group. A working group funded by the Wellcome Trust recently approved ethical\nguidelines for testing such vaccines in pregnant women, normally\nexcluded from drug trials. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) It is reassuring to learn that at least 2 vaccines are now entering\nclinical trials in women. Although anti-Zika virus drugs are under\ndevelopment, preventing infection through vaccination seems to be the\nmost effective measure to prevent fetal infection and adverse effects\nof the virus infection in adults. - Mod.TY ","keywordsMatched":[]},"297":{"title":"Dengue/DHF update (11): Americas","date":["28","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Dengue/DHF update (11): Americas","summary":"\nDENGUE/DHF UPDATE (11): AMERICAS\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nCases in various countries:\nAmericas regional\n\nCases in various countries not mentioned above or more recent case\nnumbers. (conf.) 368 cases; Provinces most\naffected: Tumbes (84 cases), La Cruz y Zarumilla.\n(http://larepublica.pe/sociedad/892895-tumbes-certifican-368-casos-de-dengue-93-casos-de-chikungunya-y-106-de-leptospirosis)\n. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Mayotte":{},"Micronesia":{},"Moldova":{},"Monaco":{},"Mongolia":{"161":{"title":"Foot & mouth disease - Mongolia (03): (DG,\r\n\tDU) multiple species, st O, spread, OIE ","date":["30","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Foot & mouth disease - Mongolia (03): (DG,\r\n\tDU) multiple species, st O, spread, OIE [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Tue 29 Aug 2017. Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017; 30(35) http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=24685   Foot-and-mouth disease, Mongolia  Information received on and dated 29 Aug 2017 from Dr Battsengel Dambadarjaa, Chief Veterinary Officer, Veterinary and Animal Breeding Service, Ministry for Food and Agriculture, Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia  Summary Report type: follow-up report no. 3 Date of start of the event: 24 Jan 2017 Date of confirmation of the event: 28 Jan 2017 Report date: 29 Aug 2017 Date submitted to OIE: 29 Aug 2017 Reason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease Date of previous occurrence: 29 Aug 2016 Manifestation of disease: clinical disease Causal agent: Foot and mouth disease virus Serotype: O Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced) This event pertains to a defined zone within the country Related reports: immediate notification (13 Feb 2017) Follow-up report no. 1 (7 Apr 2017) Follow-up report no. 2 (27 Apr 2017) Follow-up report no. 3 (29 Aug 2017)  New outbreaks (4) Outbreak 1: Dosh, Zaraa bag, Altanshiree soum, Dornogovi Date of start of the outbreak: 22 Apr 2017 Outbreak status: resolved (19 Jun 2017) Epidemiological unit: farm Affected animals Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered Cattle / - / 127 / 0 / 127 / 0  Epidemiology Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive  Control measures Measures applied: movement control inside the country; screening; quarantine; stamping out; zoning; disinfection; no treatment of affected animals; vaccination in response to the outbreak(s): - Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.  The location of these outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  As reported in EUFMD's most recent Global FMD situation report (July 2017), the WRLFMD at Pirbright has sequenced a field isolate received there from Mongolia (O/MOG/10/2017), genotyped as 'O/ME-SA/PanAsia'. The Mongolian virus was subjected to vaccine matching strain differentiation (VMSD) test, with the following results: \"good matching results with O/TUR/5/2009 but not with O 3039 and Manisa\". It will be interesting to note if the vaccine applied in Mongolia has been selected according to the said VMSD test results. The genotyping results above are not yet available on the WRLFMD website.  An OIE interactive map showing the locations of the 20 FMDV-O outbreaks reported from Mongolia since the start of the event (20 Jan 2017) is available at (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=22811).  According to Mongolia's National Broadcast, dated 30 Aug 2017 (machine-translated from (https://www.mnb.mn/i/121355)), FMD is also circulating in the eastern province (aimag) of Sukhbaatar, as well as the central province of Tuv (Tov), and in 2 districts (soums) (Songino Khairkhan and Khan-Uul) of the Mongolian capital of Ulaanbaatar. This presents a spread of the virus westwards, not yet reported to the OIE (map at (http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Mongolia.gif)).  The media report also includes the following data on vaccination: \"The vaccination program was implemented from 11 Aug 2017 in 934 427 livestock . Currently, vaccinations of 750 363 heads of livestock in 6 districts are being implemented, of which 83.7 percent have already been completed.\" It is not clear if the said vaccinations cover also the recently infected central regions. - Mod.AS  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1). Sri Lanka has now notified 107 015 cases,\nwhich WHO estimates is 4.3 times more than the average number of cases\nusually reported (http://tinyurl.com/ycvszzs8). - National. 19 Aug 2017. Since the beginning of 2017, Sri Lanka has\nreported 137 279 suspected dengue cases and more than 300 deaths.\nAbout 44.5 per cent of dengue cases were reported from the Western\nprovince. This compares with about 39 000 cases reported from January\nto August 2016, and 55 150 cases during the entire year 2016.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-updates-vietnam-sri-lanka-32087/) - National. 25 Aug 2017. Through Fri 25 Aug 2017, Sri Lanka has\nofficially reported 144 052 cases and, as of 3 Aug 2017, 3327 people\nhave died.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-epidemic-waning-sri-lanka-university-jaffna-science-faculty-closed-september-83024/) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Sri Lanka can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/144). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ India\n- National. 31 Jul 2017. 11 832 more cases than in 2016 and 46 deaths,\n11 more than in 2016. The total has risen to 28 702, with 2536 cases\nand 10 deaths last week week of 24 Jul 2017. Kerala reported the\nmaximum dengue cases with 13 913 cases, followed by Tamil Nadu with\n5474 cases, Karnataka with 4186 cases, Andhra Pradesh with 798 cases,\nWest Bengal with 571 cases, and Maharashtra with 460 cases.\n(http://www.india.com/news/agencies/dengue-cases-in-india-up-by-11832-over-last-year-2366955/) - Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Assam. 21 Aug 2017. Floods continued to wreak\nhavoc in the 3 states, which reported 88 more dengue-related deaths.\nOfficials said 33 more dengue-related deaths had been reported in\nUttar Pradesh over the last 2 days.\n(http://www.christianmessenger.in/floods-in-bihar-up-assam-88-die-in-dengue-related-deaths/) - Delhi. 31 Jul 2017. As of 29 Jul 2017, 180 cases of dengue (monsoon\narrived early).\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/delhi/882984/dengue-malaria-chikungunya-cases-on-the-rise-in-delhi/) - Tamil Nadu (Coimbatore). 4 Aug 2017. Deaths rise to 16 in last 2\nmonths; new admissions increasing.\n(http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/2-more-dengue-deaths-in-coimbatore-total-deaths-now-16-117080401128_1.html) - Tamil Nadu. 11 Aug 2017. Prevalence of dengue in Tamil Nadu is\ndecreasing. So far, 5000 people have been affected and due to proper\ntreatment by doctors in government and private hospitals, almost all\ndengue patients have been saved, health minister C Vijaya Baskar said\ntoday 11 Aug 2017.\n(http://www.dnaindia.com/\nhealth/report-prevalence-of-dengue-in-tn-down-health-minister-2526936) - Tamil Nadu (Chennai). 18 Aug 2017. At least 1500 new cases in 10\ndays. Neighbouring state, Kerala, which has recorded the highest\nnumber of dengue cases with around 15 612 cases and 25 deaths, is\nanother reason for several districts of Tamil Nadu such as Coimbatore,\nMadurai, Theni, Toothukudi, and Virudhunagar facing its brunt.\n(http://www.deccanchronicle.com/nation/current-affairs/180817/more-rains-more-cases-of-dengue.html) - Tamil Nadu (Chennai). 4 Aug 2017. 5 new positive cases every day\nnow; around 100 cases of 'suspicious fever' reported. 629 cases in\nJuly 2017 alone, according to National Vector Borne Diseases Control\nProgramme.\n(http://www.deccanchronicle.com/lifestyle/health-and-wellbeing/040817/dengue-breeds-in-north-chennai.html) - Kerala. 31 Jul 2017. Over 6000 patients have been confirmed and\ntreated as in-patients; mortality has been kept to 1 per cent.\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/thiruvananthapuram/882347/mch-keeps-dengue-mortality-rate-to-1/#) - Karnataka (Gulbarga). 4 Aug 2017. 235 cases in Gulbarga district\nfrom January to July 2017. Of the 235, 171 cases were reported from\nKalaburagi taluk sub district alone, 32 from Chincholli taluk, 13\nfrom Chittapur taluk, 4 cases each from Afzalpur, Aland, and Sedam\ntaluks, and 3 cases from Jewargi taluk.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-karnataka/235-dengue-cases-in-kalaburagi-dist/article19423638.ece) - Karnataka (Gulbarga). 23 Aug 2017. A total of 474 confirmed cases in\nGulbarga district, with 1927 suspected cases; 368 cases confirmed in\nKalaburagi sub district. Only 43 cases were reported in the district\ntill the end of June 2017 and 191 cases were reported between 1 and\n10 Aug 2017, while 240 new cases have been registered, taking the\ntotal to 474.\n(http://www.uniindia.com/dengue-474-confirmed-cases-reported-in-kalaburagi-district/health-and-medicine/fullstory/968353.html) - Karnataka. 18 Aug 2017. Nearly 8000 cases in Karnataka so far in\n2017. Kerala has reported 16 000 cases and Tamil Nadu 9500 cases.\nDengue spreads easily between the 3 adjacent states.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/karnataka/central-team-to-review-dengue-outbreak-in-state/article19512224.ece) - West Bengal (Kolkata). 12 Aug 2017. Dengue scare at RG Kar Hospital\nMedical College hostel; at least 8 test positive over the last week.\nIn 2015, more than 30 were affected in the hostel campus and one died.\nOn 2016 too, more than a dozen inmates were affected.\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/dengue-scare-at-rg-kar-hostel-8-test-positive/articleshow/60029232.cms) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nAnirban Ghosh\nKasturba Medical College\n(m_anirbanghosh@hotmail.com) - West Bengal (Birbhum). 21 Aug 2017. At least 100 cases dengue have\nbeen reported from West Bengal's Birbhum district. \"We have received\nreports of at least 100 cases of dengue since 23 Jul 2017. While\nabout 60 of these cases are from the Dubrajpur town in the district's\nSuri Sadar sub-division, the rest are from other areas such as Bolpur\nand Rampurhat towns. But no one has died so far,\" the chief medical\nofficer of Birbhum, Himadri Ari, told The Hindu.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/bengal-records-100-dengue-cases/article19535541.ece) - West Bengal (Siliguri). 23 Aug 2017. The number of people suffering\nfrom dengue is rising at an alarming rate in Siliguri. According to\nrecords, the highest number of dengue cases reported was 54. This year\n2017, the mark has been crossed.\n(http://siliguritimes.com/number-dengue-patients-rise-siliguri/) - Odisha (Ganjam). 22 Jul 2017. Blood samples of 116 people of the\ndistrict were recently tested and 4 dengue positive cases were\ndetected. Disinfecting water bodies in the district has already\nstarted and a 3-member team has been entrusted with spreading\nawareness on dengue in the district.\n(http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/odisha/2017/jul/22/4-found-dengue-positive-in-odishas-ganjam-district-1632062.html) - Odisha. 18 Aug 2017. 402 cases and 2 deaths. Last year 2016 4348\npersons were tested positive for the dengue virus by this period with\n8 deaths. Out of total 402 infected persons, 67 were tested positive\nin Bhadrak district, 61 in Cuttack district, and 59 in Balasore\ndistrict. Similarly, 35 people have been infected in Khordha, 34 in\nJajpur, 24 in Puri, 20 in Jagatsinghpur . Meanwhile, Kendrapara has\nregistered 20, Ganjam 13, Keonjhar 10, Dhenkanal 11, Bolangir 6, and\nMayurbhanj 5 cases of dengue. While Nayagarh, Sonepur, Kalahandi,\nAngul, and Bargarh registered 3 cases each, Nuapada and Kandhamal\nwitnessed 2 cases. Boudh, Rayagada, Sundargarh and Deogarh districts\nrecorded with single case each. However, 12 patients have come to the\nstate from neighbouring states.\n(http://pragativadi.com/dengue-claims-two-lives-affects-402-odisha/) - Gujarat (Ahmedabad). 1 Aug 2017. A total of 59 cases in July 2017.\nThe actual number of cases is said to be 'far more'; it takes at least\n15 days to confirm cases.\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/59-dengue-cases-in-july-amc/articleshow/59853414.cms) - Jharkhand (Jamshedpur). 30 Jul 2017. 75 positive cases in Kolhan and\nadjoining area of Jamshedpur.\n(http://www.avenuemail.in/jamshedpur/dengue-cases-rise-positive-cases-shoot-75-kolhan/111026/) - Telangana (Hyderabad). 25 Jul 2017. All 4 dengue serotypes are\npresent this year 2017. A total of 15 samples found to be\nco-infected. In an earlier study done in New Delhi, such multiple\ndengue serotype infections were reported in only 19 per cent of cases.\nAll 4 dengue serotypes were detected in almost equal number in blood\nsamples, unlike in an earlier study conducted in New Delhi wherein one\nserotype was found to be dominating. This has been indicated as a\npossible reason for the high prevalence of infection due to more than\none dengue serotype. Another finding of concern is that DEN-4 strain,\nresembling the one detected in Pune in 2009, was detected in as many\nas 11 samples. DEN-4 is associated with unusual symptoms like\nrespiratory distress, pleural effusion, and elevated levels of liver\nenzymes. Also, detection of a DEN-1 strain found closely related to a\nstrain from Thailand detected in 1980 that causes high severity\ninfection has been reported. Dr Musturi Venkataramana, assistant\nprofessor of biotechnology of UoH, who led the study, said, \"When a\nperson is infected with more than one serotype of dengue, it may lead\nto dengue haemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome which can cause\nsevere health problems, and even death. Finding 45 per cent patients\nwith such infections is worrisome.\"\n(http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/hyderabad/2017/jul/25/all-four-dengue-serotypes-prevalent-in-city-1633171.html) Maps of India can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Pakistan\n- Sindh (Karachi). 8 Aug 2017. 422 dengue fever cases have been\nreported in Sindh province so far in 2017, out of them 410 were\nreported in Karachi, 5 in Hyderabad, 5 in Tharparkar/Mithi, and 2 in\nUmerkot. As per a weekly report issued by Prevention and Control\nProgram for Dengue in Sindh, as many as 27 new dengue fever cases\nsurfaced in the city from 1 to 7 Aug 2017.\n(http://www.brecorder.com/2017/08/08/363624/a27-more-dengue-cases-surface-in-karachi/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 8 Aug 2017. 3rd death due to dengue\nhemorrhagic fever and encephalitis. Most of the affected patients were\nbrought from the Tehkal Payan area from where water samples have been\ncollected to determine the situation.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1476245/third-dengue-death-\nreported-k-p/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 16 Aug 2017. The number of dengue\npatients in the city has reached 600 in almost a month. Most of the\ncases are from Tehkal, the rear of which is a rural area, where there\nis a large number of automobile repair shops. The water kept in open\ncontainers to wash tyres and for other related work serves as the\nbreeding ground for mosquitoes that transmit dengue.\nAs per the administration of Khyber Teaching Hospital, 5 of the\npatients brought to the facility since June 2017 have succumbed to\nthe dengue virus.\n(https://www.geo.tv/latest/153878-peshawar-admin-busy-in-photo-shoot-as-dengue-cases-soar-to-600) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 22 Aug 2017. An investigation report\nby WHO on the dengue outbreak in Peshawar has revealed that the\npresence of a huge number of uncovered water containers used in houses\nand at workshops is the main reason for the outbreak. Following the\ncases reported from Peshawar, a 5-member WHO team moved to the city to\ninvestigate the reasons behind the dengue epidemic. The team collected\nsamples from 2 main areas  Tehkal and Gujran Muhalla. The report\nrevealed that 87 per cent of the samples collected from 23 water\ncontainers in the Civil Dispensary area of Tehkal tested positive for\ndengue virus. Similarly, 79 per cent of the total 19 samples of water\ncontainers in Gujran Muhallah also tested positive.\nThe data compiled by the WHO team, the total number of reported cases\nexceeded 4320 which were screened for dengue in the Khyber Teaching\nHospital from 14 Jun to 17 Aug 2017. A total of 699 people tested\npositive for dengue, of which 5 have died. Of the total patients\nscreened, 325 were admitted to the hospital while 200 were discharged.\nBy 17 Aug 2017, a total of 120 patients were admitted to the facility.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1487967/reveals-water-storage-containers-behind-dengue-surge-peshawar/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 24 Aug 2017. Dengue continues in\nPeshawar, claiming 7 lives with 69 new cases reported from different\nareas of the city during the last 24 hours, raising the number of\ntotal cases to 1703. So far, he said, 7 deaths including 6 from Khyber\nTeaching Hospital and one in Hayatabad Medical Complex were reported\nfrom dengue epidemics in Peshawar. Out of 69 new cases, 41 were\nreported in Khyber Teaching Hospital (KTH), 13 in Hayatabad Medical\nComplex (HMC), 12 in Lady Reading Hospital (LRH), and 3 in Naseerullah\nKhan Babar Teaching Hospital (NBTH), Peshawar, he said. A rapid\nresponse team has also been set up with mandate to swiftly reach to\nthe affected areas from where new cases were surfaced besides helping\nthe field staff in conduct of fumigation spray, removal of larvae, and\nprovision of other necessary medicines.\n(https://dnd.com.pk/dengue-rampage-in-peshawar-kills-seven-69-new-cases-surface/133250) Maps of Pakistan can be seen at\n(http://pakistanmap.facts.co/pakistanmapof/PakistanAdministrativeMap.jpg)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ China\n- Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region ex Viet Nam (susp). 16 Aug 2017.\nGuangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in south China has reported its 1st\nimported dengue case this year 2017, local inspection and quarantine\nbureau said. The man had stayed in Hanoi, Viet Nam, for 2 months but\ndenied having been bitten by mosquitoes or having any infectious\ndisease.\n(http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-08/16/c_136531179.htm) - Hong Kong SAR Special Administrative Region. 9 Aug 2017. 1st\nlocally transmitted case of dengue in Hong Kong, this year 2017.\n(https://today.mims.com/topic/chp-investigates-first-local-dengue-fever-case-of-the-year) - Macau SAR. 1 Aug 2017. 1st locally acquired case this year 2017\nconfirmed. 53 imported cases in 2017, including 18 from Thailand, 10\nfrom Sri Lanka, and 7 from the Philippines.\n(https://macaunews.mo/first-local-dengue-case-year-confirmed/) - Macau SAR. 24 Aug 2017. A 48 year old domestic worker from the\nPhilippines is now in hospital after health authorities confirmed she\nhas dengue fever; the 7th imported case reported in Macau this year\n2017.\n(http://menafn.com/1095765055/Tests-show-that-Filipino-maid-in-Macau-has-dengue-fever) Maps of China can be seen at (http://www.sacu.org/maps/provmap.png)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/155). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Taiwan. 3 Aug 2017. 2 more indigenous dengue fever cases have been\nconfirmed in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, making that 3 cases this\nyear, said a statement issued by Kaohsiung City's Department of Health\non Thu 3 Aug 2017. The 3 cases were all members of the same family,\nhusband, wife and son, who lived together in the southern Taiwanese\nport city, according to the department. The 3 have recovered\n(http://focustaiwan.tw/news/asoc/201708030028.aspx) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Taiwan can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/193). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Myanmar\n- National. 1 Aug 2017. From 1 Jan to 22 Jul 2017, 14 919 cases and 81\ndeaths of dengue recorded. Most of the deaths were from Ayeyarwady\nregion, followed by Yangon and Bago regions. The current reported\ncases are higher than those of 2016, yet still lower than that of\n2015, according to Dr Zaw Lin, dengue program manager of Ministry of\nHealth and Sports. In Rakhine State, about 1800 people are infected\nand 18 died from the infection. High occurrence was observed in\nMinbya, Sittwe, and Toungup townships. The majority of the deaths aged\nunder 5 and 2 adults (over 40 and 60 years old) also died of dengue,\naccording to Dr San Kyawt Khine, assistant director of State Public\nHealth Department. Only over 1500 cases were identified during 2014 in\nRakhine State.\n(http://www.thithtoolwin.com/2017/08/blog-post_23.html) in Myanmar,\ntrans. Mod.YMA, edited - Kayah. 3 Aug 2017. 370 cases as of 27 Jul 2017, 1 death. June 2017. Suzuki T, Kutsuna S, Taniguchi S,\net al. Dengue virus exported from Côte d'Ivoire to Japan, June 2017.\nEmerg Infect Dis. 2017 date cited.\nAbstract. Since April 2017, a dengue fever outbreak has been ongoing\nin Côte d'Ivoire. We diagnosed dengue fever (type 2 virus) in a\ntraveler returning to Japan from Côte d'Ivoire. Phylogenetic analysis\nrevealed strain homology with the Burkina Faso 2016 strain. On 6 May 2017, the Ministry of Health\n(MoH) of Côte d'Ivoire WHO of a dengue fever outbreak in Abidjan, the\ncapital city of Côte d'Ivoire. Suspected cases of dengue were first\nreported on 22 Apr 2017 and confirmed by the Institut Pasteur de Côte\nd'Ivoire (IPCI) laboratory on 28 Apr 2017. As of 11 Jul 2017, a total\nof 623 suspected cases including 2 deaths (case fatality rate: 0.3 per\ncent) have been reported. A total of 192 cases have been confirmed by\nPCR, of which 66 per cent were dengue virus serotype 2 (DENV-2), 29\nper cent were DENV-3, and 5 per cent were DENV-1. In addition, 90\nsamples were confirmed IgM positive by serology. The majority of cases\nhave been reported from Abidjan city. Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted for 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. The general trend of suspected cases of dengue fever\nis increasing. From 27 Jun to 4 Jul 2017, 37 new cases were reported\nand from 4 to 11 Jul 2017, 142 new suspected cases were reported. A\ntotal of 27 per cent of the suspected cases are aged between 15 and 29\nyears old, 55 per cent are 30 years old and above. 54 per cent of the\ncases are female. Coinfection with yellow fever was suspected in 68\ncases and confirmed in one case. Further laboratory confirmation is\nongoing.\n(http://www.who.int/csr/don/04-august-2017-dengue-cote-d-ivoire/en/) - Côte d'Ivoire. 8 Aug 2017. Ivory Coast continues to affect multiple\nregions: 623 cases by mid July serotype DEN-2 (66 per cent), and DEN-3\n(29 per cent). Ninety cases were also confirmed positive for\nimmunoglobulin M (IgM), an antibody produced in the body as an immune\nresponse to dengue infection. According to WHO, the majority of cases\nhave appeared in Abidjan City, while the Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. Additionally, the general trend of suspected cases of\ndengue fever has been increasing, growing from 37 new cases from 27\nJun to 4 Jul to 142 new suspected cases appearing from 4 to 11 Jul\n2017.\n(https://homelandprepnews.com/ stories/23646-dengue-outbreak-\nivory-coast-continues- increase-according-world-\nhealth-organization/) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Côte d'Ivoire can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/52). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Research\n- Viral persistence, organ transplant-related transmission.\nDate: Sun 13 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Star Online (edited)\n(http://tinyurl.com/yd4vv2bj) \nThere is now a concern that the dengue virus can reside in the body\neven after one has recovered and the virus is non-detectable in the\nblood, said a well-known dengue scientist. This came about after 2\nkidney recipients in Taiwan were diagnosed with dengue 2 days after\nreceiving a kidney each from the same donor, said National Cheng Kung\nUniversity microbiology and immunology professor Dr Oscar Perng\nGuey-chuen. \"This indicates a potential risk,\" the Taiwan-based\nscientist said, adding that no dengue virus was detected in the\ndonor's blood. He said the donor contracted dengue in 2015 and in mid-2016, he died\nin an accident. His family donated his corneas, liver, heart, and\nkidneys. Both patients had the same strain of the dengue virus the\ndonor had in 2015 and one of the recipients died of dengue\nhaemorrhagic fever, he said. Asked where the virus could be hiding since it could not be detected\nin the blood, he said it was a question scientists are trying to\nanswer. Interestingly, those who received the donor's corneas, liver,\nand heart did not develop dengue, Dr Perng said on the sidelines of\nthe National Dengue And Arboviruses Infection Conference 2017\nyesterday 12 Aug 2017. He said although there was not enough\nevidence to show the virus came from the donor as the kidneys were not\ntested for dengue before the transplant, the same virus was found in\nthe patients' bodies after that. Dr Perng said his team had studied mice for dengue virus in the blood\ntestes, kidney, liver, spleen and brain, and found the virus present\nin the kidneys and brain. \"We believe the virus probably resided in\nthe kidneys and was not cleared by the body,\" he said, adding that the\nvirus could have been activated after transplant. He said this raised\nconcerns about asymptomatic people who are dengue carriers. Health Ministry deputy director, general Datuk Dr S Jeyaindran said\npatients with severe dengue would have better recovery if they were\ngiven colloids, a more concentrated fluid, at the early stage in fluid\nmanagement for dengue patients. Dr Jeyaindran, who was representing\nHealth Minister Datuk Seri Dr S Subramaniam, said colloids may be\nintroduced at an earlier stage, instead of saline because it has not\nbeen successful in treating patients with severe dengue. He said more\nstudies will be conducted to find out at which stage the colloids\nshould be given. byline: Loh Foon Fong \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Air travel related spread of dengue.\nDate: Thu 3 Aug 2017.\nSource: Medical Xpress (edited)\n(https://medicalxpress.com/news/2017-08-air-responsible-dengue-asia.html) \nWhile the incidences of many other infectious diseases have declined\nover the past decade, the number of cases and outbreaks of dengue\nvirus have continued to increase. The spread of dengue to new areas is\nlikely due in large part to trends in air travel, researchers now\nreport in PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases. Dengue virus affects as estimated 390 million people around the globe\neach year, and can cause symptoms ranging from a mild fever and\nheadache to severe low blood pressure. The virus has mostly caused\ndisease in tropical and subtropical areas of the world, but a 2014\noutbreak in Japan broke that pattern. Overall, the geographic area\naffected by dengue has been growing in recent years. In the new work, Huaiyu Tian and Bing Xu, both of Beijing Normal\nUniversity, China, together with colleagues from the University of\nOxford and elsewhere analyzed the spread of dengue viruses in Asia\nfrom 1956 to 2015. They used 2202 genetic sequences of dengue viruses,\ncollected in 20 countries or regions of Asia over the 59 years, to\ndetermine how different strains were related. They also investigated\ntrends in air travel, maritime mobility, migration, and\nsocio-economics to determine what factors impact the spread of\ndengue. The spread of 3 different dengue virus serotypes, DENV-1, -2, and -3,\nis associated with air traffic more so than any other factors, the\ndata revealed. Air traffic hubs such as Thailand and India, the\nresearchers found, help seed dengue epidemics, while China, Cambodia,\nIndonesia, and Singapore help diffuse the virus to other Asian\ncountries. \"Future trends in global mobility could potentially accelerate the\nappearance and diffusion of DENV worldwide,\" the researchers say.\n\"Prevention and control of dengue epidemics requires a better\nunderstanding of its mode of geographic dissemination, especially for\ncountries in the tropics.\" Reference: Tian H, Sun Z, Faria NR, et al. Increasing airline travel\nmay facilitate co-circulation of multiple dengue virus serotypes in\nAsia. PLoS Negl Trop Dis. 2017; 11(8): e0005694;\n(http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0005694) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Visual impact.\nDate: Fri 25 Aug 2017.\nSource: NYOOOZ, The Indian Express report (edited)\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/delhi/902768/drop-in-vision-traced-to-inflammation-caused-by-dengue-fever-say-doctors/) \nIn a rare symptom of dengue, a 20 year old in the capital developed\n\"ophthalmic complications\" due to which she complained of a \"drop in\nvision\". Typical symptoms of dengue range from sore throat, cough,\njoint pain, and rashes. Sir Gangaram Hospital reported the rare case,\nwhere the woman, who went to the eye OPD outpatient department,\ncomplained of \"sudden blurring of vision in the left eye,\" as reported\nby IE Indian Express. According to the newspaper, doctors eventually discovered that the\ndrop in vision was due to \"inflammation of blood vessels in the\nretina\", as a result of dengue fever. The woman had earlier tested\npositive for the vectorborne disease. \"The patient tested positive for\ndengue and had fever for the past 8 days. She did not have any rashes\non her body, or any other systemic manifestation.\" \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> WHO update.\nDate: The 15 Aug 2017.\nSource: WHO Western Pacific region (edited)\n(http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/dengue_biweekly_20170815.pdf) \nDengue situation update no. 523\n-\nNorthern hemisphere\n-\nCambodia\nAs of 8 Aug 2017, a total of 1604 suspected dengue fever cases were\nreported in 2017. There is a\ndownward trend in the number of reported cases since week 16 (week\nending 22 Apr 2017). \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Namibia":{},"Nauru":{},"Nepal":{"137":{"title":"Scrub typhus - Nepal (09): (KT) urban cases ","date":["30","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Scrub typhus - Nepal (09): (KT) urban cases [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Wed 30 Aug 2017. From: Sher Bahadur Pun (drsherbdr@yahoo.com) (edited)   During a 2-week period (15 through 29 Aug 2017), at least 86 scrub typhus (ST) cases (including 9 children) have been identified by laboratory testing at Sukraraj Tropical & Infectious Disease Hospital (STIDH). Majority of these patients are being treated in different hospitals in Kathmandu. 9 children with laboratory confirmed ST received treatment at STIDH and recovered uneventfully.  It is quite surprising for me observing such a large number of ST cases being detected in Kathmandu, the biggest and most densely populated area of Nepal. Because ST has previously been almost exclusively detected in rural areas of Nepal. What is not yet clear is the impact of ST between the years 2004 and 2015. ST was first well documented in 2004 in Kathmandu (1), while the significant number of ST cases has only been detected since 2015.  The widespread use of antibiotics, such as ciprofloxacin, could be one possible explanation. In other words, healthcare workers in Nepal usually view any fever as typhoid fever, thus used to treat febrile patients with ciprofloxacin, which might have also worked simultaneously against ST too. However, nowadays, cefixime has become the drug of choice for typhoid fever, and it may, however, not work effectively against ST, resulting in emergence of ST in Nepal.  Reference  1. Murdoch DR, Woods CW, Zimmerman MD et al. The etiology of febrile illness in adults presenting to Patan Hospital in Kathmandu. Nepal. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 2004; 70(6): 670-5; (http://tinyurl.com/ybyfpqyx).   Dr Sher Bahadur Pun, MD, PhD Clinical Research Unit Sukraraj Tropical and Infectious Disease Hospital Kathmandu Nepal (drsherbdr@yahoo.com)  ProMED-mail thanks Dr Sher Bahadur Pun for his continued contributions on scrub typhus in Nepal.  Doxycycline is the drug of choice and it is preferred over other tetracyclines for treatment of scrub typhus; it is rarely associated with staining of teeth in children younger than 8 years (1). Macrolides, such as azithromycin, are also reported to be efficacious (2). Fluoroquinolones, such as ciprofloxacin and ofloxacin, have been reported to be clinically effective in the treatment of scrub typhus in a few patients. However, some clinical studies suggest that fluoroquinolones are not as effective in patients with scrub typhus as other antibiotics (3,4).  In vitro testing of some strains of _Orientia tsutsugamushi_, the cause of scrub typhus, has been reported to show resistance to ciprofloxacin and ofloxacin (minimum inhibitory concentration=8 micrograms/mL) (5) and mutation in the quinolone resistance-determining region (QRDR) of the gyrA gene associated with fluoroquinolone resistance has been found (3,5).  These findings suggest that fluoroquinolones are likely not appropriate for the treatment of scrub typhus.  References - 1. Panpanich R, Garner P. Antibiotics for treating scrub typhus. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2000; (2): CD002150. Available at (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10796680). 2. Kim YS, Yun HJ, Shim SK, et al. A comparative trial of a single dose of azithromycin versus doxycycline for the treatment of mild scrub typhus. Clin Infect Dis. 2004; 39(9): 1329-35 Epub 2004 Oct 11. Available at (https://academic.oup.com/cid/article-lookup/doi/10.1086/425008). 3. Jang HC, Choi SM, Jang MO, et al. Maps of Nepal can be seen at (http://tinyurl.com/ydf8ojtj) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2877). - Mod.ML  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Netherlands":{},"New Caledonia":{"182":{"title":"Invasive mosquito - New Caledonia (02): comment ","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Invasive mosquito - New Caledonia (02): comment [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Thu 31 Aug 2017. From: Michael J. Bangs (mbangs@fmi.com) (edited)   It stands to reason that the presence of _Anopheles farauti_ as the new entrant into New Caledonia is presumably recent. The nearest neighbor is Vanuatu, a malaria-endemic country that has but one anopheline species present in that island group, _Anopheles farauti_ sensu stricto, an effective malaria vector provided you add _Plasmodium_ to the mix.  _Anopheles farauti_ is one member of 8 known sibling species in the _Farauti_ Complex (closely related species that are morphologically identical, thus confounding accurate identification without the use of molecular techniques). It is by far the most widely distributed species in the complex in the southwest Pacific region (Maluku island group, eastern Indonesia to northern Australia, PNG, Solomon Islands and Vanuatu). The species' ability to inhabit brackish water environments (predominantly a coastal inhabitant) has aided in its dispersal throughout the region.  The origin of the anopheline population in New Caledonia might remain a mystery, but this discovery is of concern. If the area of establishment is relatively confined, it might be possible to eliminate this species before it extends further into the country. Foremost, identify the species.   Michael J. Bangs, MSPH, PhD. Public Health & Malaria Control International SOS Kuala Kencana, Papua, Indonesia (mbangs@fmi.com)  ProMED thanks Dr. Bangs for his comments.  The _Anopheles_ reported in the previous posting was found in an area of La Tontouta, north of Noumea. One hopes that the area of discovery is small enough to permit control.  Maps of New Caledonia can be accessed at (https://media1.britannica.com/eb-media/93/3293-004-8AA31F9B.jpg) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/459). - Mod.TY  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"New Zealand":{"150":{"title":"Mycoplasma bovis, bovine - New Zealand (04) ","date":["29","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Mycoplasma bovis, bovine - New Zealand (04) [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Tue 29 Aug 2017 13:01 NZST. Source: The Business Times (edited) (http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/consumer/3-more-nz-farms-test-positive-for-cattle-disease)   A serious bacterial cattle disease has been identified at 3 more farms in New Zealand, raising the number of affected farms to 6, the country's Ministry for Primary Industries (MPI) said on Tue 29 Aug 2017.  Two of the farms that reported positive results for the _Mycoplasma bovis_ disease belong to the Van Leeuwen Dairy Group, which also owns the 1st 2 farms to report the bacteria in July 2017.  The owner of the 3rd unnamed farm in the country's South Island had received a small number of calves from another infected farm, the ministry said in an emailed statement. \"We fully expect to find more infected properties as we continue our tracing and testing programme,\" MPI Response Coordinator David Yard said, adding that there was no evidence the disease was spreading without close contact to infected animals.  _Mycoplasma bovis_ is common in many countries and can lead to conditions such as udder infection, pneumonia, and arthritis in affected cattle, but does not pose a food safety risk or any risk to humans.  News of the outbreak in July 2017 briefly knocked the New Zealand currency given the importance of the cattle industry to the economy, with dairy the country's largest export good.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  We know the MPI is investigating how this pathogen got into the country. This particular pathogen causes a variety of clinical signs from respiratory, to arthritis, and mastitis and can be difficult to diagnose. It can be an aggressive pathogen, therefore it is not unexpected that MPI has found, and expects to find more cases of this disease. - Mod.TG  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164).  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Nicaragua":{},"Niger":{},"Nigeria":{"158":{"title":"Poliomyelitis update (23): global (Syria, Pakistan, DR Congo)\r\n\tWPV1, cVDPV2 ","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Poliomyelitis update (23): global (Syria, Pakistan, DR Congo)\r\n\tWPV1, cVDPV2 [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  In this update: <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Global - Polio Eradication Initiative <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Syria - WHO Situation Report   <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Global - Polio Eradication Initiative. Date: Thu 31 Aug 2017. Source: Global Polio Eradication Initiative (edited) (http://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/this-week/)   Poliovirus weekly update 30-Aug-2017, World Health Organization  New wild poliovirus cases reported this week: 0 Total number of wild poliovirus cases in 2017: 9 Total number of wild poliovirus cases in 2016: 37  New cVDPV cases reported this week: 7 Total number of cVDPV cases in 2017: 47 Total number of cVDPV cases in 2016: 5  Headlines  - Pakistan and Afghanistan polio eradication teams convened last week in Islamabad to follow up on the southern corridor (Quetta Block - Greater Kandahar) joint planning for the upcoming low transmission season. The meeting was attended by the national teams as well as the staff from the southern region of Afghanistan and Balochistan province of Pakistan.  - Summary of newly-reported viruses this week: Pakistan: 2 new wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) environmental positive samples; Syria: 6 new circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) cases; and, DR Congo: 1 new cVDPV2 case. Additionally, pre-notification was received this week of a new WPV1 case from Karachi, Pakistan, the 1st in Karachi since January 2016. The case will be officially reflected in next week's global data reporting.  Afghanistan  - No new wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) cases were reported in the past week. The total number of WPV1 cases for 2017 remains 6. The most recent case in the country had onset of paralysis on 10 Jul 2017, from Zabul province, neighbouring Kandahar province and Pakistan. - Preparations continue for a targeted vaccination round in the southern region of the country, scheduled on 11 Sep 2017  Pakistan  - No new wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) case was reported in the past week; the total number of WPV1 cases for 2017 remains 3. The most recent case in the country had onset of paralysis on 11 Jun 2017, from Killa Abdullah, Balochistan. - Two new wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) environmental positive samples were reported in the past week, from Karachi, Sindh (collected on 7 and 12 Aug 2017). - Additionally, pre-notification was received this week of a new WPV1 case from Karachi, Pakistan. The case will be officially reflected in next week's global data reporting. Karachi had previously been a key reservoir for WPV1 in Pakistan. Analysis is ongoing to determine the origin of this latest case and a response is being planned. The case had onset of paralysis on 11 Aug 2017. The last previous case from Karachi is from January 2016. - The National Task Force for Polio Eradication convened last week, chaired by the Prime Minister of Pakistan and attended by the senior leadership from the national and provincial levels. The Task force reviewed the revised National Emergency Action Plan 2017/18 and discussed mechanisms of accelerating the implementation of strategies to stop WPV1 transmission in the key hot spots. - Under the National Emergency Action Plan for polio eradication, the country is planning to implement 2 nation-wide and 2 sub-national vaccination rounds from September to December 2017.  Nigeria - - No new cases of wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) were reported in the past week. The total number of WPV1 cases for 2016 remains 4 and no cases have been reported in 2017. The most recent case had onset of paralysis on 21 Aug 2016 in Monguno Local Government Area (LGA), Borno. - Nigeria continues to implement emergency response to the detected WPV1 strain and cVDPV2 strains affecting the country (last detected in 2016). - Detection of the polio cases in Nigeria underscores the risk posed by low-level undetected transmission and the urgent need to strengthen subnational surveillance.  Lake Chad Basin  - The detection of wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) (Borno, Nigeria in 2016) and cVDPV2 (Borno and Sokoto provinces in Nigeria in 2016) continue to pose a risk to the neighbouring countries of the Lake Chad basin and hence an outbreak response plan is being implemented as part of the response to the Nigeria outbreak. - Emergency outbreak response efforts continue across the Lake Chad basin, together with activities to fill subnational surveillance gaps across the region.  Central Africa  - One new case of cVDPV2 was reported in the past week in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DR Congo), from Haut Lomami province, with onset of paralysis on 20 Jun 2017. The total number of cVDPV2 cases this year 2017 is now 8, in 2 separate outbreaks: in Haut Lomami province (6 cases, with onset of paralysis of the most recent case on 20 Jun 2017); and in Maniema province (2 cases with onset of paralysis on 26 Mar 2017 and 18 Apr 2017, with an additional isolate detected in a healthy individual with sample collection on 2 May 2017). - Confirmation of additional cases is not unexpected at this time. Outbreak response is taking place, including use of monovalent oral polio vaccine type 2 (mOPV2) in line with internationally-agreed outbreak response protocols, targeting more than 750 000 children under the age of 5 across the 2 provinces. \n- The 1st mOPV2 round was implemented on 27-29 Jun 2017 in the 2 affected provinces; and the 2nd mOPV2 round ran from 13-15 Jul 2017 in Haut Lomami and 20-22 Jul 2017 in Maniema. - Surveillance and immunization activities are being strengthened in neighbouring countries.  Middle East  - In Syria, 6 new cases of cVDPV2 were officially reported in the past week from Deir-Ez-Zour governorate, bringing the total number of cases in this outbreak to 39. Onset of paralysis of these cases is between 3 Mar 2017 and 10 Jul 2017. The bulk of all cases are from Deir-Ez-Zour, the epicentre of this outbreak. - Confirmation of additional cases is not unexpected at this time and would not change the operational situation, as outbreak response plans are being finalized and implemented, in line with internationally-agreed outbreak response protocols. Two vaccination campaigns are planned for both Deir-Ez-Zour and Raqqa governorates. - The 1st mOPV2 round in Deir-Ez-Zour was successfully carried out between 22-26 Jul 2017. Independent post-campaign monitoring reflected coverage of 88.4 percent (based on caregiver recall). - The 2nd immunization round for Deir-Ez-Zor governorate started on 22 Aug 2017 and is ongoing. Monovalent OPV2 is being provided for children between 0-59 months of age, and inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) for children 2-23 months. In addition to polio vaccines, Aqua Tabs are being provided to families for water purification - 2.5 tons of water purification tablets for 400 000 people have been disseminated at health centers. - Plans are being finalized to mitigate the risks of further spread from the outbreak zone to neighbouring areas and countries, including immunization of at-risk populations in northwest Syria, Turkey and Lebanon.  Officially reported wild poliovirus cases as of 29 Aug 2017  Total global cases in 2017: 9 (compared with 22 for the same period in 2016) - Total in endemic countries in 2017: 9 (compared with 22 for the same period in 2016) - Total in non-endemic countries in 2017: 0 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016)  - Afghanistan: 6 cases in 2017 (compared with 7 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 10 Jul 2017 - Pakistan: 3 cases in 2017 (compared with 13 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 11 Jun 1017 - Nigeria: 0 case in 2017 (compared with 2 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 21 Aug 2016  Total global cases in 2016: 37 - Total in endemic countries: 37 - Total in non-endemic countries: 0  Officially reported cVDPV cases as of 29 Aug 2017 - Total global cases in 2017: 47 (compared with 3 for the same period in 2016) - Syrian Arab Republic: 39 cases in 2017 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 10 Jul 2017 - Democratic Republic of the Congo: 8 cases in 2017 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 20 Jun 2017 - Pakistan: 0 case in 2017 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 17 Dec 2016 - Nigeria: 0 case in 2017 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 28 Oct 2016 - Lao People's Democratic Republic: 0 case in 2017 (compared with 3 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 11 Jan 2016  Total global cases in 2016: 5 - Total in endemic countries: 2 - Total in non-endemic countries: 3   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Syria - WHO Situation Report. Date: Wed 30 Aug 2017. Source: WHO UNICEF Situation Report 11 (edited) (http://www.emro.who.int/images/stories/syria/WHO_UNICEF_Situation_Report_11_cVDPV2_outbreak_Syria_29.8.17_3.pdf?ua=1)   Key Highlights  - Six (6) new cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week: 4 cases are from Mayadeen district and 2 are from Boukamal district, Deir Ez-Zor governorate. - The total number of cVDPV2 cases is 39. All confirmed cases to date have had onset of paralysis before 14 Jul 2017. - Final lab results are pending for an additional 5 poliovirus type-2 (PV2) isolates (3 from Mayadeen and 1 from Boukamal districts, Deir Ez-Zor governorate, and 1 from Thawra district, Raqqa governorate). - The 2nd immunization round for Deir Ez-Zor started on 22 Aug 2017 and is ongoing due to high levels of population movement in and out of the governorate during the round. - WHO has organized the redistribution of vaccines and mapping of population movements to increase reach. An additional 90 000 mOPV2 doses are being transported from Damascus to Deir Ez-Zor, to cater for population influxes from As-Sukhnah, Homs governorate, and Al-Qa'im in Iraq. Corrective measures are expected to extend the round by 2 days. - Preparations for the 2nd immunization round for Raqqa are underway. - The total number of AFP cases detected in Deir Ez-Zor governorate since the beginning of 2017 is 122 (91 from Mayadeen, 10 from Deir Ez-Zor, and 21 from Boukamal districts). Raqqa governorate has reported 16 AFP cases (5 from Raqqa, 10 from Tell Abyad, and 1 from Thawra districts). Homs governorate has reported 28 AFP cases (12 from Homs city, 13 from Rastan, 1 from Tadmour and 2 from Talkalakh districts).  more details on the vaccination activities and future plans are available at the source URL as well as the epidemic curve and graphic representation of the vaccination status of non-polio acute flaccid paralysis cases by governorate and district. - Mod.MPP   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  In the above global summary, there is still identified transmission ongoing in Pakistan as seen by the positive environmental sample in Karachi as well as the early report on a case of WPV1 associated disease in Karachi. It will be interesting to learn of the genetic profile of the environmental isolates in Karachi (from this past week as well as from a few weeks ago) and compare them with the newly identified WPV1 associated case in Karachi to see if they are genetically related.  There has been more activity associated with cVDPV2 in both Syria and the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DR Congo), with 6 newly confirmed cases in Syria and 1 newly confirmed case in the DR Congo. According to the Situation Report in section <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> above, there are still 5 additional PV2 (poliovirus type 2) isolates in Syria undergoing final testing  4 from Deir al Zour and 1 from Raqqa. Hence there will probably be more cases confirmed in the coming days or weeks. I have not been able to identify similar report information from the DR Congo outbreak so it is not clear if the transmission has been interrupted leaving a total of 8 cases, or if there are still probable cases pending confirmation.
