Singapore\nAs of 5 Aug 2017, there were 1732 dengue cases reported in Singapore\nsince January 2017. This is lower than the number of reported cases\nduring the same period since 2013. During week 31, there were 61 cases\nreported and the number of reported cases in 2017 remains lower than\nthose reported for the same time period in 2016 . Viet Nam\nAs of 3 Aug 2017, there were 80 555 cases of dengue reported in Viet\nNam including 22 deaths. Compared with the same period in 2016, the\ncumulative number of cases increased by 33.5 per cent, and the number\nof deaths rose by 5. Most cases were reported from the South (59 per\ncent). A sharp increase in the number of reported cases has been\nobserved in the North (almost 25 times higher than the same period\nlast year 2016), especially from Ha Noi, with about 13 440 cases. Southern hemisphere\n-\nAustralia\nAs of 31 Jul 2017, there were 695 laboratory-confirmed dengue cases\nreported in Australia in 2017. The number of cases reported is lower\nthan that reported during the same time period in the previous years\n(2012-2016). Pacific Islands countries and areas\n\nFrench Polynesia\nIn French Polynesia, 12 cases (including 1 death) in week 29 and 12\ncases in week 30 (week ending 29 Jul 2017). Among these, 15 cases were\nconfirmed as DENV-1 infection. New Caledonia (no update)\nAs of 1 Aug 2017, 4,452 dengue cases were reported in 2017. There is a\ndownward trend in the number of reported cases since week 16 (week\nending 22 Apr 2017). \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"San Marino":{},"Sao Tome and Principe":{},"Saudi Arabia":{"129":{"title":"MERS-CoV (56): UAE, Saudi Arabia (JF, HA, RI),\r\n\tWHO ","date":["29","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> MERS-CoV (56): UAE, Saudi Arabia (JF, HA, RI),\r\n\tWHO [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nMERS-COV (56): UNITED ARAB EMIRATES, SAUDI ARABIA (AL JAWF, HAIL,\nRIYADH), WHO\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> UAE, 1 new case - WHO\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Saudi Arabia, 7 new cases - Saudi MOH 19-29 Aug 2017 \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> UAE, 1 new case - WHO.\nDate: Mon 28 Aug 2017.\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News\n(DONs) (edited)\n(http://www.who.int/csr/don/28-august-2017-mers-uae/en/) \nMiddle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) - United Arab\nEmirates\n\nOn 29 Jul 2017, the national IHR focal point of the United Arab\nEmirates reported one additional case of Middle East Respiratory\nSyndrome Coronavirus (MERS-CoV) Details of the case\n-\nMERS-CoV case reported on 29 July 2017*\nPlease note, data corresponds to Disease Outbreak News as published on\n28 Aug 2017.\n* Data subject to change due to ongoing investigations. Fields related\nto the final status of the case are updated as information is\navailable.\nNA = Not available Date of notification to WHO / Reporting country / City of residence /\nAge / Sex / Health care worker / Comorbidities / Exposure to camels /\nCamel milk consumption / Exposure to MERS-CoV cases / Date of symptoms\nonset / Date of 1st hospitalization / Date of laboratory confirmation\n/ Status\n29 Jul 2017 / United Arab Emirates / Al Ain / 54 / M / No / No / NA /\nNA / No / 11 Jul 2017 / 25 Jul 2017 / Alive The patient, who lives and works in Al Ain, United Arab Emirates,\npresented at a hospital in Al Ain on 16 Jul 2017. On 16 Jul 2017,\na chest X-ray showed pneumonia and he was treated with antibiotics and\nnon-invasive ventilation. On 25 Jul 2017, his symptoms worsened and\na sputum sample was collected and tested for MERS-CoV and influenza.\nOn 26 Jul 2017, showing no signs of improvement, the patient was\ntransferred to a 2nd hospital in Al Ain and placed in an intensive\ncare unit. A 2nd sputum sample was collected on 26 Jul 2017 and both samples\ntested positive for MERS-CoV on 27 Jul 2017. The patient is\ncurrently in ICU on mechanical ventilation. Investigations into the\nsource of infection are ongoing. At the time of writing the results of\nthe investigation were not yet provided to WHO. Globally, 2067 laboratory-confirmed cases of infection with MERS-CoV\nincluding at least 720 related deaths have been reported to WHO. Public health response\n-\nThe Ministry of Health in Abu Dhabi carried out contact tracing and\nfollowed up 89 health care workers and 95 contacts at his place of\nemployment. All identified contacts were monitored for 14 days from\nthe last date of exposure. No additional cases were detected. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp I have been unable to find additional information on both official\nsources as well as unofficial sources of information related to the\ncase described in the UAE in the above WHO report. Of note is that the\nevent (identification of a MERS-CoV infected individual) actually\noccurred a month ago  the date of report of this case to WHO was 29\nJul 2017, with the date of onset of symptoms 11 Jul 2017 and date of\npositive laboratory testing for MERS-CoV of 25 Jul 2017. Information\non results of contact tracing continuing until 14 days following last\nknown contact with the case (one incubation period) was available for\nall contacts. Hence, this is a nice historical archive of\nidentification of a sporadic case of MERS-CoV infection, although the\ninformation on the investigation of possible high risk exposures of\nthe actual case is not available at present. This is now the 5th case of MERS-CoV infection identified in the UAE\nthis year, with 2 previous cases in May 2017 from Al Ain, and 2\nadditional previous cases from Abu Dhabi reported in April 2017,\nbringing the total number of cases reported by the UAE since 2012 up\nto 84. Al Ain is a major inland city of the UAE, belonging to the Abu Dhabi\nemirate (see\n(https://www.mapsofworld.com/united-arab-emirates/maps/united-arab-emirates-cities-map.jpg)). The HealthMap/ProMED map of the United Arab Emirates is available at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/132). - Mod.MPP \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Saudi Arabia, 7 new cases - Saudi MOH 19-29 Aug 2017.\nDate: Tue 29 Aug 2017.\nSource: Saudi MOH 19-29 Aug 2017 (edited)\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/default.aspx?PageIndex=1) \nAs of Tue 29 Aug 2017, there have been a total of:\n1708 laboratory-confirmed cases of MERS-CoV infection, including\n688 deaths reported case fatality rate 40.3 percent,\n997 recoveries, and\n22 currently active cases/infections. Clearly\ntransmission is continuing in this area, with 3 newly confirmed\nsecondary cases in household contacts - at least 2 of whom were\nidentified through screening of asymptomatic household contacts, and 2\nadditional cases in which high risk exposures are still under\ninvestigation. We do not know if these household contacts are\nassociated with the earlier identified transmission chain in Dawmat\nAljandal or if these are newly identified chains of transmission. The\nother 2 newly confirmed cases involve \"sporadic\" cases - an individual\nin Hail whose high risk exposure history is still under investigation,\nand an individual from Alaflaj (Riyadh region) with a history of\ndirect contact with camels in the 14 days preceding onset of illness. As to be expected, concern is being voiced on the international level\nwith the upcoming Hajj and this recent increase in cases reported both\nin Saudi Arabia and in the UAE. We now have gone through 5 Hajj\nperiods since the identification of the MERS-CoV and to date there\nhave been no cases of MERS-CoV infection identified in returning\nHajjis. The case in the UAE (see section <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> above) actually had onset\nof illness over 1 month ago with no secondary cases/infections\nidentified among known contacts of this case. As for the cases in\nSaudi Arabia, and more specifically the Hajj, population movement is\nvery well defined during the Hajj, no camels are permitted in the\nareas where Hajjis are congregated, and there are Hajj specific health\nservices that are separate from those that are available for the\ngeneral Saudi population, all factors that are reducing the likelihood\nof Hajjis having inadvertent (or intentional) high risk exposures.\nHopefully my optimism is well placed and we will pass through a 6th\nHajj period without impact on international transmission of the\nMERS-CoV associated with this Hajj. Date: Mon 21 Aug 2017. Source: The Mainichi (edited) (https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20170821/p2g/00m/0dm/077000c)   Japan's health ministry has issued a warning for people traveling to Europe on the back of an outbreak of measles in countries such as Italy and Romania. The Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare is advising tourists to go to hospital if they develop a high fever or generalized rash after returning to Japan.  Although the World Health Organization verified that Japan has eliminated infections of endemic measles strains in 2015, group infections originating from people who contracted the disease abroad are spreading in the country. As of 6 Aug 2017, the number of patients reached 169 this year in Japan, already eclipsing the figure in the previous year.  About 4100 patients in Italy and around 6500 patients in Romania have already been confirmed as of August 2017 compared with about 860 and 2000, respectively, throughout 2016, according to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control.  Symptoms of the highly contagious disease include runny nose, red and watery eyes, high fever, and rash. The virus is spread through coughing and sneezing and can cause complications such as pneumonia and can even result in death in one in 1000 patients, according to the ministry. The ministry recommends people traveling overseas to check their vaccination records and take an additional shot if they have only been vaccinated once.  The disease was prevalent about a decade ago in Japan with the number of patients soaring to over 10 000 in 2008 but the country was later considered as free from infections of the virus.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Japan can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/156). - Mod.LK   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia): ex Italy. Date: Fri 25 Aug 2017 5:36 PM AEST. Source: News.com.au, Australian Associated Press (AAP) report (edited) (http://www.news.com.au/national/breaking-news/fourth-case-of-measles-at-perth-school/news-story/ece041f55111645e10f70046d92479dd)   A 4th child has been diagnosed with measles at Perth Waldorf School Western Australia, more than a week after the health department gave an on-site vaccine to students. A Health Department spokeswoman confirmed the latest case, which came 3 weeks after the highly contagious disease was first detected in an unvaccinated year 10 student who had returned from Italy.  Revelations that about half the school's 400 students were unvaccinated against the disease led the Health Department to offer a voluntary, free on-site vaccine to students, but it is unknown how many took up the offer.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Maps of Australia can be seen at (http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gi) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62426). - Mod.LK   Europe  <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Germany (Berlin): 2014-15. Date: Thu 24 Aug 2017. Source: Eurosurveillance edition 2017; 22(34) (edited) (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=22861)   ref: Werber D, Hoffmann A, Santibanez S, et al. Large measles outbreak introduced by asylum seekers and spread among the insufficiently vaccinated resident population, Berlin, October 2014 to August 2015. Euro Surveill. 2017; 22(34): pii=30599 - Abstract  The largest measles outbreak in Berlin since 2001 occurred from October 2014 to August 2015. Overall, 1344 cases were ascertained, 86 per cent (with available information) unvaccinated, including 146 (12 per cent) asylum seekers. Median age was 17 years (interquartile range: 4-29 years), 26 per cent were hospitalised and a 1 year old child died. Measles virus genotyping uniformly revealed the variant 'D8-Rostov-Don' and descendants. The virus was likely introduced by and initially spread among asylum seekers before affecting Berlin's resident population. Among Berlin residents, the highest incidence was in children younger than 2 years, yet most cases (52 per cent) were adults. Post-exposure vaccinations in homes for asylum seekers, not always conducted, occurred later (median: 7.5 days) than the recommended 72 hours after onset of the 1st case and reached only half of potential contacts. Asylum seekers should not only have non-discriminatory, equitable access to vaccination, they also need to be offered measles vaccination in a timely fashion, that is, immediately upon arrival in the receiving country. Supplementary immunisation activities targeting the resident population, particularly adults, are urgently needed in Berlin.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Germany can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5857). - Mod.LK   <br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Romania. Date: Fri 25 August 2017. Source: Romania Insider (edited) (https://www.romania-insider.com/measles-kills-iraqi-refugee/)   The ongoing measles outbreak keeps making victims in Romania. A 10 month old girl, who was a refugee from Iraq, became the 33rd person to die of the infection, reports local Digi24. The girl arrived in Romania on 7 Jul 2017 with her family, and the doctors diagnosed her with measles in August. They also discovered that the child was suffering from malnutrition and severe psychomotor retardation.  The measles outbreak is still a major problem in Romania, with more than 8900 cases reported across the country until 25 Aug 2017, including 33 deaths, according to data from the National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT). Most deaths were registered in Timis (9), Dolj (7), and Arad (6) counties.  Measles is a highly contagious respiratory infection caused by a virus. It causes a total-body skin rash and flu-like symptoms, including fever, cough, and runny nose. According to information posted on WHO's website, the virus is highly contagious, spreading by coughing and sneezing, close personal contact, and direct contact with infected nasal or throat secretions. Unvaccinated young children pose the highest risk of measles and its complications, including death.  The Romanian Government adopted earlier this month August 2017 a draft bill on the organization and financing of population vaccination (https://www.romania-insider.com/romania-draft-bill-vaccination/). The project was sent to the Parliament for approval and could come into force in January 2018.  byline: Irina Marica   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Measles tends to be more severe in children who are malnourished, especially children who are also vitamin A deficient. And complications are commoner and more serious in malnourished children. Because of complications such as diarrhoea, measles may lead to failure to thrive. Infection with measles virus may lead to kwashiorkor or marasmus in children who are underweight at the time that they get infected. Therefore, measles may result in, or aggravate, malnutrition.  Maps of Romania can be found at (http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/romania/ro111aa/romania_pol.jpg) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/122). - Mod.LK   Measles immunity gaps  <br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Role of demographics. Date: Sat 26 Aug 2017. Source: News-Medical/Life Sciences (edited) (https://www.news-medical.net/news/20170826/New-study-highlights-role-played-by-demographics-in-the-spread-of-measles.aspx)   Even if the incidence of measles infection has decreased by at least 90 per cent worldwide since the introduction of the vaccine, measles is still one of the major causes of death in children among vaccine-preventable diseases. Regular measles epidemics are reported in developing countries and recurrent episodic outbreaks occur in the developed world.  A new study by Bocconi University and Bruno Kessler Foundation analyzing 9 countries (Australia, Ethiopia, Kenya, Ireland, Italy, South Korea, Singapore, the United Kingdom, and the United States) and published in The Lancet Infectious Diseases see reference below, highlights the role played by demographics in the spread of measles and concludes that future vaccination strategies in high-fertility countries should focus on increasing childhood immunization rates, while immunization campaigns targeting adolescents and young adults are required in low fertility countries.  Using a transmission model calibrated on historical serological data the authors estimate that the susceptible proportion of the population (that is, unprotected against the infection) varies from about 3 per cent in the UK to more than 12.5 per cent in Ethiopia, with astonishing differences in its age composition, due to different vaccination strategies and divergent demographic trends. While the percentage of over-15 among susceptible individuals in Ethiopia and Kenya is, respectively, 28 per cent and 43 per cent, adolescents and young adults represent 74 per cent of unprotected individuals in South Korea, 66 per cent in Italy and 53 per cent in the US, with considerable immunity gaps in individuals aged 30-40 years.  \"Every effort to increase the vaccination coverage rate among children is praiseworthy\", says Alessia Melegaro, a Bocconi professor and principal investigator of DECIDE, the ERC European Research Council-funded project which produced the article, \"but in some developed countries it's the lack of coverage among adolescents and adults that poses a serious threat to the goal of eliminating measles.\"  \"Measles incidence could increase, in the next decades, in Italy, Australia, and Singapore and Ethiopia is at high risk of future large epidemics\", says Stefano Merler from Bruno Kessler Foundation, \"and this is particularly worrying considering that individuals get infected later in life when the disease is more severe. The median age at infection for 2015 was estimated to be 5-10 years in the UK, Ireland, and Ethiopia; 10-15 years in the USA, Australia, Singapore, and Kenya; and older than 20 years in Italy and South Korea\".  The proposed model shows that the introduction of the measles vaccine, which occurred at different times in the 9 countries, has considerably reduced the disease burden in terms of disability-adjusted life-years (DALYs), a measure expressed as the number of years lost because of illness, disability, or early death. Every vaccine dose averts 2 or 3 weeks of DALYs in the developed world and around 20 weeks in Kenya and Ethiopia. Which translates into 2-mln years 2 million DALYs since the vaccine introduction in the UK, 13-mln 13 million DALYs in the US, and 36-mln 36 million DALYs in Ethiopia.  \"Vaccination has undoubtedly achieved incredible results in terms of public health. In particular,\" continues Prof Melegaro \"our analysis showed that routine 1st dose vaccine administration has been responsible for more than 90 per cent of the overall number of vaccine-immunized individuals in most countries. In Ethiopia and Kenya, catch-up and follow-up campaigns substantially mitigated the effect of suboptimum routine vaccine coverage, generating 25-45 per cent of the immunized fraction of the population. Tailoring immunization campaigns to achieve measles eradication goals is essential and currently, for some countries, this means considering also the role of unprotected adolescents and young adults.\"   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Reference - Trentini F, Poletti P, Merler S, Melegaro A. Measles immunity gaps and the progress towards elimination: a multi-country modelling analysis. Lancet Infect Dis. 2017. pii: S1473-3099(17)30421-8. Epub ahead of print; (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28807627).   While it is recommended that children get 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine, starting with the 1st dose at 12 through 15 months of age, and the 2nd dose at 4 through 6 years of age, this study emphasizes that it is important that adolescents and young adults also are up to date on their MMR vaccination. - Mod.LK  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"115":{"title":"Dengue/DHF update (10): Asia, Pacific, Africa, research, WHO\r\n\t","date":["25","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Dengue/DHF update (10): Asia, Pacific, Africa, research, WHO\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nDENGUE/DHF UPDATE (10): ASIA, PACIFIC, AFRICA, RESEARCH, WHO\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cases in various countries Asia\n\nSri Lanka\n- National\n- National\n- National\nIndia\n- National\n- Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Assam\n- Delhi\n- Tamil Nadu (Coimbatore)\n- Tamil Nadu\n- Tamil Nadu (Chennai)\n- Tamil Nadu (Chennai)\n- Kerala\n- Karnataka\n- Karnataka (Gulbarga)\n- Karnataka (Gulbarga)\n- West Bengal (Kolkata)\n- West Bengal (Birbhum)\n- West Bengal (Siliguri)\n- Odisha (Ganjam)\n- Odisha\n- Gujarat (Ahmedabad)\n- Jharkhand (Jamshedpur)\n- Telangana (Hyderabad)\nPakistan\n- Sindh (Karachi)\n- Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar)\n- Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar)\n- Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar)\nChina\n- Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region ex Viet Nam (susp)\n- Hong Kong SAR\n- Macau SAR\n- Macau SAR\nTaiwan\nMyanmar\n- National\n- Kayah\nIndonesia\n- Papua (Jayapura)\nViet Nam\n- National\n- National\n- Mekong Delta\n- Hanoi\n- Ha Nam\nPhilippines\n- National\n- Cebu\n- Negros Occidental\n- Negros Occidental (Bacolod City)\n- Cavite (Trece Martires City)\nLaos\n- National\nJapan ex Côte d'Ivoire Pacific\n\n- Samoa\n- Samoa\n- Samoa\n- Samoa\n- Fiji\n- French Polynesia (Tahiti) Africa\n\n- Côte d'Ivoire\n- Côte d'Ivoire <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Research\n- Viral persistence\n- Air travel related spread of dengue\n- Visual impact <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> World Health Organization update \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cases in various countries\nAsia\n\nSri Lanka\n- National. 26 Jul 2017. Sri Lanka has now notified 107 015 cases,\nwhich WHO estimates is 4.3 times more than the average number of cases\nusually reported (http://tinyurl.com/ycvszzs8). - National. 19 Aug 2017. Since the beginning of 2017, Sri Lanka has\nreported 137 279 suspected dengue cases and more than 300 deaths.\nAbout 44.5 per cent of dengue cases were reported from the Western\nprovince. This compares with about 39 000 cases reported from January\nto August 2016, and 55 150 cases during the entire year 2016.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-updates-vietnam-sri-lanka-32087/) - National. 25 Aug 2017. Through Fri 25 Aug 2017, Sri Lanka has\nofficially reported 144 052 cases and, as of 3 Aug 2017, 3327 people\nhave died.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-epidemic-waning-sri-lanka-university-jaffna-science-faculty-closed-september-83024/) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Sri Lanka can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/144). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ India\n- National. 31 Jul 2017. 11 832 more cases than in 2016 and 46 deaths,\n11 more than in 2016. The total has risen to 28 702, with 2536 cases\nand 10 deaths last week week of 24 Jul 2017. Floods continued to wreak\nhavoc in the 3 states, which reported 88 more dengue-related deaths.\nOfficials said 33 more dengue-related deaths had been reported in\nUttar Pradesh over the last 2 days.\n(http://www.christianmessenger.in/floods-in-bihar-up-assam-88-die-in-dengue-related-deaths/) - Delhi. 31 Jul 2017. As of 29 Jul 2017, 180 cases of dengue (monsoon\narrived early).\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/delhi/882984/dengue-malaria-chikungunya-cases-on-the-rise-in-delhi/) - Tamil Nadu (Coimbatore). 4 Aug 2017. Deaths rise to 16 in last 2\nmonths; new admissions increasing.\n(http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/2-more-dengue-deaths-in-coimbatore-total-deaths-now-16-117080401128_1.html) - Tamil Nadu. 11 Aug 2017. Prevalence of dengue in Tamil Nadu is\ndecreasing. So far, 5000 people have been affected and due to proper\ntreatment by doctors in government and private hospitals, almost all\ndengue patients have been saved, health minister C Vijaya Baskar said\ntoday 11 Aug 2017.\n(http://www.dnaindia.com/\nhealth/report-prevalence-of-dengue-in-tn-down-health-minister-2526936) - Tamil Nadu (Chennai). 18 Aug 2017. At least 1500 new cases in 10\ndays. Over 6000 patients have been confirmed and\ntreated as in-patients; mortality has been kept to 1 per cent.\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/thiruvananthapuram/882347/mch-keeps-dengue-mortality-rate-to-1/#) - Karnataka (Gulbarga). 4 Aug 2017. 235 cases in Gulbarga district\nfrom January to July 2017. Of the 235, 171 cases were reported from\nKalaburagi taluk sub district alone, 32 from Chincholli taluk, 13\nfrom Chittapur taluk, 4 cases each from Afzalpur, Aland, and Sedam\ntaluks, and 3 cases from Jewargi taluk.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-karnataka/235-dengue-cases-in-kalaburagi-dist/article19423638.ece) - Karnataka (Gulbarga). 23 Aug 2017. A total of 474 confirmed cases in\nGulbarga district, with 1927 suspected cases; 368 cases confirmed in\nKalaburagi sub district. Only 43 cases were reported in the district\ntill the end of June 2017 and 191 cases were reported between 1 and\n10 Aug 2017, while 240 new cases have been registered, taking the\ntotal to 474.\n(http://www.uniindia.com/dengue-474-confirmed-cases-reported-in-kalaburagi-district/health-and-medicine/fullstory/968353.html) - Karnataka. 18 Aug 2017. Nearly 8000 cases in Karnataka so far in\n2017. Kerala has reported 16 000 cases and Tamil Nadu 9500 cases.\nDengue spreads easily between the 3 adjacent states.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/karnataka/central-team-to-review-dengue-outbreak-in-state/article19512224.ece) - West Bengal (Kolkata). 12 Aug 2017. Dengue scare at RG Kar Hospital\nMedical College hostel; at least 8 test positive over the last week.\nIn 2015, more than 30 were affected in the hostel campus and one died.\nOn 2016 too, more than a dozen inmates were affected.\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/dengue-scare-at-rg-kar-hostel-8-test-positive/articleshow/60029232.cms) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nAnirban Ghosh\nKasturba Medical College\n(m_anirbanghosh@hotmail.com) - West Bengal (Birbhum). 21 Aug 2017. At least 100 cases dengue have\nbeen reported from West Bengal's Birbhum district. \"We have received\nreports of at least 100 cases of dengue since 23 Jul 2017. While\nabout 60 of these cases are from the Dubrajpur town in the district's\nSuri Sadar sub-division, the rest are from other areas such as Bolpur\nand Rampurhat towns. But no one has died so far,\" the chief medical\nofficer of Birbhum, Himadri Ari, told The Hindu.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/bengal-records-100-dengue-cases/article19535541.ece) - West Bengal (Siliguri). 23 Aug 2017. The number of people suffering\nfrom dengue is rising at an alarming rate in Siliguri. According to\nrecords, the highest number of dengue cases reported was 54. This year\n2017, the mark has been crossed.\n(http://siliguritimes.com/number-dengue-patients-rise-siliguri/) - Odisha (Ganjam). 22 Jul 2017. Blood samples of 116 people of the\ndistrict were recently tested and 4 dengue positive cases were\ndetected. Disinfecting water bodies in the district has already\nstarted and a 3-member team has been entrusted with spreading\nawareness on dengue in the district.\n(http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/odisha/2017/jul/22/4-found-dengue-positive-in-odishas-ganjam-district-1632062.html) - Odisha. 18 Aug 2017. 402 cases and 2 deaths. Last year 2016 4348\npersons were tested positive for the dengue virus by this period with\n8 deaths. Out of total 402 infected persons, 67 were tested positive\nin Bhadrak district, 61 in Cuttack district, and 59 in Balasore\ndistrict. Similarly, 35 people have been infected in Khordha, 34 in\nJajpur, 24 in Puri, 20 in Jagatsinghpur . Meanwhile, Kendrapara has\nregistered 20, Ganjam 13, Keonjhar 10, Dhenkanal 11, Bolangir 6, and\nMayurbhanj 5 cases of dengue. While Nayagarh, Sonepur, Kalahandi,\nAngul, and Bargarh registered 3 cases each, Nuapada and Kandhamal\nwitnessed 2 cases. Boudh, Rayagada, Sundargarh and Deogarh districts\nrecorded with single case each. However, 12 patients have come to the\nstate from neighbouring states.\n(http://pragativadi.com/dengue-claims-two-lives-affects-402-odisha/) - Gujarat (Ahmedabad). 1 Aug 2017. A total of 59 cases in July 2017.\nThe actual number of cases is said to be 'far more'; it takes at least\n15 days to confirm cases.\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/59-dengue-cases-in-july-amc/articleshow/59853414.cms) - Jharkhand (Jamshedpur). 30 Jul 2017. 75 positive cases in Kolhan and\nadjoining area of Jamshedpur.\n(http://www.avenuemail.in/jamshedpur/dengue-cases-rise-positive-cases-shoot-75-kolhan/111026/) - Telangana (Hyderabad). 25 Jul 2017. All 4 dengue serotypes are\npresent this year 2017. A total of 15 samples found to be\nco-infected. In an earlier study done in New Delhi, such multiple\ndengue serotype infections were reported in only 19 per cent of cases.\nAll 4 dengue serotypes were detected in almost equal number in blood\nsamples, unlike in an earlier study conducted in New Delhi wherein one\nserotype was found to be dominating. This has been indicated as a\npossible reason for the high prevalence of infection due to more than\none dengue serotype. Another finding of concern is that DEN-4 strain,\nresembling the one detected in Pune in 2009, was detected in as many\nas 11 samples. DEN-4 is associated with unusual symptoms like\nrespiratory distress, pleural effusion, and elevated levels of liver\nenzymes. Also, detection of a DEN-1 strain found closely related to a\nstrain from Thailand detected in 1980 that causes high severity\ninfection has been reported. Dr Musturi Venkataramana, assistant\nprofessor of biotechnology of UoH, who led the study, said, \"When a\nperson is infected with more than one serotype of dengue, it may lead\nto dengue haemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome which can cause\nsevere health problems, and even death. Finding 45 per cent patients\nwith such infections is worrisome.\"\n(http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/hyderabad/2017/jul/25/all-four-dengue-serotypes-prevalent-in-city-1633171.html) Maps of India can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Pakistan\n- Sindh (Karachi). 8 Aug 2017. 422 dengue fever cases have been\nreported in Sindh province so far in 2017, out of them 410 were\nreported in Karachi, 5 in Hyderabad, 5 in Tharparkar/Mithi, and 2 in\nUmerkot. As per a weekly report issued by Prevention and Control\nProgram for Dengue in Sindh, as many as 27 new dengue fever cases\nsurfaced in the city from 1 to 7 Aug 2017.\n(http://www.brecorder.com/2017/08/08/363624/a27-more-dengue-cases-surface-in-karachi/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 8 Aug 2017. 3rd death due to dengue\nhemorrhagic fever and encephalitis. Most of the affected patients were\nbrought from the Tehkal Payan area from where water samples have been\ncollected to determine the situation.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1476245/third-dengue-death-\nreported-k-p/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 16 Aug 2017. The number of dengue\npatients in the city has reached 600 in almost a month. Most of the\ncases are from Tehkal, the rear of which is a rural area, where there\nis a large number of automobile repair shops. The water kept in open\ncontainers to wash tyres and for other related work serves as the\nbreeding ground for mosquitoes that transmit dengue.\nAs per the administration of Khyber Teaching Hospital, 5 of the\npatients brought to the facility since June 2017 have succumbed to\nthe dengue virus.\n(https://www.geo.tv/latest/153878-peshawar-admin-busy-in-photo-shoot-as-dengue-cases-soar-to-600) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 22 Aug 2017. An investigation report\nby WHO on the dengue outbreak in Peshawar has revealed that the\npresence of a huge number of uncovered water containers used in houses\nand at workshops is the main reason for the outbreak. Following the\ncases reported from Peshawar, a 5-member WHO team moved to the city to\ninvestigate the reasons behind the dengue epidemic. The team collected\nsamples from 2 main areas  Tehkal and Gujran Muhalla. The report\nrevealed that 87 per cent of the samples collected from 23 water\ncontainers in the Civil Dispensary area of Tehkal tested positive for\ndengue virus. Similarly, 79 per cent of the total 19 samples of water\ncontainers in Gujran Muhallah also tested positive.\nThe data compiled by the WHO team, the total number of reported cases\nexceeded 4320 which were screened for dengue in the Khyber Teaching\nHospital from 14 Jun to 17 Aug 2017. A total of 699 people tested\npositive for dengue, of which 5 have died. Of the total patients\nscreened, 325 were admitted to the hospital while 200 were discharged.\nBy 17 Aug 2017, a total of 120 patients were admitted to the facility.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1487967/reveals-water-storage-containers-behind-dengue-surge-peshawar/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 24 Aug 2017. Dengue continues in\nPeshawar, claiming 7 lives with 69 new cases reported from different\nareas of the city during the last 24 hours, raising the number of\ntotal cases to 1703. So far, he said, 7 deaths including 6 from Khyber\nTeaching Hospital and one in Hayatabad Medical Complex were reported\nfrom dengue epidemics in Peshawar. Out of 69 new cases, 41 were\nreported in Khyber Teaching Hospital (KTH), 13 in Hayatabad Medical\nComplex (HMC), 12 in Lady Reading Hospital (LRH), and 3 in Naseerullah\nKhan Babar Teaching Hospital (NBTH), Peshawar, he said. A rapid\nresponse team has also been set up with mandate to swiftly reach to\nthe affected areas from where new cases were surfaced besides helping\nthe field staff in conduct of fumigation spray, removal of larvae, and\nprovision of other necessary medicines.\n(https://dnd.com.pk/dengue-rampage-in-peshawar-kills-seven-69-new-cases-surface/133250) Maps of Pakistan can be seen at\n(http://pakistanmap.facts.co/pakistanmapof/PakistanAdministrativeMap.jpg)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ China\n- Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region ex Viet Nam (susp). 16 Aug 2017.\nGuangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in south China has reported its 1st\nimported dengue case this year 2017, local inspection and quarantine\nbureau said. The man had stayed in Hanoi, Viet Nam, for 2 months but\ndenied having been bitten by mosquitoes or having any infectious\ndisease.\n(http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-08/16/c_136531179.htm) - Hong Kong SAR Special Administrative Region. 9 Aug 2017. 1st\nlocally transmitted case of dengue in Hong Kong, this year 2017.\n(https://today.mims.com/topic/chp-investigates-first-local-dengue-fever-case-of-the-year) - Macau SAR. 1 Aug 2017. 1st locally acquired case this year 2017\nconfirmed. 53 imported cases in 2017, including 18 from Thailand, 10\nfrom Sri Lanka, and 7 from the Philippines.\n(https://macaunews.mo/first-local-dengue-case-year-confirmed/) - Macau SAR. 24 Aug 2017. A 48 year old domestic worker from the\nPhilippines is now in hospital after health authorities confirmed she\nhas dengue fever; the 7th imported case reported in Macau this year\n2017.\n(http://menafn.com/1095765055/Tests-show-that-Filipino-maid-in-Macau-has-dengue-fever) Maps of China can be seen at (http://www.sacu.org/maps/provmap.png)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/155). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Taiwan. 3 Aug 2017. 2 more indigenous dengue fever cases have been\nconfirmed in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, making that 3 cases this\nyear, said a statement issued by Kaohsiung City's Department of Health\non Thu 3 Aug 2017. The 3 cases were all members of the same family,\nhusband, wife and son, who lived together in the southern Taiwanese\nport city, according to the department. From 1 Jan to 22 Jul 2017, 14 919 cases and 81\ndeaths of dengue recorded. Most of the deaths were from Ayeyarwady\nregion, followed by Yangon and Bago regions. The current reported\ncases are higher than those of 2016, yet still lower than that of\n2015, according to Dr Zaw Lin, dengue program manager of Ministry of\nHealth and Sports. In Rakhine State, about 1800 people are infected\nand 18 died from the infection. High occurrence was observed in\nMinbya, Sittwe, and Toungup townships. Over the past 2\nmonths, around 90 patients were taken to HCM Paediatrics Hospital No 1\nper week on average.\n(http://english.vietnamnet.vn/fms/society/182701/rising-dengue-fever-cases-leave-17-dead.html) - National. 19 Aug 2017. The number of dengue fever cases in Viet Nam\nspiked by some 10 000 cases in the past week. Tran Đac Phu, head of\nthe ministry's preventive medicine department, said the country had\nrecorded 90 626 dengue cases since the beginning of 2017, a\nyear-on-year rise of 67.8 per cent, including 24 fatalities, local\nmedia reports. This is up by about 10 000 since the last total case\ncount was released on 3 Aug 207. The outbreak is stretching the\ncountry's medical system as more than 78 000 of the cases required\nhospitalization. In the capital city of Hanoi, there have been 17 027\nrecorded dengue cases, 7 of whom died since the beginning of the year\n2017.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-updates-vietnam-sri-lanka-32087/) - Mekong Delta. 24 Jul 2017. Cases increased by 125 per cent in 1st 15\ndays of July 2017 compared with same period 2016. An Giang province\nalone recorded the highest number of 120 hospitalised cases in the 1st\n10 days of July 2017, followed by Soc Trang province with 110 cases\nand Dong Thap province, 100 cases. Since the beginning of 2017,\ndengue-related deaths have been reported in Dong Thap, Tien Giang, and\nTra Vinh provinces. Dengue fever has increased sharply this year among\nchildren aged between 10-15 in the Mekong Delta, especially in Can Tho\ncity.\n(http://english.vietnamnet.vn/fms/society/182533/dengue-fever-on-the-rise-in-mekong-delta.html) - Hanoi. 5 Aug 2017. Nearly 9000 cases of dengue fever have now been\nreported in Hanoi since the beginning of the year 2017, with 2300\nreported from 24 to 30 Jul 2017 alone, state media said. From the\nbeginning of this year 2017 through July, there was a 23 per cent\nincrease in cases in the city over the number reported during the same\nperiod last year 2016, while 46 per cent more cases were reported in\nJuly than in June, the city's health department said. According to\nWHO, as of 18 Jun 2017, there were 45 074 cases of dengue reported in\nViet Nam including 13 deaths. Compared to the same period in 2016 (40\n511 cases including 12 deaths), the cumulative number of cases\nincreased by 11.3 per cent.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/vietnam-dengue-news-emergency-declared-ha-nam-hanoi-outbreak-32326/) - Hanoi. 11 Aug 2017. Nearly 5000 new cases in Hanoi, with more than\n13 200 infected and with 6 deaths since early 2017.\n(http://www.elevenmyanmar.com/world-news/11037) - Ha Nam. 5 Aug 2017. More than 10 cases a day being reported largest\noutbreak in history of Province. The Ha Nam Province People's\nCommittee declared a state of emergency on 3 Aug 2017, to deal with a\ngrowing outbreak of dengue fever, spread by infected mosquitoes, with\n100 cases confirmed year-to-date, according to local media.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/vietnam-dengue-news-emergency-declared-ha-nam-hanoi-outbreak-32326/) Maps of Viet Nam can be seen at\n(http://www.onlineasiatravel.com/images/vn/vietnam-map.png) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/152). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Philippines\n- National. 11 Aug 2017. The Department of Health (DoH) reported a\nconsiderable decrease of dengue fever cases in the 1st half of 2017 in\nwhich only 43 770 nationwide have been tallied from 1 Jan to 1 Jul\n2017. This is 36.8 per cent lower than the 69 297 recorded in the\nsame period in 2016. Among the 43 770 cases, 250 deaths were reported,\nwhich is 84 fewer than the 334 recorded in the same period in 2016.\nThe report showed that all regions, except in Metro Manila, showed\ndecreasing trends in dengue cases as compared to 2016. Majority of the\ndengue cases were recorded in Central Visayas (6281), Metro Manila\n(5567), Central Luzon (5147), Calabarzon (5007), and Soccsksargen\n(4861). Provinces with the most number of cases are Cebu with 11 per\ncent, followed by South Cotabato with 6.3 per cent, and Pampanga with\n4.6 per cent. Metro Manila is the lone region with an upward trend of\ncases, recording a 24.9 per cent increase from 4457 in 2016.\n(http://www.manilatimes.net/dengue-cases-drop-first-half-2017-report/343788/) - Cebu. 11 Aug 2017. Talisay City, Cebu Province Central Visayas,\nPhilippines 296 cases and 9 deaths; Consolacion 260 cases and 4\ndeaths; Argao 187 cases and 1 death.\n(http://www.sunstar.com.ph/cebu/local-news/2017/08/10/talisay-tops-number-dengue-cases-557829) - Negros Occidental. 2 Aug 2017. The Provincial Health Office (PHO)\nreported that dengue cases this year 2017 in Negros Occidental have\nreached 14 from January to July. The latest death was reported in\nBarangay Mambulac, Silay City. Deaths were monitored in San Carlos\nCity, with 4; Sagay City and Kabankalan City, 2 each; Escalante City,\nVictorias City, Bago City, Silay City, Hinigaran, and Calatrava, one\neach.\n(http://www.sunstar.com.ph/bacolod/local-news/2017/08/02/provincial-health-office-dengue-deaths-negocc-now-14-556270) - Negros Occidental (Bacolod City).17 Aug 2017. A total of 9 barangays\nFilipino term for a village, district or ward identified as dengue\nhot spots: Mandalagan with 31 cases from January to 12 Aug 2017;\nVillamonte, 24; Mansilingan, 22; Banago, 18; Alijis, 17; Estefania,\n17; Vista Alegre, 14; Taculing, 13; and Sum-ag, 12.\n(http://www.sunstar.com.ph/bacolod/local-news/2017/08/17/9-barangays-bacolod-tag-dengue-hot-spots-558972) - Cavite (Trece Martires City). 23 Aug 2017. Dengue fever cases have\nbeen on the rise, particularly in the past 2 months in Cavite\nprovince's 7 districts the Provincial Epidemiology Surveillance Unit\n(PESU) reported. PESU records showed that in the 1st 8 months of the\nyear, 2193 cases and 8 deaths were reported, although only 1260 cases\nand 3 deaths were reported and recorded from 1 Jan to 24 Jun 2017.\nCavite, a 1st class province with 7 districts comprising 7 cities and\n16 municipalities, has an estimated population of 4.3 million. The\nprovincial government declared a dengue fever outbreak in all\ndistricts and placed the entire area under a state of calamity in\nSeptember 2015. The year ended with 48 deaths and 12 007 cases, PESU\nrecords showed.\n(http://news.mb.com.ph/2017/08/23/dengue-fever-cases-in-cavite-rising/) Maps of the Philippines can be seen at (http://tinyurl.com/z4y3p5v)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/158). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Laos\n- National. 4 Aug 2017. Over 5000 people infected and one death in the\ncapital Vientiane. As many as 7 other deaths have been reported, one\nin each of the following provinces: Khammouane, Savannakhet, Saravane,\nand Attapeu, while Champasak has reported 3 death since the beginning\nof 2017.\n(http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-08/04/c_136500474.htm) Maps of Lao People's Democratic Republic can be seen at\n(http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Laos.gif) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/146). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Japan ex Côte d'Ivoire. June 2017. Suzuki T, Kutsuna S, Taniguchi S,\net al. Dengue virus exported from Côte d'Ivoire to Japan, June 2017.\nEmerg Infect Dis. 2017 date cited.\nAbstract. Since April 2017, a dengue fever outbreak has been ongoing\nin Côte d'Ivoire. We diagnosed dengue fever (type 2 virus) in a\ntraveler returning to Japan from Côte d'Ivoire. Phylogenetic analysis\nrevealed strain homology with the Burkina Faso 2016 strain. This case\nmay serve as an alert to possible disease spread outside Africa.\n(https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/10/17-1132_article) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Japan can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/156). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Pacific\n\n- Samoa. 22 Jul 2017. From 6 to 17 Jul 2017, there were 43 suspected\ncases of dengue fever seen at the LBJ hospital and community health\ncenters. 15 cases confirmed from laboratory work on samples sent to\nHonolulu for testing. Physicians at LBJ hospital said they are seeing\napprox 30-50 cases per month, with symptoms related to dengue.\nAccording to a senior nurse, 10-15 patients with dengue like symptoms\nor tested positive for dengue, are admitted to LBJ per month.\n(http://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/335595/dengue-fever-on-the-rise-in-american-samoa) - Samoa. 14 Aug 2017. Current surveillance information; between 7-11\nAug 2017 doctors from the 2 main hospitals reported what appears to be\na dengue outbreak in presenting patients. The investigations continue.\nThe main hospital ICU unit and acute ward reported a sudden increase\nin cases with prolonged illness, severe headache, nausea and vomiting,\nabdominal pains, and at least one painful joint. As many as 2\nsuspected deaths have been reported. Surveillance data on PATIS\nPatient Information System shows that from January to July 2017, 37\nclinical cases and 560 requests to the lab with 5 positive cases.\nAugust 2017; 54 requests with 25 positive cases. The MoH recommends\ngeneral hygiene and source reduction of breeding sites. Drain\nlongstanding water, clean up rubbish, wear protective clothing, use\nrepellents, and mosquito nets. The public is advised to see a doctor\nas soon as possible when symptoms arise.\nThis is from an outbreak notice issued by Samoa MoH \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nMargaret Lesjak\nEpidemiology Advisor at Samoa MoH\n(margaret.lesjak@health.gov.ws) - Samoa. 16 Aug 2017. The Ministry of Health has issued an alert dated\n12 Aug 2017, about an outbreak of dengue fever in the country. As many\nas 25 cases with 2 suspected deaths. It says that the National Disease\nSurveillance and International Health Regulations Division has been\nnotified of severely ill cases from Tupua Tamasese Meaole Hospital.\n(http://sobserver.ws/en/16_08_2017/local/23251/Dengue-outbreak-warning.htm) - Samoa. 23 Aug 2017. Samoa is reported to be one of the island\nnations affected by dengue type 2. Last week week of 14 Aug 2017,\nthe island nation saw a sudden increase in the number of sick\npatients. From the registered record, the Samoan Observer reported\nthat in August alone, the lab tests reported 54 requests with 25\nconfirmed positive and 2 deaths. The 2 deaths were suspected to be\nfrom the dengue fever.
